HEADLINE: POLITICS: THE DEMOCRAT;
Clinton Says Dole's Plan Would Bust The Budget

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL 

DATELINE: SALINAS, Calif., Aug. 8

 BODY:
Savoring a last moment in the California spotlight before the Republican National Convention takes center stage, President Clinton today ridiculed Bob Dole's sweeping plan for $548 billion in tax cuts over the next six years and promised that he himself would not offer any tax cuts that jeopardized a balancing of the Federal budget.
Mr. Clinton never mentioned his Republican opponent by name. But under a bright sun here in the Central Valley that was Steinbeck country, he told a crowd, "You'll hear a lot of talk between now and November about tax cuts and how much we should have and whether we can afford them, and they all sound good." 
 "It's like going to the candy store," Mr. Clinton said. "You know, 'I'll have some of that and some of that and some of that and some of that.' But if you eat it all at once, you might get sick."
The President held out as a counterpoint his own proposals for tax credits for specific purposes like community-college tuition, and implied that Mr. Dole's approach would jeopardize programs like Medicare and Medicaid.
"I say to you that it might not be popular," he said, "but I will not advocate any cuts in taxes in this election that cannot be paid for in our attempts to balance the budget."
Mr. Dole has said his economic plan would eliminate the deficit over six years even with the tax reduction, for which he would partly pay with a surge in growth that he envisions as resulting from the cut. But the White House has ridiculed his adoption of that supply-side approach, and the targets of some of the budget cuts that would also be needed to pay for the tax breaks have been left sketchy.
California, with its 54 electoral votes, is a must-win state for Mr. Clinton, and he has lavished attention and Federal money on it, through flood, earthquake and the post-cold-war conversion of the defense industry.
Today, with Republicans arriving in San Diego for a weeklong convention that will mount a concerted assault on his record, Mr. Clinton devoted his 26th trip to the state as President to emphasis on his economic, crime-fighting and education credentials.
Much of the battle for California between Mr. Clinton and Mr. Dole has focused on crime-fighting, an issue the Republicans had long dominated until the President adopted an approach that mixed his gun-control efforts with those on victims' rights and on punitive measures like expanding the Federal death penalty.
On a stage outside the Salinas courthouse today, Mr. Clinton, surrounded by uniformed police officers, received a formal endorsement from a police organization for the first time in the current campaign. "You, more than any other President, have understood law enforcement," said Sam Cabral, the president of that group, the 80,000-member International Union of Police Associations, which supported Mr. Clinton in 1992 as well.
Mr. Clinton also used the occasion to announce that for the first time in seven years, the arrest rates among juveniles for murder and for violent crime as a whole both declined in 1995, an announcement timed to coincide with the release in Washington of new data from the Federal Bureau of Investigation.
And the arrival back home of a local Olympic hero, Alvin Harrison, born to poverty but today wearing around his neck the gold medal he won in Atlanta as a member of the 4-by-400-meter relay team, led Mr. Clinton to make a pitch for an additional way of fighting crime: providing opportunity to those who might otherwise gravitate toward gang violence.
"When you tell kids that they matter," he said, "and you tell them they can belong and that they can amount to something and they can live out their dreams and that no matter where they might start out they might wind up with a gold medal, and at least they can win a gold medal in the race of life if they do the right things, then you can change this."
Besides being significant for its electoral votes, California has been a wellspring of money for Mr. Clinton and other Democrats, and this trip was centered on a fund-raising event tonight at the Los Angeles home of Marc Nathanson, a cable television executive. The event was expected to raise $1.2 million for Democratic Congressional candidates.
Earlier, in San Jose, the President made a highly partisan speech that was delivered by satellite to a Pittsburgh conference of the United Steelworkers of America. In it, he attacked the Republican Congress and called for the Democrats to be put back in control of Capitol Hill.
"You remember what they tried to do," he said of the Republicans, "how they shut the Government down twice, what they tried to do to Medicare, Medicaid, education and the environment. Unless we win the Presidential race and change the composition of the Congress, they'll keep trying to do it over and over and over again."
 
A CELEBRATION TURNS ROWDY
 
Of the hundreds at the opening of Clinton-Gore campaign headquarters in New York, half were protesters. Metropolitan Report, page B1.

HEADLINE: Trenton Man Faces Charges in the Slayings of 4 Women

BYLINE: By DAVID STOUT 

 BODY:
At least four women who roamed the streets of a shabby part of Trenton looking for crack cocaine in the middle of the night met a slight soft-spoken young man.
The women offered sex for drugs, the police said yesterday, and because of that they died. 
 Investigators said they had charged the man, Anthony Balaam, 31, with killing four women after having lured them into drugs-for-sex encounters. The police said that Mr. Balaam, who uses crack, had confessed to the four killings and that he might be implicated in similar cases.
Mr. Balaam was described by a detective who arrested him, Anthony Manzo, as unassuming and polite, "a 'Yes, Sir, No Sir' kind of person."
Deputy Police Chief Joe Constance, who has been on the force for 27 years, called Mr. Balaam, 5 feet 5 inches and 150 pounds, "one of the calmest and coolest murderers I've encountered."
After his arrest, without incident on Wednesday, Mr. Balaam talked to detectives in polite, measured tones. "He talked about rage," Chief Constance said. "He talked about power, about his power over the women."
Investigators said Mr. Balaam would strike bargains with the women, threaten them with a knife in the sexual encounter and strangle them. Three victims were found in vacant lots and the fourth was in a rundown hotel.
The suspect has been charged with murder in the deaths of Karen Denise Patterson, 41, on Oct. 24, 1994; Valentina Cuyler, 29, on March 19, 1995; Connie Hayward, 27, on April 10, 1995, and Debora Ann Walker, 37, last July 29. Ms. Hayward was found dead in the hotel.
The deputy chief said that Mr. Balaam raped another woman on Feb. 16, but that she escaped before he could strangle her. She provided a description of the attacker, and the police soon concluded that Mr. Balaam was the man who had been killing women on the streets in the predawn hours.
Investigators said that they thought that at least one other woman had fled after having encountered Mr. Balaam, and that they hoped that she would come forward. The investigators added that they were conferring with the police in Detroit, where Mr. Balaam lived from July 1995 to last January, to determine whether he might have committed crimes there.
A homicide investigator in Detroit said yesterday that the city had no string of unsolved murders and that the police did not recognize Mr. Balaam's name.
Not much was known about Mr. Balaam. The police said he had been born in Trenton, was unemployed and lived at 421 Stuyvesant Avenue, where he was arrested about 2:30 P.M. Mr. Balaam has a roommate, the police added.
Two killings were near Mr. Balaam's home, Chief Constance said. The body of the last victim, Miss Walker, was found by Mr. Balaam's neighbors.
One of the neighbors said yesterday that she did not know Mr. Balaam, who lived a few doors away.
"Oh, my God," the neighbor, Catherine Emerson, of 415 Stuyvesant Avenue, said in a telephone interview when she learned that a murder suspect lived nearby. She said she had no image of him.
Mrs. Emerson said a neighbor telephoned her on the morning of July 29 and said, "Go look out the back door." Mrs. Emerson did so, and she saw a body in a nearby lot.
"I thought it was a little child," she said, recalling the small-frame woman who was on the grass with her blue-and-white coveralls pulled down.
Chief Constance said that DNA testing on semen recovered near two bodies had linked Mr. Balaam to the crimes and that the police hoped that further tests would tie him to all four killings and the rape on Feb. 16.
In addition to murder, Mr. Balaam has been charged with robbery and the possession of illegal weapons. He has convictions on minor burglary and drug charges and has refused offers of counsel, the police said.
Mr. Balaam was being held without bail.
Chief Constance spoke with compassion about the kind of women who were slain.
"It's like 'The Night of the Living Dead,' " he said. "They will do anything, literally anything, to obtain the drugs."

HEADLINE: At Office Of Campaign, A Protest On Welfare

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS 

 BODY:
It was intended as a celebration of Bill Clinton's strong support among New York Democrats. The opening of the Clinton-Gore campaign's New York headquarters at 300 Park Avenue yesterday was a made-for-television event that brought out the firmament of the state's best-known Democrats: former Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, former Mayor David N. Dinkins, State Comptroller H. Carl McCall and a throng of congressmen, City Council members and state legislators.
But the opening ceremony turned out to be a far more raucous affair than any of its organizers expected. Of the hundreds of people who attended the event, nearly half were protesters, voicing their disdain for the far-reaching Federal welfare bill approved by a Republican Congress and destined to be signed by the Democratic President whom the event was intended to laud. 
 The freshly opened campaign headquarters was adorned with red, white and blue Clinton-Gore signs, but there seemed to be an equal number of protesters' signs saying, "Veto the Welfare Bill." And while many of the speakers were taken aback by the vehemence of the protests, they found themselves largely agreeing that the welfare bill the President has embraced would be devastating to the New Yorkers they represent.
As speaker after speaker mounted the podium, each was heckled, booed and, ultimately, outshouted by the protesters.
"The one thing we know is that we can't permit Dole and Gingrich to be in there," Mr. Dinkins said, struggling to be heard over the roar.
"What's the difference," the protesters shouted. "Veto, Veto, Veto," they chanted in unison, drowning out the former mayor.
When Mr. Cuomo took his turn at the lectern, he told the protesters that he, too, shared their concerns about the bill, which requires states to establish a lifetime limit of five years on welfare payments to any family and abolishes a major Federal welfare program, Aid to Families with Dependent Children, replacing it with grants to states.
Mr. Cuomo said that, in a letter to the White House, he had urged the President to veto the bill. He said that the best hope for Democrats was to elect a Democratic-controlled Congress and to re-elect the President. He said he supported Mr. Clinton, recognizing that as President "sometimes you have to do things you're not totally comfortable with."
That drew the loudest chants of the afternoon, with protesters offering a chorus of "Shame, shame, shame" that left the former Governor visibly shaken.
Protests at political functions and press conferences are no novelty in New York City. But what was notable about yesterday's protest was how it seemed to touch a nerve among the politicians, who often respond to protests with nonchalance.
The protesters who disrupted yesterday's event came from an array of social service and welfare rights organizations, from the Community Food Resource Center and the Bronx Welfare Advocacy Network to Jews for Racial and Economic Justice and Housing Works.
Most of the officials at yesterday's event indicated publicly or in interviews afterward that they, too, were deeply disappointed by the President's decision to sign the welfare bill. Their disappointment, they said, reflected a major difficulty facing Mr. Clinton's campaign in the state, which has a long history of generous welfare policies.
Mr. Clinton is still expected to win handily in New York. But many of the politicians at the opening of the new headquarters questioned how enthusiastic about the President Democrats in the state would remain and whether voters' growing ambivalence might keep many of them from going to the polls in November.
"I don't like a lot of what the President's doing," said Deborah J. Glick, an Assemblywoman from Greenwich Village in one of the few moments when a speaker could be heard. But, she said, he was better than having Bob Dole, the Republican, as President. "And the best way to keep him from caving in to the Republican Congress," she said of Mr. Clinton, "is by getting rid of the Republican Congress."
In the end, some politicians said, New York Democrats would overwhelmingly support the President because they find Mr. Dole's policies too distasteful. "Let's face it," said Representative Charles E. Schumer, a Democrat from Brooklyn. "There is a lot of concern about this welfare bill and its effect on New York. But the overwhelming number of people who disagree with the President on this issue are going to wind up voting for Bill Clinton."
But several officials made it clear that the President's position on the welfare bill would require his campaign to devote more attention to New York. Judith Hope, who is chairwoman of the New York State Democratic Committee, said that resentment among some Democrats "means that there will be more work for the state party and for the campaign."
Mr. Cuomo was perhaps the most outspoken after the news conference. Speaking of the President's support of the welfare bill, he said: "There is no justification for it. It's political. He chose to do what's popular. Reagan did what was popular and it was devastating to us. Some of the time what's popular is wrong."

HEADLINE: A POLITICAL LIFE: The Legislative Years -- THE REPUBLICAN;
As Candidate, Dole Casts Off His Feats as a Skilled Senator

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH KOLBERT 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
A few days into the first campaign swing by Bob Dole as a private citizen, he was asked to list some of the accomplishments that, looking back over his long tenure in the Senate, he was most proud of.
The former Senator paused for a moment. Then he said: "Just being there. I mean being in the United States Senate. I can't think of very many days I went to work without being a little excited. You see the Capitol dome and know that you're part of something that most people would give anything for. It's a great opportunity, and a great privilege." 
 The answer -- unstudied and even moving in its modesty -- is characteristic of Mr. Dole. In person, he can be disarmingly soft-spoken, coming across as a man who, for all his obvious ambition, is genuinely self-effacing. But in its reticence the answer also points to one of the central puzzles of Mr. Dole's campaign for President.
Without doubt, Mr. Dole was one of the most influential senators of the late 20th century. First as chairman of the Senate Finance Committee and later as the Senate's Republican leader, he played a part in many -- if not most -- of the major pieces of legislation of the last 15 years. He enjoyed the respect not only of colleagues in his own party, who made him the longest-serving Republican leader in Senate history, but also of many colleagues across the aisle.
And yet Mr. Dole has still to translate this impressive record into a clear argument for his candidacy. Rarely does he refer to any of his accomplishments as a legislator or to his central role as the Senate's leading Republican. Indeed, in resigning his seat and campaigning as "just a man," Mr. Dole has seemed to be deliberately distancing himself from the long career that is his strongest claim on the Presidency.
This approach may, in part, simply reflect Mr. Dole's personality. As he observed in the same interview, "I've always had a hard time going out saying, 'I did this, I did that.' "
But, in part, it also clearly reflects the character of Mr. Dole's legislative career. Even Mr. Dole's admirers acknowledge that his accomplishments in the Senate resist the kind of neat summarizing that is required for effective campaign biography.
Unlike many of his colleagues in the Senate, Mr. Dole cannot point to a significant body of legislation that he originated. Indeed, for someone whose career in the Senate spanned nearly three decades, he has surprisingly few bills that bear his name, and one of the most prominent of these was a bill to raise taxes.
Mr. Dole can claim credit for shepherding into law many important bills written by others. But many of these bills strain against the main themes of his candidacy. They include bills that expanded Federal entitlements and mandated rafts of new Federal regulations.
Finally, Mr. Dole can point to his devoted service as Senate leader, which many call the hardest job in Washington. But he cannot easily characterize for voters the larger purpose and direction of that leadership. At different points in his 12 years at the helm, he has been a hardliner and a moderate, a partisan obstructionist and a bipartisan conciliator.
Steve Smith, a professor of political science at the University of Minnesota who has studied Senate leadership, summed up Mr. Dole's difficulties this way: "My view is he's been a fairly effective leader. But being an effective power in the Senate is a lot different from making a case for yourself as President."
Mr. Dole's service in the Senate, Mr. Smith added, "doesn't make a compelling case that he stands for a lot of things."
 
Conservative Credentials
Building a Record On Bipartisanship
At issue in November's election, Mr. Dole frequently says, are two fundamentally different visions of government. There is his vision, which he characterizes as the authentically conservative. And then there is President Clinton's.
"Can you imagine what Bill Clinton would do in a second term -- his liberalism unrestrained by the need to face the American people?" he asked an audience recently in Ohio.
By many measures, Mr. Dole's legislative record matches his conservative rhetoric. Over the years, his positions on a range of issues from from defense spending to the environment have consistently won near-perfect ratings from groups on the right, and near-zero scores from those on the left.
But the major bills Mr. Dole is most closely associated with tend to cloud rather than confirm his conservative credentials. Several are bills Mr. Dole championed in opposition to conservative lawmakers and in concert with liberal ones. And while supporters of Mr. Dole say the bills demonstrate a statesmanly commitment to bipartisanship, even they concede this is not necessarily a quality that a Presidential candidate these days wants to stress.
"If you were to define Bob Dole, it would be on his willingness to work across party lines to find solutions to the nation's problems," said Norman Ornstein, a Congressional scholar at the American Enterprise Institute and self-described admirer of Mr. Dole. "But as he moves toward the election, that's not particularly the message he wants to send."
Mr. Dole's first real legislative triumphs were a product of one of the more unlikely partnerships in American politics.
As chairman of the Republican Party in the early 1970's, Mr. Dole had routinely denounced Senator George McGovern, Democrat of South Dakota, accusing him and his 1972 Presidential campaign of a host of legal as well as ethical lapses. Not long after Mr. McGovern lost to Richard M. Nixon in a landslide, though, Mr. Dole became one of Mr. McGovern's closest allies, working with him on efforts to expand Federal nutrition programs. With Mr. McGovern, Mr. Dole helped pass legislation that enlarged the food stamp and the school lunch programs, inaugurated the Women, Infants and Children program and eventually eliminated the requirement that food stamp recipients pay part of the cost of their benefits.
All of these bills were popular among farmers -- clearly a factor in the Kansas Senator's support for them. But Mr. McGovern, also a farm-state representative, said that while Mr. Dole might have initially been most attracted to benefits the programs provided farmers, he came to be "really moved by what those programs did to help kids and hard-pressed families."
In his farewell speech to the Senate, Mr. Dole alluded to his partnership with Mr. McGovern, acknowledging that it has over the years often given conservatives pause.
"I remember working with Senator McGovern, and that crops up now and then in conservative articles, saying that I can't be a conservative because I know George McGovern," Mr. Dole said, adding, "I think George McGovern is a gentleman and has always been a gentleman."
Another important legislative victory credited to Mr. Dole was a product of a similarly improbable bipartisan alliance.
In 1982, crucial sections of the Voting Rights Act came up for renewal. Two years earlier, the Supreme Court had made it more difficult -- some argued impossible -- for voters to sue under the act, ruling that victims of discrimination had to show the discrimination was intentional.
Liberal lawmakers, led in the Senate by Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, argued that voters should be able to prove discrimination based on "results" not "intent." But conservative senators maintained that an emphasis on "results" rather than "intent" would ultimately lead to demands for proportional representation and racial quotas.
It was Mr. Dole who came up with the compromise that bridged the gulf. The compromise said that judges could consider the "totality of circumstances" surrounding a case of possible discrimination, but also stipulated that no minority group had a right to proportional representation.
Ralph Neas, counsel to the Leadership Conference on Civil Rights, who worked with Mr. Dole on drafting the compromise, recalled that after the deal was completed, Mr. Dole had managed to persuade a reluctant President Reagan to embrace it, too.
"It was a great story of Senator Dole at his best, getting everybody under the tent," Mr. Neas said.
Mr. Dole played an analogous role on the Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990, or A.D.A. The measure, which provided sweeping protections for the disabled, was opposed by conservative senators, who argued that it would be onerous to business and provoke a rash of lawsuits. Some of these senators had threatened to keep the bill bottled up in committee; once again working with liberal Democrats, like Mr. Kennedy and Senator Tom Harkin of Iowa, Mr. Dole helped guide it onto the floor and past the objections of some in the Bush Administration.
Tony Coelho, the former House Democratic whip and the chief sponsor of the bill before his resignation in 1989, called Mr. Dole "the spiritual father of A.D.A. in the Senate."
"We would never had gotten it through if Bob Dole hadn't been supportive," Mr. Coelho said.
Critics of Mr. Dole argue that his record on these important bills, viewed in the context of his current campaign, betrays a philosophy of government that is really no philosophy at all. And they maintain it will be difficult for Mr. Dole, who is now advocating a smaller and less intrusive Federal government, to get much political mileage out of a set of bills that helped to expand the reach of the Federal government.
"The issue is whether there's a consistency in what he believes," said Howard Paster, President Clinton's former chief Congressional liaison. "Is Bob Dole really going to campaign as the key Republican on A.D.A., or the one who helped bring about food stamps?"
Mr. Dole's supporters maintain, by contrast, that there is no ideological friction between the highlights of his Senate career and the themes of his current campaign.
Sheila Burke, Mr. Dole's former Senate chief of staff, who herself was often an object of conservatives' wrath, pointed to Mr. Dole's work on food stamps, on the Voting Rights Act of 1982, and on the Americans With Disabilities Act as some of his most significant achievements. Underlying all these measures, she argued, is the same philosophy that guides Mr. Dole today.
"It is a compassionate but focused government," Ms. Burke said.
 
The Tax Record
'Old-Time Religion' On Deficit Cutting
For decades, an anti-tax message has been a staple of Republican Presidential politics. This year promises to be no different.
Just this week, Mr. Dole announced that if elected, he would press for a 15 percent across-the-board cut in personal income tax rates. The proposal, unveiled after months of debate among the candidate's advisers, is clearly intended to position him as the nation's best hope for tax relief.
Here again, though, Mr. Dole's record in the Senate is likely to be of little help.
"What really comes to mind as a true Dole product?" said Barbara Sinclair, a Congressional scholar at U.C.L.A. "It's something he probably doesn't want to have remembered -- the 1982 tax bill."
The bill was titled the Tax Equity and Fiscal Responsibility Act of 1982, or, as it is known in Washington, Tefra. Mr. Dole, at that time the chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, was the act's chief author and the moving force behind its bitterly fought progress.
Although tax bills normally originate in the House Ways and Means Committee, Tefra was not a normal bill. In an extraordinary departure from the usual protocol, the bill eventually went to a House-Senate conference with no House version at all; just a few months before a national election, the Democrats who controlled the House were only too happy to step aside and the Republicans who controlled the Senate take credit -- or blame -- for the tax equity act.
Mr. Dole proposed Tefra two years into the Reagan Presidency as a response to the ballooning Federal deficit. Just the year before, Congress had approved the foundational plank of supply-side economics -- a 25 percent cut in individual income tax rates.
As one former Reagan Administration official put it, the act was "the revenge of everyone who was against supply-side economics." The act raised revenues through a series of incremental -- and often arcane -- changes in the I.R.S. code; among its provisions, it increased excise taxes on cigarettes and phone service, increased airport fees, and raised the threshold at which medical expenses became tax deductible. All told, the bill was expected to generate over $100 billion.
In his recently re-issued autobiography, Mr. Dole defends the tax act and the principles behind it this way: "If the old-time religion says you can't endlessly spend more than you take in, then old-time religion is good enough for me."
Over the next several years, Mr. Dole would continue to champion deficit reduction, even at the expense of raising taxes.
In 1983, together with Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, Democrat of New York, he helped engineer a deal to save the Social Security system from insolvency; the deal included a significant increase in payroll taxes as well as a six-month delay in cost-of-living adjustments. The next year, Mr. Dole helped push through a numbingly complicated set of tax increases aimed at reducing the deficit by $50 billion.
In 1985, Mr. Dole, then Senate majority leader, made another bold stand in favor of fiscal responsibility, leading the Senate to adopt a budget plan that would have eliminated 13 Federal programs and, perhaps even more significantly, reduced benefits to Social Security recipients.
The Senate vote on the bill was the sort of cliffhanger rarely captured on C-Span. Then-Senator Pete Wilson of California arrived by ambulance after an emergency appendectomy to cast the crucial "aye" vote, while then-Vice President George Bush flew from Arizona to break the tie. The vote was, at the time, seen as a major victory for Mr. Dole.
Just a few weeks later, though, the Reagan Administration backed away from the Senate bill and its high political price tag, leaving Mr. Dole and his caucus to bear the cost alone. The next year, the Democrats regained control of the Senate.
Mr. Dole's admirers point to the tax and budget bills he championed in the early 1980's as signs of his willingness to take tough political stands when the national interest is at stake. But Congressman Newt Gingrich of Georgia, at that time a House backbencher, was referring to these same bills when he famously branded Mr. Dole "the tax collector of the welfare state."
 
The Political Actor
Reconciling Public And Private Roles
When Mr. Dole resigned from the Senate in June, his colleagues lined up to praise him. Republicans recalled his shrewdness, his sense of honor and his ever-sharp wit. Democrats, for their part, were hardly less admiring.
"His sense of fairness and decency is a standard by which all people in public life should be held," said the Senate's Democratic leader, Tom Daschle of South Dakota, who, on matters of substance, tangled with Mr. Dole almost daily.
The praise was more than mere professional courtesy. As the leading Republican in the Senate for 12 years, Mr. Dole affected the lives of virtually every member, helping to determine whether their bills passed and when they got home for the vacation. In this role, Mr. Dole earned the esteem both of colleagues who agreed with him on questions of public policy and those, like Senator Moynihan, who generally did not.
"He has admirers across the political spectrum," Mr. Ornstein observed, "and very few enemies."
What his colleagues prized in Mr. Dole's leadership were skills that, almost by definition, are exercised behind closed doors. Mr. Dole, his fellow Senators observe, was expert in a kind of delicate negotiation and tactical maneuvering that is the real work of the legislative process. His contribution to a bill could consist of offering an amendment to satisfy a crucial but recalcitrant senator, or of persuading a senator not to offer an amendment that could upset a carefully crafted deal. As one former Dole aide put it: "People will never even know a lot of what he did late one night in the Senate."
In the dozen years that Mr. Dole led his fellow Republicans, control of the Senate switched parties twice, first forcing him to give up the majority leader's title and take on the less-exalted minority leader's post, then allowing him to reclaim it. In both positions, Mr. Dole's job was to maintain a unified Republican caucus, a job that grew increasingly difficult as the Senate grew more fractious and individual members more assertive.
In the same years, control of the White House also shifted from one party to the other. By the time Mr. Dole resigned in June, he had played every possible part in the leadership repertoire: majority and minority leader under a Republican President, as well as minority and majority leader under a Democratic President.
Ms. Burke, Mr. Dole's former chief of staff, said the Senator "didn't seem to have difficulty shifting roles" as his job description changed, and it is a credit to Mr. Dole's versatility that his Republican colleagues never seemed to question his ability to make the needed transitions. Indeed, even as one of his chief allies, Senator Alan K. Simpson of Wyoming, was ousted from the position of Republican whip, Mr. Dole was never seriously challenged.
But if Mr. Dole's record as a Senator presents difficulties for him as a Presidential candidate, his versatility as a political actor is potentially just as problematic.
On Capitol Hill, Mr. Dole's range of political personas was accepted as a necessary response to the shifting demands of his position. Colleagues point out, for example, that when former Senator George Mitchell was majority leader and Mr. Dole minority leader, the two maintained a close working relationship in private even as Mr. Dole excoriated Mr. Mitchell on the floor. For voters, on the other hand, the range of Mr. Dole's roles may simply be confusing.
Americans who remember Mr. Dole from his early years in the Senate, when he served a term as Republican Party chairman, are likely to recall a fierce partisan, one who seemed always willing, even eager, to lash out at his Democratic opponents. Those who remember Mr. Dole from the midpoint of his career are likely to view him as a more moderate figure, a conciliator willing to set aside party advantage for bipartisan agreement. So stark was the contrast in Mr. Dole's behavior, in fact, that journalists in the early 1980's began to speak of a "new" Bob Dole. And some of the Senator's former allies began to question whether he was still committed to conservative causes.
In the last years of his Senate career Mr. Dole's public image went through yet another gyration, from conciliator back to staunch partisan.
Under pressure from his caucus to be more assertive, Mr. Dole became expert at using Senate procedure to all but paralyze the Democratic-controlled chamber, delaying or killing outright a host of Democratic-backed initiatives, including, most famously, President Clinton's economic stimulus package of 1993, which the Administration abandoned when it became clear it could not overcome a Senate Republican filibuster.
When the Republicans took over Congress in 1994, Mr. Dole's renewed partisanship became, if anything, more pronounced. Many had predicted a rocky relationship between the new House Speaker and the longtime Senate Republican leader. The rise of Newt Gingrich, after all, represented a shift of power in the party away from Mr. Dole and his entire generation, toward a younger, more militant group of lawmakers.
But Mr. Dole was determined not to be outflanked by the hardliners in the House -- or by Senator Phil Gramm of Texas, who was hoping to wrest the Republican Presidential nomination from him -- and he often deferred to Mr. Gingrich on key tactical decisions. Thus, for example, although he generally opposed shutting down the Government as a negotiating tactic in budget talks last year, Mr. Dole agreed to a shutdown when House Republicans insisted they would oppose efforts to reach a compromise with the Administration.
"Might he have moved more quickly on the budget stuff and not shut the Government down?" Ms. Burke asked. "He would probably say 'yes.' "
Ultimately, Mr. Dole's identity in the Senate was, according to many, that of a political pragmatist in the broadest sense of the term.
"Dole is very much from the old school of believing you have to compromise to get things done," Ms. Sinclair, the U.C.L.A. Congressional scholar, said. "But he also has a long history as a sharp partisan. When for partisan reasons, blocking seemed to be the best policy, he certainly was willing to do that."
 
The Insider
Thriving in the Role Of a Deal Maker
One of the keys to Mr. Dole's long tenure as a Senate leader, according to his colleagues, was that he understood the internal dynamic of his caucus so well. Mr. Dole seemed to carry a file in his head, they say, of each member's concerns, from the principles he held dear to the pet projects he wanted protected. And he knew how to use this knowledge to coax and, more occasionally, threaten the members into line.
"He knows where the pressure points are," said Warren B. Rudman, the former Republican Senator from New Hampshire. "And the key to that is understanding everyone and what their needs are. He's not a social guy, but he's a very close observer of humankind."
Mr. Dole himself said: "If I've been successful, it's because I try to know everyone. I tried to know my colleagues and what their interests were. I knew where they were from and what their hot buttons were."
He also knew, colleagues suggest, how important it was to let his fellow Senators have their say; often they did not even know where he stood on a given matter under debate. "His genius is really allowing something to work itself out," said Senator William S. Cohen, Republican of Maine. "He will allow the arguments to play themselves out until you reach a consensus or stalemate."
When agreements were reached, Mr. Dole was known among members of both parties as a man who kept his word. "You could meet with him for 10, 15 minutes and cut a deal and know he would deliver," said Mr. Coelho, the former Democratic House whip.
But above all else, Mr. Dole's colleagues trace his success as a Senate leader to his intense commitment to the institution and, beyond that, his genuine passion for the give-and-take of legislative politics. His hours on the job are legendary, and it is widely asserted that he was happiest when he had two or three meetings going simultaneously.
"Bob is a consummate politician," one longtime adviser observed. "He loves the legislative process. While others had families and interests, he has thought mostly about the Senate and how to get things accomplished. He enjoys it the way other people enjoy golf."
The qualities Mr. Dole brought to his job as Senate leader -- a mastery of the legislative process, an understanding of the folkways of Congress, a commitment to honoring agreements -- are also qualities that presumably would be desirable in a President. Mr. Dole said he thought "it would be a lot easier being President" than Senate majority leader, adding "I frankly don't think Clinton's done a very good job of working with Congress."
But Mr. Dole's skills are also skills that do not necessarily translate well on the campaign trail. They are skills that evoke late-night log rolling and split-the-difference deal-making; skills, in other words that smack of political insiderdom.
"I think being a Senate leader and getting things done is a good thing and will work to Dole's favor," Mr. Smith, of the University of Minnesota, said. "But those aren't the same traits that make an attractive Presidential candidate."
Mr. Dole is clearly aware of Americans' impatience with the political process, and the challenge this poses for him as a candidate. Asked whether Congress deserved its low standing in popular opinion, Mr. Dole said it did not. Then he turned ironic.
"If you go out and say how do you rate your Senator on a scale of 1 to 10, I assume most of us would get a 6 or 7," he said. "How do you rate all these people together? You get about a, what, a 2 or 3? It's only when we're together. If we don't ever meet, we're great."

HEADLINE: Atlantans Made An Olympic Effort

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Capitalism Won No Medals" (Op-Ed, Aug. 4), by the Le Monde columnist Erik Izraelewicz, is a wonderful example of the French notion that all works best when entrusted to authoritarian technocrats as long as they are provided with endless funds from taxpayers. Atlanta's approach to the Olympics (fundamentally a private initiative) has certainly made Mr. Izraelewicz's stomach turn.
But let us not apologize for the "two weeks of questionable efficiency, horrendous traffic jams and computer foul-ups." Every noble effort falls short of perfection. Instead, let us celebrate the citizens of Atlanta and their heroic efforts, even in the face of adversity. 
 And if we really want to celebrate, let us celebrate our freedom from those authoritarian technocrats who have brought France unemployment of more than 13 percent, a bankrupt social security system and payroll taxes that can exceed 60 percent.
 
L. J. DE OCEJO
Long Lake, Minn., Aug., 4, 1996

HEADLINE: A New Fashion Attitude by Women? Maybe;
High Fashion Lives

 BODY:
To the Editor:
If the fashion industry were in the dire shape you suggest in your front-page stories (Aug. 5, 6), those of us who report on fashion could put down our pencils and go home. As it is, the fashion industry is alive and well, and it is curious that you should choose this moment to suggest otherwise.
In the wake of the 1987 stock market crash, the fashion industry suffered serious setbacks, as did virtually every other industry in the country. Few people while away a recession shopping for co-ops, cars or clothes.
More recently, a stronger economy has resulted in more confident consumers, who, however chastened by the early 90's, are not so chastened that they are ready to spend the late 90's dressed exclusively in khakis and T-shirts. 
 As for the evidence you have compiled to prove that fashion is a dated folly American women are no longer willing to indulge, I find it incomplete. For example, while Sharon Stone did wear a black Gap turtleneck to the Oscars this year, she wore a Giorgio Armani evening coat over that turtleneck -- a detail you chose to omit.
Another example is the news that Martha's has closed its Park Avenue doors. But the vacancy left by Martha's has been more than filled by Calvin Klein, Chanel, Giorgio Armani, Prada, Gianni Versace and Valentino, all of whom either have opened or are about to open dazzling new stores in Manhattan.
There is another indicator that the rumors of fashion's death are greatly exaggerated: the 708-page September issue of Vogue is the largest since September 1989.
 
ANNA WINTOUR
New York, Aug. 7, 1996
 
Editor in Chief, Vogue

LENGTH: 1247 words

HEADLINE: POLITICS: POLITICAL MEMO;
A Final Round In Dole's Dance To Pick a No. 2

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE 

DATELINE: SAN DIEGO, Aug. 8

 BODY:
Just two days before he plans to announce his choice of a running mate, Bob Dole let it be known today that he had added a late entrant to the Vice-Presidential list, Jack F. Kemp, with whom Mr. Dole has often feuded in the past.
But for all the sudden interest in Mr. Kemp, one person close to both him and Mr. Dole cautioned that the ever-evolving list could change again by nightfall. Mr. Kemp, he said, was the top contender "for the hour." 
 So goes the quadrennial dance of the running mates. Before Mr. Kemp's rise, Senator Connie Mack of Florida was purported to be Mr. Dole's favorite on the list. A day or so earlier, it was Senator John McCain of Arizona on the top of the list. Former Gov. Carroll A. Campbell of South Carolina has been on and off more times than a head waiter's smile.
Then there is Gov. John Engler of Michigan. For a year he was the contender most heavily promoted (often by his own aides). Then, Mr. Dole's advisers said they were not interested. Then they were. Now, no one knows where Mr. Engler stands.
In fact, only one man -- Bob Dole -- knows where all the Vice-Presidential wannabees stand. And, as a politician who likes to pop surprises, he must be thoroughly enjoying the confusion. After all, Mr. Dole had told aides that he would not have gone through with his dramatic decision to quit the Senate in June had the move been leaked to the press.
Today only Mr. Dole knew whether he would really pick Mr. Kemp. Or whether he was tossing out the name to keep the guessing game going (better to have the press focus on a running mate than on the tussling over abortion). Or whether he was trying to prove to stalwart supply-siders that he really does believe that tax cut he proposed this week will strengthen the economy.
"Bob Dole may have been thinking about Kemp for the last three months and not told any one," said former Senator Warren B. Rudman of New Hampshire, who is close to Mr. Dole and marvels at his love of suspense.
Asked for his best analysis of Mr. Dole's thinking, Mr. Rudman -- who once served on the Senate Intelligence Committee, said this afternoon, "at least until yesterday, he didn't know." But then again, Mr. Rudman quickly added, even if Mr. Dole had made up his mind, he might not have told him.
If for no other reason, the notion of a Dole-Kemp ticket is intriguing because the two have never been fond of each other. Republicans were rolling their eyes at the vision of the laconic Mr. Dole gritting his teeth through weekly lunches at the White House with a garrulous Vice President Kemp.
Mr. Kemp, 61, a Housing Secretary in the Bush Administration, has many appealing attributes.
But most of Mr. Dole's advisers had ruled out Mr. Kemp on the day last April when he infuriated Mr. Dole by endorsing Steve Forbes's sputtering bid for the Republican nomination. That capped years of tension between the two men.
The strain between Mr. Dole and Mr. Kemp was most public in 1988 when both vied -- unsuccessfully -- for the Republican Presidential nomination.
After a mailing by the Kemp campaign attacked Mr. Dole for trying to freeze Social Security cost-of-living adjustments, Mr. Dole lambasted Mr. Kemp for trying "to scare old people."
The Clinton campaign is no doubt salivating over the possibilities for commercials, such as a reminder that Mr. Kemp once ridiculed Mr. Dole and then-Vice President George Bush as "old guard Republicans."
Jude Wanniski, a political economist who for months has promoted Mr. Kemp as the best choice for Mr. Dole, said Mr. Kemp's outspokenness was an attribute. "The big argument against Jack is that he's a loose cannon on deck," he said. "What Dole is saying is, 'With Jack Kemp in the adjoining office to mine, whenever I have an uncontrollable urge to raise taxes or bomb North Korea, Jack will tackle me in the corridors.' " Mr. Wanniski played down the strains between the two, saying, "I know Dole doesn't dislike Jack as much as everyone thinks he does."
Whatever their motivation, Mr. Dole's aides today were unexpectedly enthusiastic about the potential for a Kemp pick. They noted that Mr. Dole met with the former Buffalo Congressman for at least two hours on Wednesday night at the Watergate complex in Washington, where Mr. Dole owns an apartment.
Aides to Mr. Dole said that, for now, their plan is to unveil his running mate on Saturday in Mr. Dole's hometown of Russell, Kan., before the two arrive here for the Republican National Convention that opens on Monday.
The betting on the running-mate is something of an industry for politicians, consultants and analysts who are talked-out on abortion and on the strengths and weaknesses of Bob Dole. Some of the speculation center on whether Mr. Kemp's apparent emergence is a sign that the nominee-in-waiting is hard pressed to find a choice who would get voters' attention, fill the specifications Mr. Dole has set for the No. 2 slot and satisfy all of the competing constituencies within the Republican Party.
Part of the frustration for the Dole camp is that even Mr. Dole's advisers say they still long for a powerhouse like Gen. Colin L. Powell, who is wildly popular in the polls but has professed not to be interested in the Vice Presidency. Without General Powell, some advisers say, the choice may come down to a contender who will simply not damage the ticket.
"I've always felt that Colin Powell would be a terrific Vice President and I believe the next best choice is Jack Kemp," said Steven Merksamer, a lawyer in Sacramento, Calif., who is close to Mr. Kemp and an informal adviser to the Dole campaign. "The rest of the choices are fine, but I don't think any of them have the charisma or the energy."
Mr. Dole has long said that his main concern about the selection was that he be comfortable with his running mate. But Mr. Dole has also said he wanted someone who would score a '10' with the public -- and others whom his advisers have said have been considered may be solid but have never been accused of being exciting: Mr. Mack is not well known nationally; Mr McCain has had a social life that may be a bit too colorful for some Republicans; Mr. Campbell is a consummate Washington insider; and Mr. Engler is thought by some Republicans to have little charm.
Michael Nelson, a political scientist at Rhodes College in Memphis who has written extensively about the Vice-Presidential selection process, was not ready to believe the whispers about Mr. Kemp. Asked to evaluate the possible choice, he said: "It will depend on whether he's seriously considering Kemp or making a show. It's not clear to me whether he's seriously considering Kemp or creating an illusion that he's seriously considering Kemp."
Despite their differences, Mr. Kemp is regarded as having many plusses: He can be be presented as possessing the stature and experience to step into the Oval Office. He is popular with the party's rank and file. He is well liked by some Democrats because of his championing of inner cities.
"Kemp has always been someone who Dole has been interested in because he, simultaneously, is the most popular Republican among Republicans and the most popular Republican among Democrats," said a senior aide to Mr. Dole, speaking on the condition that he not be identified. But there is another reason Mr. Dole may -- or may not -- be thinking of Mr. Kemp. As the candidate said recently of his selection: "It'll be, hopefully, a surprise. But not to me."

GRAPHIC: Photo: After aides said Bob Dole's running-mate prospects were down to three, he arrived for a talk with Jack Kemp. (Reuters)

HEADLINE: World News Briefs;
U.N. Backs Iraq Oil Sales

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Aug. 8

 BODY:
The Iraqi sanctions committee approved procedures today allowing Iraq to export oil to raise money for food and medicine, diplomats said.
The approval was a formality after the United States said Wednesday that it would accept the program; the committee's other 14 members had already agreed. 
 Iraq is to sell $2 billion worth of oil over six months, on a renewable basis. Before exports can begin, the United Nations must appoint overseers to approve individual contracts and station monitors in Iraq.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
The Mark Rises on New Doubt About Europe's Money Plan

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar ended mostly lower yesterday on dimming prospects for higher interest rates in the United States and a broad rally in the German mark, which benefited from new doubts about plans for one European currency by 1999.
Traders said the mark's strength was the dominant theme in the market, reflecting fear that divergent agendas of the large European countries would undermine the proposed single currency. The mark has tended to rise on any sign that the proposal might be delayed or altered. 
 The French franc was particularly hard hit by surging demand for marks, falling to a four-month low against the German currency. France, Europe's second-biggest economy behind Germany, is facing big deficit problems and may not meet the strict criteria required under the single-currency plan.
"We had a big flight to quality to the Deutsche mark today," said Jack Stearns, an analyst with Refco Group in Chicago.
In late New York trading yesterday, the dollar settled at 1.4780 marks, down from 1.4842 Thursday. The dollar traded at 108.24 yen, unchanged from Thursday. The British pound slipped to $1.5485 from $1.5490.
The dollar's steadiness against the yen reflects an expectation that interest rates in Japan will remain at historic lows for a while. Japanese finance officials said earlier this week that they foresaw no need to raise them. Rising rates in Japan would tend to strengthen the yen by increasing the return on yen-denominated investments.
The prospect of steady or lower rates in Japan emerged early yesterday after the Bank of Japan reported sluggish lending by Japanese banks in July. The data suggested that many companies were still unwilling or unable to borrow because the economy remained weak.
The dollar benefited from that news initially but the gain was offset later when the Labor Department reported that producer prices stagnated in July. The report, coupled with other evidence of an economic slowdown in the United States, suggested that the Federal Reserve would not raise interest rates at its next policy-making meeting Aug. 20.
"With dollar-yen, there was no reason to sell or buy today," said Kosuke Hanao, head of foreign exchange trading at the New York office of the Industrial Bank of Japan.

HEADLINE: More Previews Than Performances

BYLINE: By RALPH BLUMENTHAL 

 BODY:
Largely sold out since its previews began on July 25, "Hughie," the Eugene O'Neill revival directed by and starring Al Pacino at Circle in the Square, has extended its run by two weeks, to Sept. 14.
The one-act drama, about a restless gambler who talks the ear off a night clerk at a fleabag hotel, is not scheduled for its official opening until Aug. 22, and was to have closed on Aug. 31. Still, it will probably be seen by more people before its opening than after. 
 As the wisecracking Pacino character, Erie Smith, might ask: What gives?
Only the latest example of that latter-day Broadway institution: the extended preview.
After the famously exacting Mr. Pacino tried out the play for nearly three weeks last month at the Long Wharf Theater in New Haven, it came to Broadway for four more weeks of performances designated as previews, from which critics, by convention, are excluded. The play, last seen on Broadway in 1973 with Ben Gazzara, was to have run only 10 more days after its opening, but the extension has added 14 days. So: previews, 28 days; regular run, 24 days.
Although ticket prices at preview performances are often discounted, seats at the previews of "Hughie" have been going at full price, $55. But a spokesman for Circle in the Square said yesterday that starting on Sept. 2, it would make available 50 tickets at each performance for same-day sale at $20. In addition, he said, students with valid identification will have access to 50 more seats on Aug. 25 and Sept. 8 for same-day sale at $20.
The indelicate balance of a performing schedule that consigns the opening to the tail end of a run is hardly unknown on Broadway. Presenters of musical spectacles in particular have sometimes looked to the relative financial security of a long preview run as insurance against a bad review. Off Broadway, Joseph Papp became adept at prolonged previews at the Public Theater, but the practice has been less common at nonprofit theaters like Circle in the Square.
Mr. Pacino, approached through representatives, did not respond to requests for an interview. But Josephine R. Abady, co-artistic director of the theater, said that Mr. Pacino's crowded schedule allowed for only a limited run. "Our feeling is any artist deserves two or three weeks of previews," she said. She said that "Hughie," like other plays, depended on "a collaborative process" between artists and audience that took time to perfect.
When it comes to previews, "people are savvy theatergoers," she said. "They understand it's an opportunity for an artist to amend his work." She called Mr. Pacino "extremely meticulous about the production" and said there was no intention to bypass the critics, although, she said, the heavy ticket sales meant the show did not have to depend on critics for an audience.
The circumstances parallel Mr. Pacino's last appearance at Circle in the Square, in 1992, when he starred in two one-act plays, "Salome" and "Chinese Coffee," which were not open to reviewers until almost six weeks into a two-month run.
Now previews are again in the spotlight. The New Yorker this week raised the issue in a short article on "Hughie" that slipped in a brief pre-opening critique (positive) of Mr. Pacino's performance. Some critics argue that with so many people flocking to the show or clamoring to get in, the public should not be deprived of an evaluation.
While producers would still prefer to rehearse a show away from New York City's prying eyes and ears, said the longtime producer Alexander Cohen, the economics are prohibitive. "To take a show to Boston for two weeks," he said, "would cost $400,000." Instead, he said, shows are now routinely tested or fine-tuned in previews.
Bernard Gersten, executive director of Lincoln Center Theater, said: "We normally preview for the better part of four weeks. With a new play, you're wrestling with the text and revisions with the playwright. With a revival, you're dealing with nuance." But he acknowledged that there had been abuses by producers trying to maximize income before a reckoning with the critics.
After the Broadway musical "Merlin" went through eight weeks of previews, seating 60,000 full-paying customers with no sign of opening, Frank Rich of The New York Times attended unbidden in 1983, finding little to like apart from the illusionist stunts of the magician Doug Henning.
Even more notorious was the musical "Nick and Nora," which performed 71 previews over nine weeks in front of 100,000 customers paying full price before the troubled show opened in December 1991 and closed after nine performances. The experience prompted an inquiry by the city's Department of Consumer Affairs and a new industry practice of clearly labeling as previews all shows that have not been open to review.
For their part, many producers link the growing reliance on previews to a concentration of power in the hands of ever fewer critics, increasing the risks of a critical failure. "There's an undue dependence of the Broadway theater on the critic," said Robert Brustein, artistic director of the American Repertory Theater in Cambridge, Mass., and theater critic of The New Republic. "They want to run as long as possible before the death sentence."

HEADLINE: Price Report Shows No Sign Of Inflation

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 9

 BODY:
Inflation is nowhere to be found these days.
After more than five years of solid economic expansion -- and a spring surge at perhaps twice the sustainable pace -- producer prices for finished goods showed no change in July while goods at an earlier stage of production declined in price for a second month, Labor Department figures showed today. 
 David Orr, an economist for the First Union Corporation in Charlotte, N.C., called it "an amazing performance," adding that it would be hard to imagine any reason for the Federal Reserve to raise short-term interest rates at its Aug. 20 meeting.
The bond market rallied on the figures, which were better than most analysts had expected. The yield on the 30-year Treasury bond fell 10 basis points, to 6.69 percent. Stocks, however, finished lower.
The prices of finished goods -- those ready for sale to the final business or individual user -- remained flat last month, helped by the third consecutive monthly decline in energy prices. When the volatile energy component was excluded, prices rose one-tenth of 1 percent.
Over the last 12 months, producer inflation has been at an overall rate of 2.6 percent. The rate was only 1.5 percent without energy or food, another erratic component.
"This is an excellent reading," William V. Sullivan Jr., a senior economist at Dean Witter Reynolds, said of today's report. "What was particularly impressive was the total absence of pressures in the pipeline," he said, referring to the price of goods at the next-earlier stage of production, like bolts of cloth or sacks of flour. For these goods, prices fell three-tenths of 1 percent last month to generate the first back-to-back decline in nearly five years.
Raw materials climbed 1.2 percent in price last month, recovering about half of the June decline. Crude goods other than food and energy fell a hefty 1.6 percent, a bit more than in June, to bring the 12-month decline to 13.5 percent.
The only apparent inflation risk might come from a tightening labor market. With the unemployment rate at 5.4 percent, many employers have been forced to step up efforts to attract and retain workers.
If the still-subdued pace of pay increases was to accelerate, the shift would probably show up in the Consumer Price Index -- 57 percent of which reflects the price of services -- before it would push up the Producer Price Index, which only indirectly reflects pay.
The consumer index for July, to be released Tuesday, is expected to show a moderate rise of two-tenths of 1 percent, further reassuring an inflation-wary Federal Reserve.
Still, with a nod toward the possibility of surprise, Mr. Sullivan and other analysts did not entirely rule out a Fed move to tighten monetary policy this month.
The flat showing of producer prices in today's report was heavily influenced by a decline of nine-tenths of 1 percent in the price of energy. Gasoline prices fell 2.8 percent while residential electricity prices dropped eight-tenths of 1 percent.
Food, meanwhile, edged up just two-tenths of 1 percent, after June's surge of 1.6 percent. Last month, the price of fresh fruits and melons tumbled 15.4 percent, pork prices dropped and the prices of dairy products, beef, veal and processed chickens rose at a slower pace.
Passenger car prices registered a drop of nine-tenths of 1 percent, essentially erasing a June rise, while textiles for the home jumped 1.7 percent and capital equipment rose three-tenths of 1 percent, the largest increase since November.
Among intermediate goods, which as a group are now two-tenths of 1 percent less costly than in July 1995, nondurables used in manufacturing dropped eight-tenths of 1 percent. In June, nondurables were unchanged. The prices of plastic resins, chemicals and paint materials turned down and paper prices fell again. But, the price of wood pulp accelerated, jumping 5.3 percent after advancing 2.9 percent in June.
For durables used in factory processes, overall prices turned down by nine-tenths of 1 percent as aluminum ready for fabrication fell faster and various forms of hot-rolled steel rose at a slower pace than in June. Copper, aluminum and plywood prices also fell less than in June, while the price of flat glass turned higher.
The index for construction materials eased one-tenth of 1 percent in July, after a rise of four-tenths of 1 percent. Softwood lumber slumped 3.2 percent, reversing a June rise.

HEADLINE: Rally Sends Bond Yields To the Lowest In 4 Months

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
The bond market rallied strongly yesterday after a Government report showed that inflation at the producer level remained subdued in July. The rally pushed long-term interest rates to a four-month low.
Bond prices rose after the Labor Department reported that producer prices over all were unchanged in July, after a rise of two-tenths of 1 percent in June. 
 The core Producer Price Index, which excludes the volatile energy and food sectors, rose a slight one-tenth of 1 percent in July, against an increase of two-tenths of 1 percent in June.
"The P.P.I. data show there is not even a glimmer of an inflation problem in the pipeline," said Christopher Low, senior economist at HSBC Markets Inc. "The inflation picture is excellent."
The inflation data lured investors back to the market after two days of losses tied to a large influx of fresh bonds from the Treasury's quarterly refunding auctions.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond rose 22/32 , to 10026/32 . The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, fell from 6.79 percent on Thursday to 6.69 percent, the lowest the yield has been since early April.
The report on producer prices bolstered expectations that the Federal Reserve would leave interest rates unchanged at the next meeting of its policy-making committee on Aug. 20.
"The market got a good boost from the P.P.I. report," said William Sharp, an economist at Smith Barney Inc.
Treasury bonds also received a helping hand from two surprising interventions by the Federal Reserve, as the central bank bought back Treasury securities in an effort to add reserves to the nation's banking system.
During the operations, known in the market as coupon passes, the Fed bought securities with maturities ranging from Nov. 15, 2006, to Feb. 15, 2026. It also bought securities expiring from Aug. 15, 2001, to July 15, 2006.
Both operations are for delivery on Monday.
Analysts said the Fed action was technical and reflected a seasonal currency need in the economy.
The operations had no implications for monetary policy, the analysts said.
Michael Strauss, chief economist at Yamaichi International (America) Inc., said he believed the Fed would have to undertake another such intervention soon, most likely "just ahead of Labor Day," which is on Sept. 2.
Although market sentiment was mostly positive, some analysts dropped a word of caution, saying a possible rise in consumer spending in August could revive some inflationary fears.
"I think the market will be fine over the very near term because the news will be consistent with what the market thinks about the economy," said William Dudley, senior economist at Goldman, Sachs & Company. "The risk is later on when the August data start to show that the consumer is coming back."
Mr. Dudley said he expected gross domestic product to rise at a 3 percent annual pace in the third quarter and 3.5 percent in the last three months of the year. The economy grew at a 4.2 percent pace in the second quarter.
In the corporate market, prices rose in lock step with Treasuries across all sectors, traders said.
High-yield bond activity yesterday was topped by $200 million of 10-year senior notes offered by the Stone Container Finance Company of Canada in a private placement led by Salomon Brothers Inc.
The notes, rated B1 by Moody's Investors Service and B+ by Standard & Poor's, were priced at par to yield 11.50 percent.
In another private placement, Mariner Energy Inc. sold $100 million of 10-year senior subordinated notes to yield 10.58 percent via Morgan Stanley & Company.
The notes are rated B3 by Moody's and B- by Standard & Poor's.
A flood of new corporate issues is expected next week including a $1.5 billion, four-part offering from Aetna Services, a unit of Aetna Inc.
Aetna Services will be offering 5-year, 10- and 30-year notes along with a 40-year tranche with an 8-year put, traders said, adding that demand for the issue is strong. Merrill Lynch is the lead manager.
Also, the Sprint Spectrum L.P./Finance Corporation is expected to issue $650 million in a two-part offering, with Lehman Brothers as the lead manager.

HEADLINE: Domingo Cavallo's Achievement

 BODY:
Few people get the chance to play so constructive a role in their country's history as Domingo Cavallo, who resigned last month after five years as Argentina's Finance Minister. Applying his own powerful intellect and personality, and enjoying the unflinching political support of President Carlos Saul Menem, Mr. Cavallo guided an economy desperately sick with hyperinflation and corruption back to vitality and international respectability.
The benefits of Argentina's economic revival have been unequally distributed. Mr. Cavallo's ruthless war against inflation and his vigorous privatization campaign have brought high unemployment and painful reductions in social programs. But by most measures Argentina's overall economic performance and its future prospects now look better than at any time in the past 65 years. 
 Before Mr. Cavallo took office in 1991, the Government paid its bills by printing money, sending prices soaring. Mr. Cavallo stripped the Government of its unfettered right to print money, creating a "currency board" that tied the value of the peso to the United States dollar. He pledged that additional pesos would not be created unless Argentina, through trade and investment, accumulated sufficient dollar reserves to back new currency. That way foreigners would be assured that they could redeem pesos for dollars at full value.
Inflation fell to near zero and the economy prospered, growing more than 7 percent a year. Mr. Cavallo then sold large blocks of the economy to private investors, who managed to boost output even as they laid off employees from bloated Government enterprises. If the economy continues to prosper, the laid-off workers will soon find new jobs.
Mr. Cavallo's success helped Mr. Menem win re-election in 1995. But last month, after union protests against increased unemployment, Mr. Menem decided that the Finance Minister's political usefulness had come to an end.
By replacing Mr. Cavallo with Roque Fernandez, the University of Chicago-trained president of the central bank, Mr. Menem signaled that he remains committed to anti-inflation policies. But Mr. Fernandez lacks Mr. Cavallo's independent authority to confront corrupt bureaucrats and unions, many of whom wield influence in the ruling Peronist Party. If Mr. Menem wants credit for Mr. Cavallo's impressive achievement, he must take on that politically hazardous assignment himself.

HEADLINE: Mr. Kemp's Return

 BODY:
He could not get Colin Powell, and he apparently felt that neither the new-generation Midwestern Governors like John Engler nor the low-recognition Senators like Connie Mack and John McCain could help him close President Clinton's 20-point lead. So after a last-minute courtship, Bob Dole is said to have settled on Jack Kemp as his running mate. Given the relative obscurity of those who were still on the leader board as of mid-week, it was not a dumb choice.
Mr. Kemp does not have Mr. Powell's national allure, but his careers as a football star, Congressman and Cabinet member have made him highly visible. He is a strong campaigner who looks younger than his 61 years, he actually believes in Mr. Dole's newfound economic views, and he is just enough of an original thinker to give the Democrats something to worry about. His independent turn of mind may also cause Mr. Dole anxious moments. 
 
 His selection can only reinforce the widening gulf between the G.O.P.'s economic strategy and Bill Clinton's. Mr. Kemp, an original supply-sider, has long argued that massive tax cuts promote economic growth and social regeneration. He endorsed Steve Forbes in the primaries because he liked Mr. Forbes's flat tax more than he liked Mr. Dole's preoccupation with deficit reduction. Mr. Dole has now publicly embraced Reaganomics, but he has not revealed what he thinks of Mr. Kemp's long-winded sermons for the gold standard.
Mr. Kemp is also against abortion, which should please the Christian right but will do little to win back the legions of pro-choice women in the G.O.P. On other issues he has infuriated many of his Republican colleagues. In 1994, for example, he opposed Proposition 187, a California ballot initiative that denied public services like health care to illegal immigrants. His generally tolerant views on immigration have greatly annoyed the G.O.P.'s Buchanan wing, and Pat Buchanan's combative sister, Bay, said yesterday that Mr. Kemp would not have been her first choice.
Mr. Kemp also believes in affirmative action and criticizes those who would make it an issue. When he removed himself from the Presidential running last year, he warned his party that it would find it "very hard to govern if it runs a campaign that separates people by race and gender."
In truth, Mr. Kemp has been one of the G.O.P.'s more thoughtful politicians on issues involving the cities and the underclass -- albeit with a Kemp-like spin. Under the banner of "empowerment," he has encouraged "enterprise zones" in poor neighborhoods and promoted market-driven strategies to help the poor buy their own homes and choose their own schools. Those may not be the right answers, but at least Mr. Kemp has thought about the problem. One of his regrets about his tenure as Housing Secretary was that he could not get George Bush's White House to focus on inner-city poverty.
Bob Dole, once a deficit hawk, and Jack Kemp, a tax cutter, have had their difficulties over the years. Mr. Dole has obviously chosen to set past differences aside to strengthen his ticket with someone who himself might have been a plausible Presidential candidate.
