SECTION: Section 3; Page 1; Column 1; Money and Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 2060 words

HEADLINE: SPENDING IT;
The Hit Quiz Show For Those Who Owe

BYLINE: By DAVID J. MORROW 

DATELINE: HOLLYWOOD

 BODY:
BONITA MILLER came to repay a $7,680 car loan. Tracy King had hopes of erasing $23,000 in student loans and a $200 phone bill. Tom Hertz wanted to pay off $8,234 in credit card bills for living expenses, including a cross-country move, some new clothes and two TV's.
Only one of them would succeed, though, on the set of "Debt" -- Lifetime Television's new game show -- where financial miracles seldom take more than an hour. By answering a few trivia questions correctly, the winning contestant -- instead of flying to a beach in Tahiti -- can walk away free and clear of debt. 
 Jeff Nimoy, a 30-year-old actor, is typical of the winners. His take? $16,224. "I spent 12 years racking up that amount of debt," Mr. Nimoy said. "I got rid of it in a half hour."
Dispensing with years of bills in such short order is many an American's fantasy. And it has helped make "Debt," which made its debut in June, one of the most popular shows on Lifetime, a cable channel known mostly for its movies. The show may make a leap from its cult-like following, now about 750,000 households each weeknight, to a much broader audience. ABC -- looking to cash in on a possible hit -- has an option to move "Debt" into its prime-time lineup as early as next year. With the backing of the network, the stakes could be even higher for contestants, who might be able to pay off not just credit cards and such, but perhaps their mortgages, too.
America's cadre of spenders provide a steady stream of eager contestants as is. The number of applications has swelled from about 25 a week in June to about 250. At a recent taping, many were recent college graduates trying to pay off school loans or credit card bills from living beyond their means.
Much of the show's strength comes not from its competitive edge (questions ring more of People magazine than of "Jeopardy"), but from its philosophy. Some of the most popular game shows of the 1950's or 60's -- like "Let's Make a Deal" and "The Price Is Right" -- awarded prizes so that the contestants would go home feeling prosperous. Most families would have spent months saving to buy that washer or to take that European vacation. The creators of the new show make that format sound quaint.
"When we were looking at a game show to develop, we figured that by the way Americans were spending money, most of them had already bought their prizes," said Andrew Golder, 35, the senior producer of "Debt" and one of its creators. "What most people needed instead," he said, "was a way to pay all those bills."
The numbers buttress his point. Having spent freely during the recent economic expansion, Americans now owe a record $1.1 trillion in debt other than home loans. Even accounting for population growth, nonmortgage debt has nearly doubled the last 10 years to about $12,000 a household. The load has clearly become taxing. The portion of people who have fallen behind on their credit card bills is at its highest level in 15 years.
Once something that people might be ashamed of, mounds of credit card bills now prompt easy television confessionals. To be uninhibited in the 1960's meant a visit to the "Newlywed Game" or the "Dating Game," which routinely quizzed contestants on their sex lives. "Debt" takes voyeurism out of the bedroom and puts it in the living room, requiring contestants to divulge how they dug themselves into the hole.
Student loans are the No. 1 complaint, the show's producers say. Credit card spending is another common culprit. Susan Brightbill, an aspiring Hollywood actress and a recent contestant, says her last computer purchase took her credit card balance to $7,900. Aran Eisenstat, an earnest-looking lad from Los Angeles, says he racked up $18,000 on credit cards but is at a loss to say where the money really went, though he mentioned groceries, gasoline and car repairs.
"People like to hear other people talk about money the same way they like to hear them talk about sex," said Dr. David W. Krueger, a Houston psychoanalyst. "Either they get a feeling of connection -- 'Good. Someone else has a lot of debt, too' -- or they feel superior. Either way, it's a good feeling for the viewer."
"Debt" hinges on the notion that financial blunders are commonplace. The show's 150 audience members -- older adults one day, a crew of Marines the next -- seem to empathize with the three contestants, each out to purge financial sins.
The contestants begin each game with a negative total that reflects their combined average debt -- the limit is $10,000 each. With a correct answer, they pare that debt on the way to zero. For the first two rounds, they answer questions on pop culture. Whoever whittles away the most debt progresses to a speed round of questions. No matter how much money has been won at this point, if the final contestant answers 10 questions correctly in this round, he gets a check equivalent to his personal debt (again, up to $10,000).
Then comes the final temptation. The host, Wink Martindale, a veteran of the game-show circuit, asks the winner if he would like to wager all his money. If the contestant bites, he will either double his money or go home empty-handed. The potential pot: $20,000 (before taxes, of course, so there might be little left for fun after the bills are paid and the Government takes its share).
The producers of "Debt" hope that even the financially prudent will get a chuckle from the show. Unlike "Jeopardy" -- which is geared toward armchair highbrows -- "Debt" appeals to hip, young Americans.
Gregg Sherman, the show's 33-year-old head writer, said: "To do well here someone has to be a pop-culture junkie. In a way, you could say 'Debt' is one of the first shows geared toward Generation X, since they know a lot of what's going on in film and music."
The early reaction to the show has been encouraging for Lifetime, a division of Buena Vista Television, a development company for its parent, the Walt Disney Company. "Debt" has corralled a prime spending audience of 20- to 49-year-olds, and with them, advertisers as disparate as MCI, J. C. Penney and Pennzoil.
"While we'll have to wait and see if 'Debt' moves to prime time, it's much more likely that it can be sold into syndication," said Mort Marcus, president of Buena Vista. "We've just now begun to sell the international rights to the show."
Buena Vista would not say whether the show was a money maker, but if "Debt" moves into syndication, it will be sold for a profit to local television stations nationwide. If ABC, also owned by Disney, picks up the show, the network's prime-time audience will generate even heftier advertising revenue.
When the show was first broadcast, potential contestants simply phoned in their names and phone numbers. Now they fill out formal applications, and the wait is anything from several weeks to a year.
The first hurdle is perhaps the highest. The show's producers seem to favor people in their 20's, 30's and 40's, and those with a good tale of how they got into debt.
Joseph Kuhr, a 30-year-old Los Angeles screen writer, landed a spot on "Debt" last month after the recent decline in technology stocks depleted his portfolio by $12,000. (He won $7,100.) Kameron White-Holmes, a Pasadena, Calif., homemaker, appeared on the show when she was five months' pregnant and carrying $20,000 on her credit cards. (She lost.) But the most interesting contestant so far has to be Rob Steinberg, 36, who wanted to pay off $8,893 in travel expenses from attending a year-long tour of Grateful Dead concerts. (He took home $17,786.)

EOPLE who pass the application process take a written test. Each person has 15 minutes to whip through 36 questions about pop culture, covering trivia from foreign films to Cher's songs. Most questions are fairly straightforward. "I was high on the water tower in 'What's Eating Gilbert Grape' and just plain high in 'The Basketball Diaries.' " Who am I? The answer: Leonardo Di Caprio. Prospects who get at least 31 of the 36 questions right are grouped in threes for a mock show, in which producers look for excitement and quick reflexes.
Some television critics have ravaged "Debt," saying it makes its questions too easy.
"I've been doing game shows for years," said Mr. Martindale, the host, "and this is the first one that has so many young people on it. And most know their trivia. Sometimes I won't know anything, but we'll get some kid who'll rip through the questions like Grant through Richmond."
While most contestants know their trivia, don't expect them to know the interest rates on their credit cards or their monthly account balances, if a recent sampling of contestants is any indication.
What many of these contestants did say, however, was that their financial troubles were not their fault. The debt is just the price of their life style, which by their definition is Spartan.
Take Mr. Hertz, a handsome 34-year-old stand-up comic who faults his wife, Susan, for much of his $8,234 debt. She buys too much "girl stuff," he tells the television audience. The truth is that Mr. Hertz likes his share of "stuff," including brews with the boys and dinners on the town, as he reveals after the show.
 "It's one thing to make a nice salary," Mr. Hertz said later, "but even then, why shouldn't my wife and I go out to dinner? You have to buy that new computer for your recipes. Put them in a wooden box, and you'd be run out of the neighborhood. Of course, you have to run up debt on your credit card. Life's expensive."
Winning clearly means more to some contestants than to others. Shortly after buying a car a year ago, Ms. Miller lost her job as a communications executive and has struggled ever since to repay the $7,680 loan. During the first game of a recent day's taping, she was matched against Mr. Hertz, a trivia wizard..
Before the show begins, both get a touch of Hollywood humiliation. Ms. Miller has forgotten to wear a dress with pockets and is forced to wear a microphone pack in her underwear. At 5 feet 9 inches, Mr. Hertz is deemed too short by a stage manager, who asks him to stand on a small wooden box.
They sweep through the first round, knocking off a third contestant, and square off in the second. There, they "one up" each other on how many questions they can answer on oblique topics like "They Call Me Tom," for famous Toms, or "North, South, East or West," pop-culture questions that have directions in their answers. Mr. Hertz wins and moves to the speed round -- questions about foreign films.
Ms. Miller gets the hook. "Well, Bonita, we're not going to pay your debt," intones an announcer, "but we will give you a plastic piggy bank and a $500 savings bond." Like other losers, she is escorted to the front row of the studio audience for the remainder of the show.
Off the wooden box, Mr. Hertz rips through the speed round on foreign films. For answering the questions correctly, he is awarded enough money to wipe out his entire debt, $8,234. Finally, Mr. Martindale asks him if he would like to bet his winnings and possibly double his take. Mr. Hertz refuses.
"I plan to pay off my credit card debt -- honest I do," he said after the taping. "But you know it's hard to get excited about it. Bonita needed the money more than I did."
As in life, few of the show's contestants ultimately polish off their debts. Out of work for a year, Ms. Miller says she has now decided to accept a job that pays $10,000 less than her old one.
"It comes down to how life is today," she said. "Downsizings happen all the time. You just hope they don't happen to you. In that circumstance, you may need those credit cards just to survive."
Ms. King, who got nowhere on the show and is still weighed down by $23,000 in student loans, has taken a job as an English teacher at a junior high school. She acknowledged that it would take her many years to make even a dent in the load.
Some losing contestants plan to try out for other game shows. Others seem content to make monthly payments, while still others aren't overly concerned about their financial craters.
Mr. Eisenstat, who owes $18,000 on several credit cards, said: "You can't let your debts take the joy out of your life. Right now I'm not willing to not enjoy myself to pay off debt. What good is being debt free, if you're not living your life to the fullest?"

HEADLINE: When Welfare Cases Land on State Playing Fields

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The inaccurate assumptions and misguided conclusions that form the basis of the applause from Mayor Steve Goldsmith of Indianapolis for the dismantling of the Federal welfare system (Op-Ed, Aug. 4) provide a frightening glimpse of the future facing low-income families who must now rely on the states' administration of programs that will replace Aid to Families With Dependent Children. 
 In arguing that Indiana's current system undermines family cohesiveness, Mr. Goldsmith wrongly claims that Indiana residents cannot receive A.F.D.C. unless they are unmarried and/or in a different home from their extended family. In fact, both married parents and young parents living with their own families can receive benefits to help support their children. And contrary to Mr. Goldsmith's assertion, Indiana mothers receiving welfare benefits can receive a portion of the child support collected from their children's fathers.
In arguing that private charities can now replace a so-called government monopoly on the business of helping people, Mr. Goldsmith ignores the fact that the charities now doing the most for people in his community, including Catholic Charities U.S.A. and the Salvation Army, have begged Congress and the President not to abandon the 60-year Federal safety net and have insisted that they and other private charities will be unable to mend the holes in that safety net once it is shredded.
Mr. Goldsmith's conclusion that greater "flexibility" and local autonomy will allow cities and other local government bodies to be more effective at reducing poverty is belied by the fact that his main prescriptions for reducing the welfare rolls do not address the ills of his own community's low-income population. For example, he places great emphasis on finding people jobs, but Indianapolis boasts of an economy where low-wage jobs often go wanting.
It appears that while recent legislation may have finally concluded the treatment of low-income families as political footballs at the national level, those families have been punted to the electoral playing fields of the 50 states.
 
FRAN QUIGLEY
Indianapolis, Aug. 4, 1996
 
The writer is a professor of law at Indiana University.

LENGTH: 964 words

HEADLINE: DIARY

BYLINE: By DAVID RAMPE 

 BODY:

DEJA VU VOODOO
Bob Dole, Tax Busting
Mr. Dole, sailing to the Republican nomination in San Diego but sinking in the polls, reached for the magic vitamin that has revived many a Republican campaign: tax cuts. And not a dinky one at that. He pledged to cut income taxes by 15 percent and to spur economic growth to 3.5 percent. Naturally, this is all part of a plan to balance the budget. The old Bob Dole ridiculed tax cuts without spending cuts -- what he called "gain without pain" -- but now that he is a self-declared optimist, he plans to lop off all sorts of unspecified programs to "roll back the empire of liberal, big spending" government. For spice, he also compared the I.R.S. to the K.G.B.
 
BEYOND NO-FAULT
Cutting Car Insurance
While he's harpooning political points, the Republican candidate is also espousing a big change in auto insurance. The savings could be so immense to drivers -- upwards of $40 billion a year -- that the issue could well have legs politically. Trial lawyers are against it, so many politicians, especially Republicans, would see that as a plus. The plan would give drivers the option of buying no-frills coverage, omitting insurance for pain and suffering. That could save individuals hundreds of dollars a year in premiums.
 
FAMILY FORTUNES
A Micro Tax
Why wait for Washington to cut taxes when you can as good as abolish them now? J. R. Simplot, the potato magnate behind the volatile chip maker Micron Technologies, found a way for his family company to sell a lot of Micron stock without paying $39 million in capital gains taxes for six years. Tax avoidance of this sort is legal, but a source of consternation to the Clinton Administration. The maneuver also allows the family company to retain voting rights on most of the shares sold. Mr. Simplot, who is 87, long boasted that he had been a buyer of Micron, but never a seller, but since last fall the stock has tumbled, and he evidently decided to pull back. After the sale of 6 percent of Micron, the family apparently still owns 15 percent, worth $800 million.
 
THE OPEN MARKET
Nasdaq Under Duress
Nasdaq brokers fixed prices for years, the S.E.C. charged, and all the while the problem was ignored by the exchange's oversight body. The Securities and Exchange Commission censured the stock market and the self-regulatory National Association of Securities Dealers, and one commissioner said the anticompetitive practices might have resulted in tens of millions of dollars of overcharges. Nasdaq is the second-largest exchange in the world in the dollar value of stocks traded, after the New York Stock Exchange, and has climbed to prominence with a roster of leading technology companies like Intel and Microsoft. The Government did not charge any individual brokerage firms criminally, at least yet, but required the N.A.S.D. to spend $100 million to improve monitoring to prevent abuses. The exchange, which essentially is a computer system that links brokers who then trade by phone, accepted the censure without admitting or denying the charges. But many Nasdaq traders are outraged by rules the S.E.C. is proposing to guarantee that investors get the best possible price in trading, saying they would devastate brokerage profits.
 
LOGGING OFF
A Day Off in Cyberspace
The lights went out at America Online, leaving its six million customers out of commission for most of a day. In the process, small-business and home-office workers discovered just how much they depend on E-mail, and some were irate. "This is a great way to burn customer loyalty," said Gary Arlen, the head of a market research firm. But crashes have long been part of the on-line world, and others approached the disruption more calmly. David Gardner, who with his brother founded the personal financial site Motley Fool on America Online, said: "I've come to accept that from time to time computers break down. But if it goes on more than a day, I'll be very upset." Steve Case, the company's chairman, issued a mea culpa to customers but also saw a silver lining. A decade ago, on-line services were the turf of computer hobbyists. Now they are so much a part of everyday life that a day without A.O.L. "is disorienting and downright frustrating."
 
MERGER MANIA, CONTINUED
Buying Spree, Episode 238
A slow week on the merger front, just $5 billion or so. In the managed care department, Pacificare of Orange County agreed to buy the neighboring FHP International. The price is $2.1 billion. GE Capital is getting the First Colony life insurer, at $1.8 billion. And the fertilizer company Freeport-McMoran is taking over Arcadian, for $1 billion or so in stock.
 
SEMICONDUCTOR SAGA
Trade Skirmishes Morph
True, Washington and Tokyo concluded another chip deal, but it didn't seem to mean nearly as much as the original one, 10 years ago. "We're fighting the last trade war," said one American semiconductor executive, who added that today, Japan is a relatively open market, while China, a newcomer to the industry, is a graver problem.
 
MARKET INDICATORS
Investors Ante Up Less
Investors gulped during July, adding a measly $3.5 billion to stock mutual funds. That was by far the least of any month of the last year and could mark an ominous turn for the market. For the week, the Dow Jones average ended up 1.48 points, at 5,681.31. In his job for one month, the head of Fidelity's Magellan fund surprised Wall Street by sticking with the investments he inherited when he took over the giant fund. Robert E. Stansky kept the mountain of government bonds that dragged down the performance of his predecessor, Jeffrey N. Vinik. Mr. Stansky chose to keep his head down, in Fidelity's words, "pending full review of various opportunities."

HEADLINE: MARKET TIMING

 BODY:

Monday
 
The Conference Board is to report the leading indicators for June, and an increase of two-tenths of one percentage point is expected. An increase would be the fifth in a row, a streak that has not occurred in two years. The index rose three-tenths of a point in May.
 
Tuesday
 
The American Petroleum Institute issues its weekly report on petroleum stocks, production and imports.
 
Wednesday
 
The Federal Reserve issues its so-called beige book, which details business conditions in each of its 12 districts. It will help prepare the Fed for its policy-making meeting on Aug. 20.
 
The Fed is also expected to report consumer installment debt for June; an increase of $7.5 billion is predicted, a jump from May's $4.7 billion.
 
Thursday
 
Earnings reports are expected from America Online, Clorox and Procter & Gamble.
 
Friday
 
Producer prices are due out for July, and the Labor Department is likely to report an increase in prices for finished goods of two-tenths of a point. The core index, stripping out energy and food, is likely to be up by the same amount, forecasters say. The rise would mirror June's increase.

HEADLINE: When Parties Go to Extremes;
It's Hard Running Up the Middle

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
ONE of the abiding rules of Presidential politics is this: Crawl too far out on a limb, to the left or to the right, and you will fall off. "Extremism in the pursuit of liberty" or any other virtue, to borrow Barry Goldwater's phrase, may be no vice -- but it costs elections. Few tags will doom a Presidential campaign as quickly as "extremist."
Recent history is full of examples. Mr. Goldwater himself is the most vivid one; nominated in 1964 as the darling of the resurgent conservatives, at a convention where Nelson Rockefeller was booed and other Republican moderates were either scorned or ignored, he carried only six states as Lyndon B. Johnson took 61 percent of the popular vote, the largest share in American history. 
 Mr. Goldwater had demonstrated his command over the ideologically committed activists who vote in primaries and attend party meetings only to discover that the general electorate is an entirely different political animal.
Eight years later, the same fate befell George McGovern, a man, like Goldwater, restrained in personal demeanor but far from restrained on the key issues. Opponents of the Vietnam war captured the Democratic convention and mounted a campaign full of left-wing zeal, but Richard M. Nixon took 49 states (all but Massachusetts), the largest number ever captured by a Presidential nominee.
Now nobody has ever accused Bob Dole of being an extremist; he is in fact a classic Plains conservative, suspicious of isms and movements, given to compromise and tolerant of the other guy in the way legislative leaders tend to be. His choice of Jack Kemp as his running mate Friday was classic Dole. He chose a man with whom his personal and professional relations have been rocky in an effort to demonstrate his willingness to embrace the pro-growth wing of the party.
But it is not only the man who matters; it is also the kind of message that he sends or that is sent on his behalf, and that is a danger that faces Mr. Dole on the eve of his nomination this week in San Diego. Such was the case with George Bush in 1992; no firebrand himself, indeed diffident to the point that he sometimes seemed offended by the crudities of political life, he was nominated by a convention that sent signals of exclusion, especially on abortion and especially to women.
Two-party politics, almost by definition, is the politics of inclusion, and Mr. Bush paid a price for his party's exclusionism, running far behind the Republican norm in affluent suburbs and among women generally. That helped Bill Clinton beat him.
Once in the White House, Mr. Clinton forgot for a time that he had won (albeit only by a plurality) as a New Democrat, the self-anointed champion of the middle class, less obligated than most of his recent Democratic predecessors to labor unions, minorities and other interest groups. On such issues as gays in the military and health-care reform, he got out ahead of the public, lost the support of those in the vital center and suffered in the polls. The 1994 Republican "revolution" followed.

 
 
Malleable
 Now he has morphed back into his 1992 self -- and then some, adopting as his own such hoary Republican themes as lower taxes and smaller government. He has not really reformed welfare but abandoned it in favor of a risky experiment.
Likewise Mr. Dole. He has shown himself no less malleable than his opponent, promising voters early in the campaign year, "I'll be another Reagan if you want." This some seem to want, so he has transformed himself, for the moment at least, from deficit hawk into tax-cutter, jettisoning a lifetime of preoccupation with balancing the government's books (and an abiding skepticism of Ronald Reagan's economic policies). The choice of Mr. Kemp, a supply-side tax-cutter from way back, gives him a bit more credibility in his new role.
Washington is anathema to voters these days, so Mr. Dole sought early on to symbolically shed decades of personal history by resigning from the Senate to campaign as a plain Joe from Kansas.
Mr. Dole has done what he could to see to it that this year's Republican convention avoids the pitfalls of the 1992 gathering in Houston. Before settling on Mr. Kemp, he sought in vain to persuade General Colin Powell, perhaps the best man to guarantee the ticket an image of good sense and balance, to become his running mate.
He also sought language in the platform that would explicitly express the party's tolerance of those in its ranks who back abortion rights (for "tolerance" read "inclusion" or "non-extremism"). But the opponents of abortion, especially Pat Robertson's Christian Coalition, had done their work well, electing delegates in state after state who were determined not to yield on what they deem to be a profound moral issue.
The best the former Senator could manage on that score was a tolerant appendix, which will no doubt be even less read or heeded than the platform it accompanies. It was apparently enough to avoid a floor fight led by the Rockefellers of 1996, like Governors William Weld of Massachusetts and Christine Todd Whitman of New Jersey. But the platform as a whole constitutes a statement of party principles closer in its music, if not always in its words, to the unbridled nationalism and populism of Patrick J. Buchanan than to Mr. Dole's careful formulations.
"We could not be more pleased," said Angela (Bay) Buchanan, Mr. Buchanan's sister, with a document that will include many of the themes from the Buchanan campaign: opposition to American troops serving under foreign commanders in United Nations peacekeeping forces, opposition to same-sex marriages, opposition to public assistance for children born to illegal aliens while in the United States.
It is uncertain how the platform and the convention speeches about it will play with the voters; a prominent moderate Republican in Pennsylvania said last week that voters in suburban Philadelphia, one of the pivotal areas where the hot Houston rhetoric hurt Mr. Bush in 1992, would be listening to every word.
If they are offended once more, if they sense that the Republican Party has been radicalized like the Democratic Party of the 1970's, Mr. Clinton will be waiting to greet them with open arms. His own convention later this month will be scripted to send nothing but signals of harmony and moderation, in sharp contrast to the scenes of combat, both physical and metaphysical, that emanated from Chicago in 1968.
Ross Perot will be waiting, too, as the presumptive nominee of his Reform Party at its curiously bifurcated convention, beginning in Long Beach, Calif., before the Republican gathering down the coast and ending after it in Valley Forge, Pa. Third parties in America have traditionally been havens for those who found the major parties too moderate, not too extreme, but Mr. Perot likes to think he is in sync with the Jaundiced Majority that considers all mainstream politics a joke, particularly a mainstream politics whose leading lights so readily jettison principles to woo voters. But in the end the joke may be on Mr. Perot, too, since he has his own problems with political constancy.

 
 
The Hard Line's Victories
 The most pressing problem for Mr. Dole, as he himself has no doubt concluded, is the hard-line conservatives within his party, who have also triumphed in a number of important primaries in recent months. In Kansas, Representative Sam Brownback, one of Newt Gingrich's foot soldiers, defeated the establishment Senator appointed in Mr. Dole's place, Sheila Frahm, and other outspoken foes of abortion won in such diverse states as Georgia, Michigan and Illinois. They are all expected to face trouble in November, local politicians say, in appealing to moderates of both parties.
So may Mr. Dole. For two decades, from 1968, when Richard Nixon discovered how to appeal to what he called the Silent Majority, through 1988, it was the Republicans who seemed like the natural party of government, in tune with the national Zeitgeist, and the Democrats who seemed the party of cranks and have-nots. Those roles may now be reversing, with profound political consequences.

HEADLINE: Ideas & Trends;
For Your F.B.I. File, Take a Number (15,001)

BYLINE: By DAVID WALLIS; David Wallis is a writer in New York.

 BODY:
NEXT time the Clinton Administration trumpets declining unemployment figures, they may owe some thanks to Craig Livingstone.
Mr. Livingstone, the former White House director of personnel security, resigned under pressure in June after improperly acquiring confidential Federal Bureau of Investigation files on nearly 900 people, including many prominent Republicans. While Mr. Livingstone's departure reduced the nation's labor force by one, his legacy may be the creation of 350 jobs at the F.B.I. 
 Since news broke of the file fiasco, the F.B.I. has been swamped with requests from citizens asking to review their own files under the Freedom of Information and Privacy Acts, the laws establishing the statutory rights to obtain Government documents. In response the Senate committee responsible for funding the bureau voted unanimously this month to beef up the F.B.I. department that processes those requests.
There are 9.6 million F.B.I. files on individuals, alive and dead, plus organizations and criminal investigations. If the empty 9-by-11 1/2-inch white folders were empty and stacked one on top of another, the paper tower would rise about 20 miles into the sky. But the files are not empty. They are full of "raw" information -- uncorroborated rumors often spread by anonymous sources, including paid informants, about marital infidelities, sexual orientation, drug use, political leanings and mental stability. Imagine a federally financed version of the National Enquirer with J. Edgar Hoover as its editor-in-chief.
Investigative files existed before Hoover joined the Bureau in 1917, but they multiplied exponentially during his reign as director from 1924 until his death in 1972. He maintained dossiers on Government officials, artists, writers, activists and celebrities ranging from Edward R. Murrow to Liberace. And he would often share morsels of gossip with the White House to titillate, and sometimes threaten, the presidents he served. During the Hoover years, publicly criticizing the F.B.I. or signing a petition protesting the Vietnam War was enough to spur an F.B.I. surveillance. No more.

 
 
Mastercard Knows More
 "Two types of files now exist," explained James M. Fox, former chief of the F.B.I.'s New York office. 'The first type is for people who have committed crimes or been the subject of a criminal investigation. The second is for someone nominated for a high position that requires a background check."
"You just can't collect stuff like you used to," Mr. Fox said. "In some cases the F.B.I. can collect far less information than your local credit bureau."
Most Americans don't have a file, Mr. Fox said. But those who do can expect to wait between two and four years to get the scuttlebutt. "Don't expect to get a quick answer to your request, when you've got 15,000 people in line ahead of you," said F.B.I. spokesman Bill Carter.
Why the wait? Several exemptions to the Freedom of Information Act enable agencies to censor information. In recent testimony before the House, J. Kevin O'Brien, chief of the F.B.I.'s Freedom of Information and Privacy Acts Section, blamed much of the backlog on the considerable time and resources the F.B.I spends to decide what information can be released "without harming national security, revealing confidential sources, invading personal privacy, interfering with ongoing investigations, disclosing specialized investigative techniques or revealing other sensitive information."
Critics contend that the F.B.I.'s laborious "line by line" editing erodes the Freedom of Information Act's effectiveness. "It's basically been a downhill run for the act since it was signed into law," lamented Ramsey Clark, who helped write the law when he was Attorney General under Lyndon B. Johnson."The exemptions carved into the act are overwhelmingly unwarranted."
Carl Stern, chief spokesman for the Justice Department, faults overzealous requesters. "Better than 95 percent of requests the Justice Department gets are these 'give me all you got' requests." He recalls one that included a list of questions that ran 11 typed pages, single spaced. "It would take a number of F.B.I. employees a number of years just to process that one request," he said.
Jack Greenberg, the former director of the N.A.A.C.P. Legal Defense Fund, is intimately familiar with the F.B.I.'s Orwellian interpretation of the laws. In 1991 he received a predominantly censored file. He appealed to the bureau to reverse its decision, only to be informed that the Privacy Act also protected the confidential sources that supplied the skinny on Mr. Greenberg. So, Mr. Greenberg sued the F.B.I. in 1993. The District Court for the District of Columbia ruled in Mr. Greenberg's favor, awarding him plenty of reading material as well as $18,000 in legal fees.
The full file included an assessment of Mr. Greenberg as "not subversive," transcripts of wiretapped telephone conversations between him and the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. and a report saying he was the target of two assassination plots. "I knew about one assassination attempt, but the F.B.I. never told me of the other," said Mr. Greenberg. He still cannot fathom the bureau's stubbornness in releasing it.

 
 
High Stakes
 The Freedom of Information Act has few friends at the F.B.I. Mr. Fox recalls "going through pages and pages and pages of stuff deciding what could be excluded and what had to be released." He added, "I did not join the F.B.I. to do this. I joined the F.B.I. to catch bad guys."
The agency is trying to streamline its operations. Previously, it processed requests on a first-come-first-serve basis, but now, requests of under 100 pages are put in a separate queue. And the White House and Congress are pitching in too. To reduce file-glut, the White House requested an additional $3.3 million to hire 129 more analysts, a figure that's likely to be approved by the full Senate in September. The House offered more, nearly $14 million, to hire 350 new F.B.I. employees. But its generosity comes with a condition: the people whose files were acquired by the White House get to leapfrog to the front of the line.
Harry Hammitt, publisher of Access Reports, a newsletter that tracks the implementation of the law, suggests that Livingstone's prey should not hold their breath. "To change the F.B.I. from a very closed agency to a very open one will take a considerable amount of time," he said. "They rejected releasing Jimmy Hoffa's file because they said it's a case still under investigation. I don't think the F.B.I. will ever change its spots."
For further information about obtaining an F.B.I. file, contact the F.B.I.'s Freedom of Information/Privacy Acts Section at (202) 324-3000. Or call the Freedom of Information Act Clearing House, a non-profit organization, at (202)588-1000.

HEADLINE: Poor Losers;
Class Warfare? The Rich Win by Default.

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
YOUR chance of running into a low-income delegate among the Republicans gathering in San Diego this week is 50 to 1, only a bit higher than the chances that the next time Congress considers legislation affecting poor people, it will hear much from any of them. The Democratic National Convention will offer better odds of finding a delegate with a family income under $25,000: they'll be just 14 to 1.
It was only 10 days ago that the Senate completed action on welfare legislation whose critics said would push at least a million children into poverty. The corridors outside the chamber, usually an obstacle course of lobbyists, were deserted. Senators and Representatives, who were deluged by lobbyists and constituents two years ago when health care was the issue, heard little from the roughly 13 million people on the rolls for Aid to Families with Dependent Children. 
 More important, they heard little from them, or from poor Americans in general, at the polls in 1994. Nor do they have reason to fear them on Election Day 1996. For voting among lower-income Americans has been declining while voting among those with higher incomes has been rising.
And those trends affect political agendas for an age-old reason: Politicians get re-elected by looking after the voters who elected them the time before. So as long as turnout among poor people declines while participation among the higher income groups increases, government is unlikely to focus on issues -- or solutions -- that appeal to low-income people.
Curtis Gans, head of the Committee for the Study of the American Electorate, argues that in 1990, 13.8 percent of the voters came from families with incomes under $15,000. In 1992, they declined to 11.0 percent. And in 1994 they were just 7.7 percent.
Why? "The basic cause is essentially that neither party is speaking to the interests of the lower-income brackets of Americans," he says. "The Democratic Party has become, in its message, studiously geared to the middle class and the Republican Party has never made any pretense of speaking to lower-income people."
It's not that the parties are altogether failing to discuss the plight of the poor. The Republican welfare bill, which President Clinton has said he will sign, is intended to encourage work and end dependency. And the Republican party platform pledges to help the poor with tax cuts and reduced regulations intended to spur economic growth.
But it's clear that the platform is aimed at middle and upper-middle class voters -- like those with $2,000 in extra cash to put in an Individual Retirement Account for a spouse without a paying job. With 2 percent of the delegates surveyed by The New York Times/CBS News Poll reporting family incomes of $25,000 or less, the average somewhere around $75,000 and 11 percent over $200,000, there is little in the economic section of the platform to bother the delegates themselves.
Even so, the Republicans say how they will help "the poor." The Democratic platform that was recommended Monday in Pittsburgh avoids the word desperately. It appears in a list of Republican sins, what it calls "their wrong-headed and mean-spirited efforts to punish the poor." The Democrats say good things about the Earned Income Tax Credit and raising the minimum wage, but they never whisper the word "poor" to identify the beneficiaries of those programs -- who at least have jobs.
That hesitancy, which was seen last year when some Democratic Senators were briefly reluctant to support such a bedrock party issue as raising the minimum wage, may contribute to the declining turnout -- which, in a vicious circle, may then contribute to more avoidance of those issues.

 
 
High Stakes
 The Rev. Jesse Jackson attributed the recent decline to a lack of "candidates who inspire hope." But he said that in about 50 House districts this fall, he planned to emphasize the importance of voting, and the hope of wresting Congress from the Republicans: "The stakes are very high, and much higher than the Presidential campaign."
Black leaders are not the only ones to worry about declining interest among poor voters. Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan of New York was eloquent last September, when the first version of the welfare bill was passed, asking the Senate: "Why do we not see the endless parade of petitioners, the lobbyists, the pretend citizen groups, the real citizen groups? None are here."
Last week, he said a major reason for the decline was an intellectual disdain many Democratic reformers of the 1970's held for "the political views of working class, low-income voters, which were at odds with the patrician left." That disdain, he said, led them to curb the role of low-income voters in party politics.
The welfare bill actually may not be a particularly salient example of the effect of lower voting rates among blacks. Douglas J. Besharov, a resident scholar at the American Enterprise Institute here, said that over 30 years, "attitudes toward welfare have almost inexorably led to a bill like this."
"If there had been a Democratic majority in the Congress, it would have been somewhat softer," he said. "But there still would have been time limits and mandatory work. Maybe the poor don't vote. Maybe that made it worse. But you have this underlying tide."
Another cautionary voice is that of Ruy A. Teixeira of the Economic Policy Institute. He said turnout differences had less to do with the political agenda than with hostility toward government among the rest of the electorate. "The poor," he said, "have always been at the mercy of the views and opinions of the middle-class voter."
Representative John Conyers of Michigan, the longest-serving black in Congress, said he was dismayed at a turnout of only 17 percent in Detroit in last week's primary, about two-thirds of the normal level.
"I'll tell you what surprised me," he said. "I have never heard any more complaints about the government's insensitivity to what people need in this country than there have been under the Gingrich leadership. Yet at the same time, instead of that translating into a remarkable turnout, an angry protest at the polls, it turns into a whimper."

HEADLINE: Russia Reopens Its Cosmopolitan Door to the Pacific

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE 

DATELINE: VLADIVOSTOK, Russia

 BODY:
One day this spring, Canadian Navy sailors climbed a hill overlooking the Pacific Ocean and put marble headstones over graves of American and Canadian soldiers who died here while fighting against the Bolsheviks in 1918. Down the hill, workmen are restoring the Beaux Arts terminal of the Trans-Siberian Railway. Nearby, work is to start on another turn-of-the-century tourist attraction -- a mansion that the Communists expropriated from the family of Yul Brynner, the actor.
As if awakening from a decades-old deep sleep, this Pacific port is slowly reassuming the character that once made it one of Russia's most cosmopolitan cities. A free port in Czarist days, Vladivostok virtually dropped off Westerners' maps after the Communists took control here in 1922. 
 In 1948, Stalin closed the American Consulate here and shut the entire city, where the Soviet fleet was based, to outsiders. When Vladivostok finally reopened in 1992, foreign euphoria easily matched local euphoria.
With a deep-water harbor and a rail link to Moscow, Vladivostok is a natural gateway to Russia's Far East, a region rich in mineral resources and timber. Already Vladivostok and its sister port, Nakhodka, handle a quarter of Russia's foreign trade.
But almost five years after the opening, Vladivostok's landscape, like much of Russia's, is littered with failed American enterprises. After $10 million in investments, a Giant supermarket complex stands like a 90,000-square-foot beached whale after the American backers pulled out in May.
American companies leaving this year include I.B.M., Deloitte & Touche, and an experienced guide to American investors, the Pacific Law Center.
"It's impossible to do business honestly in Russia because of the taxes," an American businessman said last week in the hushed privacy of Nostalgia, a restaurant with red velour walls hung with oil portraits of Czar Nicholas II.
In addition to taxes that eat up profits, bribes and bureaucracy have taken the bloom off the city's coming-out party.
"The fishing companies complain that the only way to get the quotas is to go to Moscow with suitcases full of money," said Deborah Turnbull, associate editor of Russian Far East Update, a based business monthly based in Seattle.
But for every step taken backward, this tough sailor's town seems to lurch forward two steps.
"There is so much potential here that the greatest Slavic control freak in the world can't keep his hands on it," said Vladimir Berzonsky Jr., an American lawyer of Russian origin who opened his law office here in October.
Indeed, despite setbacks, this city has not seen such a strong American presence since 1918, the year the Brooklyn dropped anchor here with the first doughboys of the American expeditionary forces.
A seven-story American Consulate has opened on Pushkin Street, where it enjoys a commanding view of the long-secret harbor. As trans-Pacific contacts mushroom, the consulate now stamps out visas at the rate of 10,000 a year.
In a city where local residents were taught only five years ago to denounce all foreigners to the K.G.B., there is now a biweekly English-language newspaper, Vladivostok News, and daily CNN programming on a local television channel. This fall, an American-style international school is to open here, the first since the 1920's.
Once a cold-war flash point where American spy planes were shot down while testing Soviet anti-aircraft defenses, military tensions are now at their lowest levels in memory.
In a sign of waning xenophobia, the first foreigner, Andrew M. Fox of Britain, was elected in April to the board of the private company that runs Vladivostok's port.
Western institutions are taking root again after a long absence. The Vladivostok Rotary Club now has so many members that it will spin off a new club next month. Swelling the membership are officers of Coca-Cola, which started bottling here in May.
Russian Orthodox churches have opened, although the cathedral was destroyed by Soviet troops in 1937. High on one of the roller-coaster hills, Roman Catholic Mass once again resonates within the red-brick walls of Most Holy Mother of God Church, a sanctuary that until three years ago was a state archive. Later this year, the army is to remove cannons and war exhibits from a military museum. This crumbling neo-Gothic building is to be restored to its original owner, the Lutheran Church.
But, on the business front, most foreign investors have looked Vladivostok's taxes and bureaucracy in the eye -- and have decided to wait.
"The problems we have here are the same to all of Russia," said Pavel Morozov, international director of Acfes, a Russian conglomerate based here. "The rules are always changing. You sit down to play poker -- and then discover that you are playing baccarat."
Shaun Going, a Canadian who was hired last fall to build housing here for American diplomats, is still waiting for permits while an entire construction season slips by.
Commuting between here and Albania, where he also builds houses, he said, "It's easier to do business in Albania."

SECTION: Section 1; Page 28; Column 1; National Desk 

LENGTH: 1803 words

HEADLINE: POLITICS: THE CITY;
Heady Times for 'New' San Diego

BYLINE: By B. DRUMMOND AYRES Jr. 

DATELINE: SAN DIEGO, Aug. 10

 BODY:
To most Americans, this city in the country's sunny southwestern corner is perhaps best known for its Navy base, its zoo, its 12-meter racing yachts and, icon of icons, that red-roofed wooden pile called the Hotel Del Coronado.
But that was the old San Diego. 
 The new San Diego, the oh-so-Republican city and surrounding county chosen as the site of the 1996 Republican National Convention, has all of those things -- and then some.
In recent years, particularly since Southern California was laid economically low by the national recession and the reductions of the armed forces and the aerospace industry, San Diego has begun to transform itself from a pleasant but somewhat bland town of sailors, tourists, retirees and military industrial workers into one of the nation's leading high-tech centers, a cyber comer on the Pacific Rim.
Within the metropolitan area -- San Diego County is home to 2.7 million people, with 1.8 million of them in the city, the nation's sixth-largest -- there are more than 350 software producers, more than 200 telecommunications companies and at least that many biotechnology and medical concerns.
These days, San Diegans like to brag that their city is the next Silicon Valley, an upscale, heavily suburban, families-not-glitz place of unfettered all-American inventiveness, ingenuity and capitalism.
What better setting for a gathering of the Grand Old Party?
"We've turned it around and we're off and running in a new direction," boasts Mayor Susan Golding, a Republican who, like most San Diego leaders, endlessly preaches slow, steady, clean urban growth -- lest blighted sprawl bedevil smokestackless San Diego as it bedevils Los Angeles, that glitzy Democratic behemoth up the coast that San Diegans so love to hate.
Thanks to the high-tech revolution, the San Diego unemployment rate, which jumped close to 10 percent in the depths of the recession, was down to 5.2 percent in June, the latest month for which complete figures are available. That was a notch better than the national average of 5.3 percent and almost a full two percentage points better than the overall California average of 7.1 percent.
Just in the past year, more than 20,000 new jobs have been created here -- 65,000 were lost in the recession -- and city statisticians say that now, for the first time in the better part of a decade, more people are moving in than out.
Most telling of all, here and there on sunny inland hilltops with views of the distant Mediterranean-like Pacific Coast, there can now be seen that rarest of post-recession California sights: construction of new houses, office parks and shopping malls.

Lingering Problems In the Comeback
On a discordant note, San Diego, even as it bounces back and moves into high tech, still faces some serious problems.
It badly needs a larger airport, more container-ship docks, improved rail connections, a better water supply and a safe place to store low-grade radioactive waste. There are too many high school dropouts and too few low-income housing units and too many underemployed people.
"Life can be so pleasant in San Diego that we sometimes tend to forget or gloss over that we're not in heaven, not yet," said Neil Morgan, who has been writing newspaper columns and books about San Diego and the West since migrating here 50 years ago from North Carolina. "There are still people hurting. There is still pressing work to do."
Most pressing, at least in the short term, is the problem of illegal immigration.
San Diego, whose environs stretch south to the Mexican border and teeming Tijuana, is struggling with the most serious increase of undocumented immigrants anywhere in the country, an illegal influx the Federal Government has thus far been unable to slow very much.
It is an increase that has weakened ties between many whites, who make up about two-thirds of the population, and the Hispanic residents, who account for nearly 25 percent.
It is also an increase that threatens to divide the city into haves and have-nots, and that is casting doubt on proud assertions at City Hall that San Diego will not only be the next Silicon Valley but will also be the "first great city of the 21st century."
Finally, it is an invasion that has soured some San Diegans on the need for stronger social and economic ties with its sibling Tijuana, though officials in both cities continue to press for more ties, particularly since the signing of the North American Free Trade Agreement.
A common nightly sight along the border is patrol agents in hot pursuit of ragged clutches of people desperately trying to sneak into the land of opportunity, hoping to find work, here and elsewhere, not as highly paid high-technology engineers and scientists but as faceless, undocumented day laborers, dishwashers, maids and gardeners.
Without knowing it, the Republican conventioneers will be mixing with some of these people as, festooned with elephant-shaped badges and funny red-white-and-blue hats, they partake of the tourist delights of San Diego's rejuvenated downtown business district, hard by a harbor with hulking gray warships and graceful white pleasure yachts.
Then, just before leaving town, the conventioneers will probably adopt a platform plank that reiterates their party's longstanding call for tougher controls on immigration.
"All this focus in recent years on immigration has caused serious deterioration in relations between our white and Latino communities," said Juan Vargas, the City Council member who represents the city's heavily Hispanic, heavily Democratic Eighth District. "There's more and more tension. It's true that San Diego is making a comeback. But my people are not getting their fair share. We still have a 40 percent high school dropout rate, and we still are a community of house renters, not buyers, and we're still underemployed and underpaid."

Booming Growth In High-Tech Jobs
Still, the biggest nonpolitical news as the Republicans gather here concerns not immigration but high technology.
San Diego continues to be heavily dependent on the Navy, tourism and a steady influx of well-to-do retirees to maintain its quiet (this is not Surf City), comfortable (average household income: $65,400), mainstream Republican (fiscally conservative, socially moderate) style in a climate that just might be the most consistently pleasant in the United States (sunny 70 percent of the time, with an average temperature of 62.3 degrees Fahrenheit).
But of late, in the aftermath of a great recession, San Diego is also a city where white-frocked bioscientists have settled and begun making big money by developing new drugs and health treatments, where electronic innovators are coming up with wizard ways to communicate and where flocks of computer experts are producing cutting-edge software that can compete with anything coming out of the Silicon Valley.
Just about all of California is now well along the road to economic recovery (with polls indicating that one of the biggest political beneficiaries is Bill Clinton, not Bob Dole). But the recovery here is striking.
"We're not yet growing like we were in the Roaring 80's, but when your unemployment rate is better than both the state and national averages, you've got something important to talk about," said Mike Madigan of Pardee Construction, one of the region's largest developers.
Many of the new high-tech companies employ fewer than 50 workers. The ambitious entrepreneurs who run them often labor side by side with recently hired workers.
Such business compactness is one of the universal hallmarks of California's comeback this time around. But the proliferation of small companies in the San Diego area is particularly notable, especially in the valleys lying east of the idyllic coastal cliffs neighborhood of La Jolla.
A few of the new concerns here have even managed to grow recently to 500 or more employees. Given the history of high-tech growth, they could have 5,000 or more employees in another year or so.
"There's just the right critical mass for tremendous high-tech growth in San Diego," said Jim Madsen, an engineer who in the depths of the recession helped establish Next Wave, a company that specializes in digital wireless communication and recently hired its 200th employee.
"The universities in the area and the defense and aerospace companies helped get things started by providing a lot of the initial research and development brain power and expertise," Mr. Madsen said. "Then individual scientists and engineers began to break off and start their own operations, particularly after defense and aerospace began to downsize. Then some of those operations began to spin off entrepreneurs.
"It just goes on and on. You throw in the great quality of life that we have down here, and what you have is another great American success story."

Contrasting Views Of City's Future
There are voices of caution.
Steve Erie, a political scientist on the San Diego campus of the University of California and a close student of Southern California, holds that the city will never be one of the great metropolises of the Pacific Rim unless it moves to improve its transportation system and services.
"There's a lot of boastful talk by the Mayor and others," he said, "but realistically, San Diego is going to march in place until it improves on such basics as the airport, rails, water, waste dumps. It can go high-tech -- and still not go anywhere."
The San Diego airport has one runway and cannot handle fully loaded jumbo jets. Few flights are nonstops, and many San Diego passengers use the Los Angeles airport, about 100 miles away.
Similarly, the city's commercial piers are so few and small that most sea shipments must pass through the Long Beach-Los Angeles port, hauled to and from San Diego by trucks fighting heavy freeway traffic or by trains on rail lines that are little better than a spur.
Much of San Diego's water comes from Los Angeles, though the city recently took action to lighten that dependence by negotiating to purchase some supplies from agriculture interests in the Imperial Valley. But that agreement may be challenged in court.
"We've got ourselves a city run by people afraid to rock the boat," Mr. Erie said. "They've been talking about a new airport and all these other things for years and years. This is a phantom city, not the 'first great city of the 21st century.' "
Mayor Golding is having none of that. "What the people who come to this convention will see," the Mayor said, "is a strong city, a city on the move. We have the basics, and we're going to grow even stronger. With our new high-tech underpinning and our increasingly important cross-border trade and our terrific location on the Pacific Rim, we're bound for greatness."

HEADLINE: Defying U.S., Turkey to Sign Gas Deal in Iran

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: TEHERAN, Iran, Aug. 10

 BODY:
Defying a new United States law that imposes sanctions on major investments in Libya and Iran, Prime Minister Necmettin Erbakan of Turkey arrived here today and said he hopes to sign a $20 billion natural gas agreement.
But Mr. Erbakan said his visit here, which is schedule to last three days, was not intended as a challenge to the United States, which accuses Iran and Libya of sponsoring international terrorism. 
 "Our visit has no aims against the United States, which is also our friend and ally," he said after arriving today at Teheran's airport, where he was greeted by an honor guard.
Mr. Erbakan, who leads Turkey's Islamic party, added that, "We shall open a new era in our relations with our Muslim brother, Iran."
When asked if he would sign the gas accord, Mr. Erbakan said, "I'm here to sign many agreements and improve ties." He is expected to meet several times with President Hashemi Rafsanjani.
The visit, Mr. Erbakan's first official trip abroad since taking office in June, has been viewed with a wary eye by officials in Washington, and the gas accord would be the first to fall under the new sanctions law.
The United States and the West have also expressed concerns over the rise of Mr. Erbakan's coalition in Turkey, the country's first Islamic-leaning Government since the state was founded after World War I. Turkey's own military, guardians of the country's secular tradition, has also viewed Mr. Erbakan with suspicion.
President Clinton signed the sanctions law on Monday. It would punishforeign companies making new investments of more than $40 million a year in the oil and gas sectors of Iran and Libya. The legislation has been widely criticized by the European Union and Russia, which have said they will not abide by it.
Since taking office, Mr. Erbakan has sought to expand ties with Muslim countries while trying not to alarm Turkey's Western allies.
Iran's clerical Muslim leaders, who disdain the separation of religion and politics, see Mr. Erbakan as one of their own. And Iran's state-controlled newspapers have portrayed the Turkish leader's visit as evidence of the failure of American efforts to isolate Iran.
Iran's Oil Minister, Gholamreza Aqazadeh, said on Thursday that the gas accord would be signed during Mr. Erbakan's visit. The 22-year agreement would allow Iran to sell 140 billion cubic feet of gas a year to Turkey beginning in 1998, and to build pipelines in Iran and Turkey.
Trade between the two countries totaled nearly $1 billion last year. Still, they have had their differences.
Turkey has been suspicious that Iran may be behind various terrorist attacks in Turkey that have been blamed on Muslim militants. It has also accused Iran of backing rebel Kurds fighting for autonomy in the south. In June, Iran accused Turkey of a cross-border attack in which six Iranians were killed.
But Iran has expressed hope that Mr. Erbakan's Islamic political leanings will provide a new start to relations.

HEADLINE: Political Briefing;
THE CAMPAIGNS FOR CONGRESS

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES 

 BODY:

North Carolina
Helms Is Showing A Warmer Side
A touchy-feely Jesse Helms? Who would have thought it? 
 Certainly no one who saw the first television commercial of Senator Helms's re-election campaign, broadcast in April, would have called the Senator huggable.
In the style of Senator Helms, Republican of North Carolina, the commercial was a blunt-edged attack on the two Democrats who were competing to oppose him this fall. Its main points were that both supported "racial preferences in hiring" and "extending health insurance to homosexual partners."
It harkened back to Mr. Helms's last contest, in 1990, when he defeated a black Democrat, Harvey Gantt, in a bitter contest that was notable in part because of Mr. Helms's subtle emphasis on race. Mr. Gantt is back for a second try, having won the Democratic primary in April. And now, voters are seeing the softer side of Mr. Helms.
His latest television advertisement, on crime, opens with a manacled prisoner being unshackled as a narrator recalls how violent criminals used to be released from jail early. The prisoner is distinctly Caucasian. The commercial ends with a little girl ambling safely down a country road.
For years, Mr. Helms has been among the most adamant opponents of abortion in Congress, saying in 1990 that he "will never sit idly by while people say it's just a choice." But last week, Mr. Helms told The Associated Press that he understood the position of abortion rights backers; they also dislike abortion, but "it's the choice part that they're talking about."
In 1990, Mr. Helms answered journalists' questions only by fax. In 1996, he is available for interviews "as often as time permits," said his spokeswoman, Julie Wilkie. Ms. Wilkie says Mr. Helms's abortion statement is not a softening of his views. The Gantt camp says the new Mr. Helms "is a lot like the old Jesse."
Others wonder, noting that Mr. Helms has dumped his old red-meat campaign strategists, from the Congressional Club, and hired a Texas media adviser, Scott Howell, who is renowned for his heartstring-plucking commercials.
"The guy's been born again," said Ted Arrington, a political science professor at the University of North Carolina-Charlotte. "This is an enormous change."
But Professor Arrington adds that Mr. Helms comfortably leads Mr. Gantt in the latest polls. "The real test of a candidate's intentions," he said, "is what he does when he's slightly behind."

Kentucky
Riding to Hounds For a Republican
First there was Chicken George, the Democrat in a chicken suit who followed President George Bush in 1992 to spread the accusation that Mr. Bush was afraid to debate Bill Clinton. Then came Butt Man, the filter-tipped Democrat who trailed Bob Dole this summer after Mr. Dole questioned whether nicotine was addictive.
Now meet their linear descendant, a nattily attired fellow working for the re-election campaign of Senator Mitch McConnell, a Kentucky Republican.
Hunt Man, as the McConnell campaign calls him, sports the red velvet coat, jodhpurs, black riding boots and black helmet of a patrician fox hunter. In the last week, he has begun to show up at campaign appearances by Mr. McConnell's Democratic challenger, Steve Beshear.
Mr. Beshear, a former Lieutenant Governor who is now a lawyer in Lexington, depicts Mr. McConnell as a Newt Gingrich-style Republican who is bent on slashing benefits to ordinary folk, and says his values more closely reflect the tenor of the state.
Mr. McConnell disagrees. As evidence, he notes that Mr. Beshear belonged to an exclusive fox-hunting club in Lexington's horse country even as he carried nearly $80,000 in unpaid debts to supporters from a failed 1987 campaign for governor.
To underscore that point, Hunt Man is pounding the Beshear campaign trail with a sign reading "Fox Hunters for Beshear" and yelling "Tally ho!" at inopportune moments.
Mr. McConnell's campaign manager, Kyle Simmons, said Hunt Man was doing an excellent job. "I wouldn't be surprised if he shows up throughout the remaining days of the campaign," Mr. Simmons said.

Wyoming
Democratic Chance In Senate Race?
Alan Simpson is leaving the Senate at year's end, and the departure of the eclectic Republican is leaving a hole in the Wyoming political scene as big as -- well, as big as Wyoming.
For the first time in 26 years, a Democrat may have a chance to fill it.
Wyoming voters will choose nominees to Mr. Simpson's Senate seat on Aug. 20, and nine Republicans are fighting for the job. While polls are scant in a state of only 450,000 people and no major news markets, the race appears to have narrowed to a Casper surgeon and television personality, Dr. John Barrasso, and State Senator Mike Enzi, a former Mayor of Gillette, a mining boomtown. Both are more conservative than Mr. Simpson.
Whoever wins will face a well-liked Democrat: Kathy Karpan, a coal-miner's daughter who became Wyoming's Secretary of State and now practices law in Cheyenne. Ms. Karpan has a record of budget-cutting in state government. Like Mr. Simpson, she is for abortion rights and against gun control. And even Republicans admire her campaign skills.
"She's smart," said Mike Meenan, the brother and campaign manager of one of the Republican candidates, Kevin Meenan, "a heck of a stump speaker; a very good politician."
Whether that will get her to the Senate is another matter. Ms. Karpan has already lost one statewide race, for governor in 1994, when she was buried with other Democrats in that fall's national Republican landslide.
"Her numbers are pretty good," said Stuart Rothenberg, a political handicapper. "The problem comes when the question is, 'Do they want to send Kathy Karpan or any Democrat to Washington?' I think she has a shot, but that's about it."
Bob Beck, a University of Wyoming instructor and news director of the state's public radio network, said he believed that Ms. Karpan could overcome Wyoming's suspicion of Washington Democrats. One reason, Mr. Beck said, is that the national backlash against the Republican Congress is as fierce in Wyoming as in most other states.
Her real problem, he said, is that the most revered politician in Wyoming history is likely to be stumping for her Republican opponent, whoever he may be.
"She'll be running against Al Simpson, whether she likes it or not," Mr. Beck said. "If she can overcome that, I think she's got an excellent shot at winning."
Ms. Karpan faces her own battle in the Wyoming Senate primary, but nobody expects her to lose. Her opponent is Mickey Kalinay, a 43-year-old student who maintains a home page on the World Wide Web. Mr. Kalinay proposes to create jobs and bolster the economy by building a 22,000-mile tower for future space exploration. MICHAEL WINES

HEADLINE: YACHT RACING;
All Eyes Are on Maxis At Hawaii Regatta

BYLINE: By BARBARA LLOYD 

 BODY:
What do you do with two giant maxi-yachts that needed to be transported to Hawaii for racing this week in the Kenwood Cup regatta? Since there wasn't enough time to sail them there, the owners booked them a flight.
"We had only 46 inches to spare," said Peter Wilson about loading the pair of 80-foot maxis end-to-end on a huge Russian cargo plane, an Antonov AN124-100 RUSLAN. "I was sweating it a bit. We put them in the cargo hold bow-to-bow so that we could overlap them. Then we had to fit in two keels, two masts and two boat cradles. At the end of the day, the airplane was the most economical way to do it." 
 The trip, coordinated by Wilson's company, Marine Construction Management of Newport, R.I., cost about $225,000. The maxi-yachts Boomerang and Sagamore were flown from Quonset, a military air base in Rhode Island. The two sailboats made it in time for the start last Monday of the Kenwood Cup, a biennial nine-race regatta that continues off Honolulu through this Friday.
Among the five maxi-yachts racing in the 45-boat fleet, the leader as of yesterday was Sayonara, a Farr 78 being steered by Chris Dickson of New Zealand. Over all, the competition, which includes yachts as small as 35 feet, is turning out to be intense.
"The quality of the fleet is the most competitive in the event's 18-year history," said Ken Morrison, race director. "There are no dogs out there. The oldest boat in the fleet is four or five years old, and 90 percent of the boats were built within the last two years."
The racing roster includes nine sailboats in a highly competitive Mumm 36 Class, and 14 cruiser-racers sailing under the International Measurement System handicap rule. Ten of those boats are taking advantage of a new change in the rule that gives them a 1 percent handicap allowance over grand prix racing boats.
Still, all eyes are on the maxis, those multimillion-dollar, high-tech leviathans of the sea that maneuver like dolphins. Within that elite pack, at the outset of racing last week, it looked to be a fight between two of the newest maxis and their eager owners, both of whom are computer software moguls.
Hasso Plattner of Germany, chief executive officer of SAP, the German applications software company, owns Fancourt's Morning Glory, a new Reichel/Pugh 80; and Larry Ellison, chief executive officer of the Oracle Corporation, an international software company based in Redwood Shores, Calif., owns Sayonara.
Plattner had enlisted Russell Coutts of New Zealand to steer Fancourt's Morning Glory; Ellison hired Dickson, who, like Coutts, is a top New Zealand sailor and America's Cup veteran.
But in racing last Tuesday, Morning Glory lost its mast in a 20-knot breeze. In the day's first race, a steady trade wind blew off Diamond Head near Oahu as Sayonara crossed the finish line 33 seconds ahead of the black-hulled Morning Glory.
By afternoon, big Pacific sea swells rolled across the windward-leeward course. At the beginning of the second race, both maxis came up to the start line too early, and crossed prematurely. Their penalty -- to return and round again -- gave Plattner's boat the advantage over Sayonara.
But not for long.
On its approach to the first windward mark, Fancourt's Morning Glory snapped its carbon fiber mast. None of the crew was hurt, but the incident put the anxious team and disabled yacht out of further competition.
Sayonara was first; in second was Falcon 2000, a new Nelson/Marek 78 owned by Donald Smith of Oklahoma City. The boat, being steered by Ed Baird, is a training yacht for PACT 2000, the 1999-2000 America's Cup challenge team sponsored by the New York Yacht Club.
"We're really disappointed they can't sail anymore with us," Baird said Friday. "Five of these big maxis sailing around together is just awesome."
Boomerang, a Frers 80 owned by George Coumantaros of New York, was third. The yacht's tactician is Paul Cayard, skipper for the 1999-2000 America's Cup challenge from the St. Francis Yacht Club of San Francisco. In fourth was Sagamore, a Sparkman & Stephens 82 owned by James Dolan of Oyster Bay, L.I.
In the 150-mile overnight Molokai Race Wednesday and Thursday, Sayonara finished first among the maxis.
 
MAKING WAVES
The ever-growing One Design 48 sailing fleet is planning on adding a sixth member to its fledgling ranks Friday when the group gathers for the Verve Cup in Chicago. The newest of the 48-foot sloops -- not as yet named --is being chartered by DEAN TANK of Chicago. The other five ID48's competing are: Leading Edge; Windquest; Indulgence Corum Watches; Abracadabra, and Australia Challenge 2000.
