HEADLINE: For Sale: Zambia's Rich Copper Mines, All of Them

BYLINE: By DONALD G. McNEIL Jr. 

DATELINE: LUSAKA, Zambia

 BODY:
It's easy to tell where the real money in Zambia is. Just look underfoot.
The carpet runners in the dingy halls of the Ministry of Finance are made of scuffed plastic. But in the lovely open-atrium headquarters of Zambia Consolidated Copper Mines, the runners are custom woven with the company logo: the roan antelope that back in 1902 was shot by a prospector who found its body lying atop a rich vein of green ore. 
 The national copper company produces 90 percent of Zambia's foreign exchange. It employs nearly 50,000 people. In a country where the average income is about $350 a year, it owns guest houses where visitors gaze across lakes into Zaire while dining off ivy-patterned china. Its hospital in Kitwe has the country's only CAT scanner. Its Mpelembe High School for miners' children has a pass rate on national exams of nearly 100 percent.
And it is all up for sale.
The company (universally referred to by its initials, Z.C.C.M.) is the crown jewel in Zambia's aggressive privatization program, which is converting 27 years of command-economy socialism under former President Kenneth D. Kaunda into what may be Africa's freest economy.
Since Frederick Chiluba came to power in 1991 in Zambia's first multiparty elections, he has moved to reverse Mr. Kaunda's policies and to Westernize the economy with a combination of help and arm-twisting from the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund, the lead lenders for the $6.3 billion in external debt the country is carrying.
All exchange controls, tariff barriers and food subsidies have been dropped in the shock-treatment switch-over to rampant capitalism.
Virtually everything the state owned is for sale, from the national concrete industry to corner grocery stores to antique steam trains to leases on camps in the national parks. In the last two years, 140 enterprises have been sold, said Valentine Chitalu, chief executive of the Zambian Privatization Agency.
"We had to liberalize quickly," Mr. Chitalu said. "For years, Zambia was 80 percent state-owned, and the worst-run country in Africa. There were no goods in the shops, and you could wait five hours for a bus. So the political outrage that could create a climate for privatization was there. Now it's just a matter of keeping our nerve."
Mr. Chitalu, who is 34, commands enormous respect from the Western bankers and diplomats with whom he works. Last year, in a study of Zambia's work so far, the private research institute S.R.I. International, in Menlo Park, Calif., praised the privatization program, saying that if it kept up its momentum, it would be "a model for the African continent." Its momentum has since increased.
Foreign buyers, particularly South African and British ones, are snapping up the economy. Tate & Lyle, the British food company, bought the national sugar industry for $63 million. "Now it's their lowest-cost producer," Mr. Chitalu said.
Lonrho, another British conglomerate, bought the cotton industry. South African Breweries bought one of two national breweries; Shoprite of South Africa absorbed state stores into its grocery chain.
Last month, it was announced that the biggest prize, the copper company, would be offered for sale, probably in four packages: three mine-smelter combinations and a power company. Its lesser assets, from its private airline to cobalt-rich furnace slag, may be sold separately.
As in all its other sales, the Zambian Government has outside help. The privatization agency has five Wall Street investment bankers on staff, their salaries paid by the United States Agency for International Development. The copper deal is so big that the World Bank brought in the investment bank N. M. Rothschild & Sons and the London law firm Clifford Chance as consultants.
None of this is to say that the copper company is thriving. For 20 years, Mr. Kaunda's Government drained off the foreign exchange it earned, refusing to plow back enough to buy new machinery. Annual production fell from a peak of 700,000 tons in 1969 to fewer than 300,000 last year. And copper prices have been in a slump since the 1970's. The company lost about $40 million in the first quarter of this year.
Huge investments are needed. The Nchanga open-pit mine, the company's most productive, needs $150 million in new equipment, one expert estimated. Right now, the cash crunch is so bad that it cannot buy a simple gravel crusher to harden the pit's roads during the rainy season.
But, despite the problems, big mining companies like South Africa's Anglovaal and America's Phelps Dodge are showing interest. The company is setting up an office at each mine where geological, metallurgical and financial information will be concentrated for the stream of investors it hopes are coming.
And a tour 3,000 feet down into the Konkola mine shows the huge potential -- and huge potential costs -- that investors face. Konkola is the wettest mine in the world, shedding 50 tons of water for every ton of ore extracted. Where aquifers are being drained to make new shafts possible, miners and visitors wade through tunnels thigh-deep in water.
John Kalubai, who runs a cavernous underground pumping station, seems remarkably calm for a man who, in a power failure, has 20 minutes to restart his pumps or drown. "It's worked pretty smoothly for 23 years," he said. "But it's getting harder to afford spare parts."
Once the underground lake is empty, miners can begin sinking much deeper shafts to get at a huge formation that is 3.8 percent copper -- three times as rich as many mines in the Americas -- and big enough to last 100 years. But the cost of the digging has been estimated at $600 million.
Of great concern to the ordinary miner is whether the new buyers will keep the mine schools, hospitals, housing tracts and pension plans that have made being a copper miner in Zambia a more dignified experience than being a gold miner in South Africa, despite the lower pay.
"The Government seems desperate to sell, so they might let the schools go," said a decidedly pessimistic Michael Tandeo, an administrator of the mine schools, 70 percent of whose operating expenses are paid by the company. "If I were a businessman, my heart would be in the shafts, the copper, in making a profit. It's a decision I'd probably take."
The Government has no clear stand on the issue. It is not requiring buyers to agree to retain the social services.
Edwin Koloko, head of the company's privatization effort, said buyers may choose to jettison them. "But they may find that it's in their best interests to keep them," he added.
The schools, for example, were created so that British mine managers would agree to move their families from Welsh coal fields to the Zambian copper belt. Now the student body is 97 percent Zambian, but the school is an important part of keeping managers, whether local or expatriate, happy.
Similarly, a mine hospital has more interest in saving an injured miner, if only to get him back underground, than a Government hospital.
The Mineworkers' Union of Zambia wants to keep all the social services, but the Government recently removed its president, Ernest Mutale, from the company's board, so he is no longer privy to information about bids.
"We'll negotiate with whoever is buying to make sure we still have access to these facilities we sweated for," he warned. "We do say to investors: Zambia is not for sale. If you plan to make things worse than you found them, then take your money and go away."
All those factors will be taken into consideration in whatever deal is struck.
"We've moved away from just looking at price," said Mr. Chitalu, of the privatization agency. "We look at the whole package -- whether the buyer agrees to set up training programs, or start up other industries, or introduce employee-ownership schemes."
"We need to send a message," he added, summing up the privatization effort as he was leaving for Asia to search for new investors. "Profit can be made in Africa, and southern Africa isn't just South Africa."

HEADLINE: POLITICS;
Kemp's Vision for Americans And for a Dole Presidency

 BODY:
Following are remarks made by Jack F. Kemp yesterday in Russell, Kan., where he was introduced by Bob Dole as his Vice-Presidential running mate, as transcribed by The New York Times:
Bob, thank you so very, very much for that wonderful introduction and that great welcome to Russell, Kansas, for Joanne and me. We just happened to be in the neighborhood. 
 To those who have heard me speak before it may be somewhat of a disappointment. I understand this is going to be a short Jack Kemp speech. I kind of got a feeling it was going to be short at lunch today with Elizabeth and Robin.
I turned today and I said, "Bob, how long would you like me to speak?" He said: "Kemp you can speak as long as you want. But we're only going to be here for five more minutes, or until it rains, right?"
It is no secret that I believe this is the most exciting time in the most eventful century in human history. Here on the eve of the third century, the 21st century and the third millennium, American ideals and American ideas grip the imagination of men and women in every corner of the globe.
In every country in which we travel you hear the echoes of 1776, the words of our Declaration of Independence that all men are created equal. The history of our nation has become the central feature of the history of the world. There is no more challenging nor exhilarating time in history to help shape America's leadership and America's future.
And let me say from the bottom of my heart to Bob and Elizabeth, to their daughter, Robin, with my wife at my side, I don't believe there's a higher honor than the one that Bob Dole has bestowed upon me and my dear family and my wife, Joanne.
It will be with a keen sense of determination as well as confidence in our ultimate victory that I accept the challenge and trust of running on Bob Dole's ticket for Vice President of the United States of America. It is within our grasp to renew America's promise, its possibilities and most of all its potential.
Bob Dole has formally accepted that challenge. He has unfurled our banner of growth and opportunity and hope and cultural renewal. He has proposed to fundamentally reorganize and finally change and reform the way Government does business. He wants to expand equality of opportunity for all our people. That's made the Republican Party the Lincoln party. It's now the Lincoln-Reagan-Dole reform party for America.
When he proposed major tax cuts, when Bob Dole and his team proposed major tax cuts to get America growing again, the Clinton White House immediately came out with a million reasons why it just couldn't be done.
But it forgot the real lives of millions of our fellow Americans, parents who lay awake at night because they can't pay their taxes or their bills; workers in the permanent recession of stagnant wages; the children of poverty in America's inner cities who have never seen a business open in their life.
They face despair instead of opportunity and a shot at the American dream. Tell them that the status quo is good enough. Tell them we can't do better, and grow faster. Tell them that inflation is caused by too much economic growth.
I am especially excited about Bob's bold proposal because our final goal is even bolder. This is just the beginning. This is just a down payment on true reform, reorganization and renewal.
Bob Dole's vision, Bob's vision is to start with a blank slate, create a fairer, flatter, simpler tax code that will carry us into the next century and into unimagined prosperity in our children's future.
Bob Dole knows it's time to release the pent-up and the great potential of human freedom and the free men and women of our free society.
It's a hopeful agenda. It's an inclusive agenda. And it's one that Bob has described that is not just limited to taxes. It extends to welfare and education, crime, drugs, breaking the destructive monopoly of Federal power, giving authority and resources and responsibility to states and families.
In every area, Republicans today are testing and confronting the frontiers of true ambitious reform. This is the place for the people of America who want to reform this great nation and our Government.
On one side the Clinton Administration seems satisfied with a kind of stagnation. On the other side Bob Dole is pursuing the high road begun by Ronald Reagan in 1980, a positive, specific agenda of restoring hope, cultural renewal and growth.
An election should be about most of all, the big things that touch our lives. I can't wait to make that case. I can't wait to make that case for Bob Dole in every community and every neighborhood of the United States of America.
This above all is a great nation. And we have a great mission and a great cause. The entire world is looking to America for inspiration and leadership. More than ever, we are the bright signal in an otherwise dark night. And our country needs a leader whose stature is equal to that calling. And it's Bob Dole.
We need someone who will fight for his principles, who loves America, knows what it means to sacrifice for others, to sacrifice for his nation, to demonstrate courage under fire, a leader who has throughout his career brought together men and women of all parties and all backgrounds and all colors in a common cause. Bob Dole is that man.
Let me close by suggesting that in recent years it has been a Presidential practice when delivering a State of the Union address to turn and introduce the heroes in the balcony. Next year when Bob Dole delivers the State of the Union address there will be a hero at the podium.
He'll be able to, if you let me finish my speech. Let me take a moment to put our opponents on notice. Bob and I are going to be asking for the support of every single American from the boroughs of New York to the barrios of California.
The appeal of growth and opportunity crosses every boundary of geography and climate and race. Reaching these voters, shaking hands and touching hearts is our foremost goal. We may not get every vote. But we're going to make it unambiguously clear, in word and in our actions, that we want to and intend to represent the whole American family. That no one will be left behind and no one will be turned away. That's the Bob Dole mission for America.
One other thought: the great purpose of a great party is not to defeat the other party. The purpose of a great party is to provide superior leadership and great ideas and to motivate, inspire and take this country up, not divide us.
Our goal is not just to win, but to be worthy of winning. Bob and I are asking Americans to believe again in the promise of the American dream. To reach once more for the distant stars.
We ask for your hands. We ask for your hearts and prayers. We want you to stand by us in this battle. and together with God's help we can achieve a better life for each and every American. Dr. King said, "I don't know what the future holds, but I do know who holds the future."
God bless you. God bless America.

HEADLINE: POLITICS: THE ISSUES;
KEMP FISCAL VIEWS WIN PARTY'S HEART

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 10

 BODY:
It was Jack F. Kemp's long and passionate advocacy of tax cutting as the best way to stimulate greater prosperity for both rich and poor that brought him to the Republican Presidential ticket alongside Bob Dole.
But Mr. Kemp's economic philosophy goes well beyond the tax-cutting proposals Mr. Dole unveiled on Monday, and it runs counter in many ways to the conservative Republican orthodoxy of the past few years. 
 Mr. Dole's plan, which he is counting on to reinvigorate his campaign, is based on the notion that it is possible to slash taxes by $548 billion over the next six years and still balance the budget by 2002. Mr. Kemp, while not opposed to fiscal austerity, has always argued that balancing the budget should not be the "be-all and end-all" of Republican economic policy.
While Mr. Dole's plan assumes deep cuts in spending across nearly all areas of the Federal Government except the Pentagon, Mr. Kemp maintains that it would be a mistake for Republicans to dismantle social welfare programs in the name of deficit reduction.
Mr. Dole has issued a somewhat vague pledge to overhaul the tax system, but Mr. Kemp has strong views about specific steps that should be taken, including the adoption of a single-rate flat tax, a proposal that Mr. Dole criticized when it was pushed by Steve Forbes, one of his challengers during the Republican primaries.
And while Mr. Dole has never been known for a love of detailed economic policy proposals, Mr. Kemp loves to hold forth at length on the arcane details of topics like the need to restore the nation to a gold standard.
"To Republicans, I humbly suggest that we make it possible for Democrats to give up their quest for redistribution of income and wealth by our acceptance of an appropriate role for government in financing those public goods and services necessary to secure a social safety net below which no American would be allowed to fall," Mr. Kemp wrote in an opinion article for The Wall Street Journal in June.
"The huge government bureaucracy we now confront was created over the last 60 years with good intentions, but with a redistributionist philosophy that led to counterproductive results," Mr. Kemp said. "In the face of this reality, we Republicans make a serious mistake when we try to economize first on social programs. It allows us to be characterized as putting the 'cart' of fiscal austerity before the 'horse' of rapid economic growth."
Among Republicans, Mr. Kemp has been one of the few who has tried to draw a clear line dividing taxes and other economic policies from the prosperity not just of the middle class and the wealthy, but of the urban poor as well.
One of his pet projects in recent months has been speaking out in favor of a proposal by Eleanor Holmes Norton, the nonvoting Congressional delegate for the District of Columbia, to drop the Federal income tax in Washington to a flat rate of 15 percent, from a current top rate of 39.6 percent, to attract affluent residents into the financially reeling district.
As Secretary of Housing and Urban Development during the Bush Administration, Mr. Kemp championed a proposal to allow residents of public housing to use rental vouchers to move to privately owned houses in other neighborhoods.
In some ways, Mr. Kemp is a classic advocate of free market policies. He favors free trade and supported such policies as the renewal of China's trading status with the United States and ratification of the North American Free Trade Agreement.
But he also says government policy can play a role in some situations. He has long advocated enterprise zones, where tax breaks and other incentives are used to lure businesses to poor neighborhoods.
At the core of Mr. Kemp's philosophy is the idea that more economic growth would benefit those at the bottom of the economic ladder as much as those at the top. Only through the increased tax revenues that faster growth would bring can the deficit be ended, Mr. Kemp says.
"Taxes on capital, taxes on labor, inflation, bureaucratic regulation, minimum wage laws, are all -- to different degrees -- unnecessary slices of the wedge that stand between an individual's effort and reward for that effort," Mr. Kemp wrote in 1981."
Even before Mr. Dole began considering him as a Vice-Presidential choice, Mr. Kemp was celebrating something of a victory in seeing tax cutting take center stage after several years in which his supply-side approach had taken a back seat to his party's deficit-reduction wing.
Mr. Kemp proved himself effective, if somewhat clumsy, at keeping his economic views on the Republican agenda over the last few months, when it seemed that Mr. Dole's victory in the primaries had ended any chance of the party's supply-side wing playing an influential role in the election. His clout was particularly evident at a Capitol Hill forum last month when he instigated a public endorsement of sweeping tax cuts by nearly all the Republican leadership of Congress, raising the pressure on Mr. Dole to go down the same path.
The forum had its roots in a meeting Mr. Kemp held earlier this summer with three of his best friends from the House: Speaker Newt Gingrich; Trent Lott of Mississippi, now the Senate majority leader, and Senator Connie Mack of Florida. At the meeting, Mr. Kemp, one participant said, attacked Mr. Gingrich and Mr. Lott for not doing more to pursue the supply-side agenda, and they . agreed to do something to invigorate the "pro-growth" debate. They settled on the public forum as the best way to start.
Some people in the Dole campaign were annoyed by Mr. Kemp's maneuver, but Mr. Kemp said: "I was not there to upstage the Dole campaign. I was there to get Newt and Trent and Connie to elevate the issue again because balancing the budget is not the be-all and end-all of the American economy."

HEADLINE: POLITICS: OVERVIEW;
Dole Hails Kemp as Partner in Run for White House

BYLINE: By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE 

DATELINE: RUSSELL, Kan., Aug. 10

 BODY:
Bob Dole returned today to the spot where he began his political career more than 40 years ago, to present to his hometown, his party and the nation the man he hopes will help him finally win the White House, Jack F. Kemp.
After rainy, leaden skies cleared in time for their appearance, Mr. Dole stood before an enormous American flag, with an ebullient Mr. Kemp and proclaimed what the rest of the world already knew: that he had chosen the 61-year-old former Congressman from Buffalo and sometime rival as his running mate. 
 To a crowd of about 2,000 people gathered here outside the courthouse, where Mr. Dole started his first political campaign in 1951 and then started his own unsuccessful Vice-Presidential run 20 years ago, Mr. Dole pronounced Mr. Kemp "a man of unlimited talent, energy and vision, an American original."
He added: "I've been saying for weeks, I wanted a running mate who rates a 10. Someone who believes in the same values I believe in. Someone who is ready to fight the battles I will fight. Someone who has courage, integrity and character. I was looking for a 10, and I found a No. 15, which is the number Jack wore while playing for the Buffalo Bills."
Mr. Kemp called Mr. Dole a "hero" with "stature" and called his agenda "hopeful" and "inclusive." He said Mr. Dole was "someone who will fight for his principles, who loves America and knows what it means to sacrifice for others."
Both stressed that the Dole/Kemp ticket would press for tax cuts while "not leaving anyone behind." Mr. Dole said, "Jack and I are going to work side by side with the Republican Congress to restore the American dream to every citizen."
Mr. Kemp, whose longtime concern about racial matters made him appealing to a campaign trying to broaden its base, quoted the Rev. Martin Luther King Jr. to the almost exclusively white crowd and talked about an expansive party that would lift people up. "No one will be left behind, and no one will be turned away," he promised. "Our goal is not to win but to be worthy of winning."
The appearance, complete with a balloon release, waving placards, band music and cheering crowds, was intended as a crisp and upbeat send-off before the two men go on Sunday to San Diego, where the Republican National Convention convenes on Monday to formally endorse them as the party's ticket.
There was an awkward moment or two when the habitually verbose Mr. Kemp went on about twice as long as the five minutes he promised he would speak -- and four minutes longer than his senior partner -- leaving Mr. Dole smiling gamely and fidgeting on the stage behind him.
Scott Reed, Mr. Dole's campaign manager, said Mr. Kemp, co-director of Empower America, a conservative policy group, was chosen because he was "on the leading edge of Republican ideas and policies," because his California roots could help win that important state and because he was a "leader in tax-cutting ideas." That would mean he could be an avid salesman for Mr. Dole's economic plan, which involves 15 percent across-the-board tax cuts.
Mr. Kemp's championing of tax cuts has been one of the chief ways in which he has parted company with Mr. Dole, who built his reputation by emphasizing a balanced budget.
There was considerable talk here this morning about how the two would reconcile their many differences, which over the years have included disputes over policy issues -- including welfare, immigration and affirmative action, not to mention tax cuts and balancing the budget -- as well as a prickly personal relationship.
Several years ago, in a spat over tax cuts, Mr. Dole said the finely coiffed Mr. Kemp, wanted "a business deduction for hair spray."
Mr. Kemp, who once boasted of having 1,600 books in his Maryland house, responded that Mr. Dole's library had burned down and "both books were lost -- and he hadn't even finished coloring one of them."
But aides to both men took pains today to suggest this was ancient history. "Politics is about the future," Mr. Reed said. He said that Mr. Dole was obviously aware of their differences, "but that doesn't bother him."
"The bottom line," said Charles Black, a strategist for Mr. Kemp in 1988 and now a senior adviser to him, "is whatever Bob Dole is for, Jack Kemp is for."
Pressed as to whether Mr. Kemp understood that the Vice-Presidential slot was 'No. 2" on the ticket, Mr. Reed said that the former quarterback "told me he understands, he told the Senator he understands, and I think what you'll see today is a lot of understanding."
When Mr. Dole called Mr. Kemp from Kansas on Friday night at 10:06 to tell him he wanted him on the ticket, he related a story about his own experience as President Gerald Ford's running mate 20 years ago. He said that one day in Minnesota he said Mr. Ford would raise price supports for farmers. When Mr. Ford got wind of it, he came down hard and quickly on Mr. Dole.
Nelson Warfield, Mr. Dole's campaign spokesman, added, "Jack Kemp got the message loud and clear."
During the ceremony today, Mr. Kemp joked about one aspect of their differences -- Mr. Dole's spartan use of language compared with Mr. Kemp's legendary verbosity.
He said he had asked Mr. Dole how long he wanted him to speak at today's rally. He said that Mr. Dole replied, "Jack, you can speak as long as you want, but we're only going to be here for five more minutes."
After hearing Mr. Kemp, Elmer Steinle, a 73-year-old lifelong Russell resident, who had been silent throughout both speeches, said: "He's long-winded, isn't he?"
But Dole aides said they hoped Mr. Kemp would add needed zest to the campaign.
Mr. Reed, a longtime aide to Mr. Kemp in the 1980's, said that the campaign did not seek detailed financial information from Mr. Kemp until Thursday. He said Mr. Kemp had not moved into the "top tier" of candidates, winnowed down from an initial 25 in April, until Friday.
Roderick DeArment, a Dole aide who helped in the vetting process, said that Mr. Kemp's previous runs for Congress and for the Presidency in 1988 had served as the "supreme kind of vetting."
On Friday, Mr. Reed called seven other contenders to tell them they had not made the cut. But when Mr. DeArment left Washington Friday afternoon to meet the Vice-Presidential candidate, he did not know where he was going. Mr. Reed said he called Mr. Kemp by phone on Friday afternoon to find out where he was going to be and "to see how his head was, and it was great."
Eventually, Mr. DeArment was directed to Dallas, where he and Sheila Burke, Mr. Dole's longtime chief of staff when he was in the Senate, met Mr. Kemp, who had been delayed by a flight from Orlando. The entourage left in a private jet for Kansas and spent the night at a Holiday Inn in Great Bend, 38 miles south of Russell, before being whisked into Russell this morning.
Even as the news of the selection had been out for several hours, Mr. Dole, who enjoys surprises, had told Mr. Kemp on the phone, "We're going to figure out if we can sneak you in through the back door of our little house here."
"As Bob Dole generally does, he got his way," Mr. Warfield said after the two men and their wives, Elizabeth Hanford Dole and Joanne Kemp, had emerged from the Doles' home here, providing the first official glimpse of the new ticket.
Mr. Reed said that some of Mr. Kemp's staff would be "integrated" into the campaign staff.
At the end of the week, the two men plan to visit Mr. Kemp's hometowns in California and then Buffalo, where he quarterbacked the Bills to two American Football League championships and which he represented in Congress from 1971 to 1988.

HEADLINE: POLITICS: THE QUARTERBACK;
Buffalo Region Embraces Its Favorite Football Son

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO 

DATELINE: HAMBURG, N.Y., Aug. 10

 BODY:
In the sleepy suburbs, one-stoplight hamlets and rolling farm land south of Buffalo, football has long been an elixir against the harsh winters, a chronically weak economy and the bum national reputation many residents feel they have suffered for too many years.
So it is not surprising that Jack F. Kemp is first remembered here as the fair-haired quarterback with the winning attitude and a pretty-good arm who led the Buffalo Bills to two American Football League championships in the 1960's. That he later became their Congressman, a Cabinet member and a leading spokesman for the Republican Party's tax-cutting wing is just fine, too, his fans say, if not quite as important. 
 But Mr. Kemp's 26 years in western New York, eight as a football star and 18 more as the Representative of what was then New York's 31st Congressional District, played a significant role in shaping the political ideas and public persona that he has now brought to national prominence as Bob Dole's running mate, according to his friends here. In that time, he developed many of the attitudes about tax cuts, affirmative action and immigration that have given him appeal across not only party lines, but also racial and class lines.
"His political ideals were forged here in Buffalo, by his experiences not only in Congress but on the football field," said Edward J. Rutkowski, who played football with Mr. Kemp and later worked in his district office.
Not quite Midwestern but not quite Northeastern either, the Buffalo area has long viewed itself as something of a political and cultural hybrid, and Mr. Kemp's Congressional district was as diverse as they came. From the steel mills and Polish neighborhoods of Buffalo, it streteched south along Lake Erie through affluent suburbs into rural dairy farms and cornfields. And though it was heavily blue-collar and pro-union but it was far from liberal, becoming a bastion of Reagan Democrats in the 1980's.
But it was perhaps the plight of Buffalo's dying factories that most affected Mr. Kemp. Mr. Rutkowski recalled how they would leave practice together in the early 1960's and inevitably encounter traffic jams outside the Bethleham Steel plant as shifts were changing. As the years passed, the traffic grew thinner as the company laid off workers and eventually shuttered its building.
"To see that place go from bustling to a ghost town had a profound impact on his thinking," Mr. Rutkowski said. "It made him care more about economic development, about cutting taxes and creating jobs, about rescuing inner cities."
As a football player, Mr. Kemp became close to people who, as he was fond of noting, most Republicans never associated with. And he was a co-founder and president of the American Football League's Players Association from 1965 to 1970, which gave him cachet with Buffalo's powerful union leaders.
As a Congressional candidate, Mr. Kemp was able to espouse tax-cutting, laissez-faire policies while enjoying powerful support from unionized workers, which never ceased to infuriate local Democrats.
But paradoxically, while Mr. Kemp's football fame clearly made him a household name in the region, it was also seen as something of a liability by his handlers during his first campaign for Congress, in 1970.
"There were a lot of people who thought they couldn't vote for a football player, sort of that dumb-jock thing," said Marie Richardson, a former Erie County legislator who worked on Mr. Kemp's first campaign. "They didn't know he was a history buff, that he devoured books. I'd say, 'Just come have coffee with him.' That's all it took -- one coffee."
Mr. Kemp narrowly won that race, taking a seat that had long been held by the Democrats. He was re-elected eight times, defeating challengers by increasingly lopsided margins of never less than 70 percent. Throughout that time, he made his home in Hamburg, a semi-rural town 15 miles south of Buffalo, until 1988, when President-elect George Bush named him Secretary of Housing and Urban Development and he moved his family to the Washington area.
In recent years Mr. Kemp has made only sporadic visits to western New York. But many residents here have remained in touch with his career, viewing his high national profile as a source of pride for themselves and a just dessert for a hometown hero. To his many fans, he should have become a senator, governor or even President, but always confounded and disappointed them by dropping out of the race.
"I always thought he had the capability to do more, there was so much potential in him," said Virginia Bates, a bank branch supervisor, who was Mr. Kemp's neighbor in Hamburg.
To be sure, not many people interviewed could recall details of his work in the House or as Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, though most seemed aware of his strong advocacy of tax cuts. What they remembered was his guy-next-door demeanor, garrulous speech-making, can-do optimism and, most of all, his Number 15 jersey.
"Football around here is people's lives," said Richard Dollard, a research chemist from West Senaca.
Previously undecided and unenthusiastic about the Presidential race, Mr. Dollard -- like many others interviewed -- said he now plans to vote for the Dole-Kemp ticket.
Indeed, politics was not much on the minds of the people attending the Erie County fair on Friday night when they were asked about Mr. Kemp. They simply wanted to celebrate the news that for the first time in decades, a western New Yorker -- even a lapsed western New Yorker -- had a shot at the White House.
"You don't get a lot of celebrities from around here," said Curt Young, an automobile painter from Angola. "It kind of helps the image."

HEADLINE: POLITICS: THE CONVENTION;
Wilson and Weld, Citing Restrictions, Say They Won't Speak at Event

BYLINE: By ADAM NAGOURNEY 

DATELINE: SAN DIEGO, Aug. 10

 BODY:
In a last-minute snag that spotlighted Republican efforts for tight control of the proceedings at their convention here, two Governors, Pete Wilson of California and William F. Weld of Massachusetts, have told convention organizers that they will not speak at the event rather then accede to conditions for their participation.
Aides to both men said today that they believed that convention organizers had set out to prevent them from speaking because they had been at the forefront of an unsuccessful effort to force the Republican Party to moderate the anti-abortion plank in its platform. 
 But convention organizers said they believed that Mr. Wilson and Mr. Weld were trying to shore up their credentials at home, and were showboating at the expense of party unity and Bob Dole's candidacy.
The dispute raises the possibility that the convention may open here Monday without a greeting from the Governor of the host state, Mr. Wilson, who is also a former mayor here. And it underscored the lengths to which the organizers have gone to control the agenda here, seeking to avoid the air of intolerance that permeated the Republicans' 1992 convention in Houston and to insure what the party chairman, Haley Barbour, called a "fast-paced, multi-media-oriented approach conveying easy-to-understand messages."
As the dispute unfolded today, Republican officials produced an array of internal Republican National Committee memorandums, dictating exactly what the candidates could say and even what they could wear. Mr. Barbour, in a note to Mr. Wilson explaining the party's intention, said:
"Accordingly, we look forward to working closely with you on the nature of your remarks in order to ensure each presentation enhances the objective of the convention. A commitment by you to this new approach, initial drafting responsibility, advance speech review, final editorial control, and rehearsals are simply a must if program participants are to contribute to a successful convention."
Many Republicans blamed lax vetting of convention speakers' remarks for the tone of the 1992 convention, when phrases like Patrick J. Buchanan's declaration of a "religious war" slipped by convention organizers, whose only concern was whether Mr. Buchanan was unequivocally endorsing President George Bush, and out onto live television.
This year, the organizers are not stopping at only the content of speeches. Another document, titled "Guidelines for Podium Speakers," included wardrobe suggestions: "Dark, blue or black are always the better suit colors. Pale, blue, gray and tan do not show well. Checks or plaids are not recommended." It also said jewelry should be avoided.
Mr. Weld was informed that he had two segments -- one of 90 seconds and one of 60 seconds -- to introduce two videos that would be shown. One video featured remarks by Morry Taylor, the quirky tire manufacturer and one of the more unsuccessful Republican candidates for President this year.
Mr. Weld was also told exactly what he would say. He would discuss "his leadership in bringing about economic renewal and success in Massachusetts," and that "he shares Bob Dole's economic philosophy and believes that a Dole Presidency will be good for job creation."
The problem was that Mr. Weld also wanted to talk about abortion rights, which he favors. A senior Republican organizer involved in the vetting of speakers said today that the party would have allowed him to speak about abortion. Aides to Bob Dole said they thought that Mr. Weld was just trying to highlight his abortion rights position to win advantage in his race against Senator John F. Kerry in Massachusetts.
Mr. Weld's campaign manager, Ginny Buckingham, denied the accusation of political motivation and insisted that he had been told that abortion was off limits.
"Had the convention managers said the governor could give the speech he wanted to give, he would have spoken," Ms. Buckingham said.
Mr. Wilson's situation was more complicated. Mr. Wilson said he had originally been invited to speak -- for five minutes -- in a prime-time slot on Monday. Then, shortly after his Op-Ed article appeared in The New York Times on Aug. 1 urging that his party adopt a moderate course on abortion, he was told that his role would be joining -- silently -- the Mayor of San Diego, Susan Golding, on stage in welcoming the convention delegates, on Monday morning.
Mr. Wilson's aides immediately rejected that offer. But they left little question that they saw the handling of the Governor as something of a snub, and distributed copies of correspondence from Republican officials.
"It seems a little strange," Mr. Wilson said. "But frankly, it isn't going to stand in my way of enjoying a convention that I am proud to have in my hometown and in this state, which is crucial to electing a Republican ticket."
Mr. Barbour said he had no knowledge of the letter that had been sent out under his name inviting him to speak Monday night. At a news conference, he asked a reporter to show him a copy of the letter, studied the document, and then pronounced himself vindicated.
"It says 'participate,' " Mr. Barbour said. "It doesn't say, 'speak at the podium.' I mean, I'm just telling you what it says here."

HEADLINE: POLITICS: THE REACTION;
Move Is Hailed as a Sign of Party Unity

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE 

DATELINE: SAN DIEGO, Aug. 10

 BODY:
Republicans today hailed Bob Dole's selection of Jack F. Kemp as his running mate, saying they hoped the former Buffalo Congressman would enliven their party's convention here next week and spur voters to take a second look at Mr. Dole.
While the two men have had a sometimes strained relationship for years, several Republicans applauded the choice of Mr. Kemp, an ebullient onetime professional football player, as a move that would help the ticket and show that Mr. Dole was willing to reach out to a longtime foe. 
 Republicans played down the fact that Mr. Kemp, though popular among many Republicans, has long been at odds with many in the party, including Mr. Dole, who disagree with his championing of supply-side economics and his refusal to endorse tough restrictions on immigration. And they argued that despite Mr. Kemp's tendency to talk too much sometimes, he would be a formidable competitor in a debate with Vice President Al Gore.
"Jack is life and buoyancy and optimism," said William J. Bennett, the conservative Republican author who was himself on Mr. Dole's Vice-Presidential list but told the Dole campaign on Saturday that he was not interested. "People have been saying this campaign doesn't talk enough, doesn't have ideas, doesn't have vision, and here comes Kemp. He has all three."
Ron Schmidt, a delegate from South Dakota attending party meetings here before the convention, said: "Dole is a very stiff candidate, which is why Kemp is an asset to the campaign. He is a very warm and articulate person."
Jude Wanniski, a political economist who is close to Mr. Kemp and has been publicly promoting the choice for months, was more blunt when he referred to Mr. Dole's inability thus far to catch up to President Clinton in the polls. "Dole looked like a corpse," he said, "and Jack is coming in as a rescuer."
The Republicans who said they had reservations about Mr. Kemp did not cite his qualifications, but rather his reputation as not being a team player. In fact, even after it was a foregone conclusion earlier this year that Mr. Dole would win the nomination, Mr. Kemp refused entreaties to be a loyal Republican and instead endorsed his protege, the billionaire magazine publisher Steve Forbes. That episode led many Dole advisers to believe that Mr. Kemp would never get the nod.
Today, Mr. Forbes greeted the improbable alliance with delight, He emphasized that Mr. Kemp and Mr. Dole did not have to be "bosom buddies" to make a winning team.
Gov. Pete Wilson of California noted that Mr. Kemp disagreed with Mr. Dole on affirmative action and immigration control measures. "Perhaps in the fullness of time," Mr. Wilson said, "Mr. Kemp wil have to come to modify his views to reflect those of his running mate. Obviously it seems to me he has to do that or he can not in good conscience accept a spot on Mr. Dole's ticket."
As the convention approached, a New York Times/CBS News Poll taken in late July and early August showed that 7 percent of the delegates preferred Mr. Kemp to be the running mate; the only candidates who fared better were Colin L. Powell, with 13 percent, and Gov. John M. Engler of Michigan, with 8 percent. In January 1995, when CBS News asked Republicans whom they wanted as the party's Presidential nominee, Mr. Kemp was the choice of 9 percent of those polled, while Mr. Dole was the winner, with 24 percent.
In another survey, a December 1994 Times Mirror poll conducted by Princeton Survey Associates, 43 percent of the voters polled nationally had very favorable or mostly favorable opinions of Mr. Kemp. Eighteen percent said their opinion was unfavorable; 9 percent said they had never heard of him, and 20 percent gave no answer.
Republican officials have been counting on the Vice-Presidential choice, combined with the convention next week, to give Mr. Dole a lift in the polls as the general election campaign gets under way in earnest.
Even before the choice was official, the White House and the Democratic Party were churning out news releases and compilations of Mr. Kemp's record that party leaders said demonstrated that he was out of touch with Americans, and with Mr. Dole.
In a press release today, the Clinton-Gore campaign said Mr. Kemp's selection illustrated how Mr. Dole had "completed his transformation from deficit hawk to economic gambler willing to bet our economic future on a reckless supply side theory."
"Bob Dole confirmed that women should not have the right to choose and anyone with an opposing view is not welcome in San Diego," it said.
Senator Christopher J. Dodd of Connecticut, general chairman of the Democratic Party said that Mr. Kemp had been "the darling of the extreme right in this country for a number of years."
Carole Shields, president of People for the American Way, a liberal group, said, "Moderate and mainstream Republicans have got to wonder where to turn."
But the description of Mr. Kemp as a hard-edged conservative may fall flat; Mr. Kemp has clashed at times with Republicans for his support for affirmative action and for rebuilding the cities and for not being more vocal in his opposition to abortion.
In fact, representatives of minority groups generally cheered Mr. Kemp's selection, declaring that he has been one of the few voices within the Republican Party who have shown interest in the plight of blacks and Hispanics, and one of the few to have been a counterweight to the opposition to immigration that is sweeping the party.
"Part of the ability that Kemp has is to talk to groups of audiences from the inner city and people much more associated with the Democratic Party," said Linda Chavez, a head of the United States Civil Rights Commission in the Reagan Administration.
She said that was something the Republican Party had lacked, adding: "The Republican Party has been much more the party of middle America and has tended to be middle class, upper middle class and wealthy and much less attuned to the situation of African- Americans and Hispanics."
Indeed, in his speech in Russell, Kan., today, Mr. Kemp quoted the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. and said that one of his missions was to court a broad range of voters.
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani of New York, who remains coy about his Presidential endorsement, said he was "very enthusiastic" about Mr. Kemp's addition to the ticket, praising his mastery of domestic policy as a former Secretary of Housing and Urban Development.
"He's also someone who understands cities, spent a great deal of time both as a member of Congress and as a Secretary helping cities in very new ways," Mr. Giuliani said.
Mr. Kemp, who was born in California and once played for the San Diego Chargers, could also give Mr. Dole a lift in this electorally critical state, where Mr. Dole lags far behind Mr. Clinton in the polls. But Mr. Kemp infuriated many of this state's conservatives in 1994 when he opposed Proposition 187, which required teachers and clinic doctors to deny help to undocumented immigrants and to report them to the police. Mr. Kemp said the measure was so Draconian that it would be unconstitutional.
Edward J. Rollins Jr., who was an important aide to Mr. Kemp in the 1988 campaign, said that Scott Reed and John Buckley, former aides to Mr. Kemp who are now top officials of the Dole campaign, must have warned their former boss that he had better maintain cordial relations with Mr. Dole.
Mr. Rollins criticized Mr. Kemp as being something of a loose cannon. "He's so indefatigable that they're never going to keep him down unless you have an 800-pound gorilla flying around with him," he said.
But former Senator Warren B. Rudman of New Hampshire, who is close to Mr. Dole, said he was not worried about the two getting along. "There's been a lot of scuffling back and forth between Dole and Kemp," he said. "But that was then. This is now. We're locked in a tough race."
Describing the running-mate selection as "enormously important," Mr. Rudman added: "The campaign obviously will need added depth. Bob Dole himself will say he's not the greatest on the stump."
William Kristol, editor of The Weekly Standard, a conservative publication, said the pairing was a sound one, but he said there would inevitably be tensions between Mr. Dole and Mr. Kemp. "In two weeks, we'll have stories with sources saying that Kemp's unhappy that Dole's not pushing the tax cut harder," he said.
But Republicans seem to be rallying around the selection. The House Speaker, Newt Gingrich, said Mr. Kemp was true to the beliefs of Ronald Reagan. "I know of no one who has been in more places in America preaching the concept of opportunity than Jack Kemp," Mr. Gingrich said.

HEADLINE: Man in the News;
A Passion for Ideas: Jack French Kemp

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM 

DATELINE: SAN DIEGO, Aug. 10

 BODY:
After he decided not to run for President this year, Jack F. Kemp explained himself this way: "My passion for ideas is not matched with a passion for partisan or electoral politics."
His devotion to ideas, some of them unconventional, is what has set him apart all his adult life. 
 When other professional football players were reading playbooks on the road, Mr. Kemp studied politics, history and economics.
When other members of Congress spent their time and energy on committee work and constituent services, Mr. Kemp concentrated on developing bold and controversial tax legislation, outside the jurisdiction of any committee on which he served. He also implored his Republican colleagues to reach out to blacks and members of other minority groups.
When other members of President George Bush's Cabinet concentrated on reducing the size of the Federal Government, Mr. Kemp, as the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, assembled and presented to the White House big plans for spending more money, creating more programs, rejuvenating the cities and making a greater commitment to helping the poor.
When other politicians routinely change their ideological clothing to fit the voters' fashions, Mr. Kemp, 61, resolutely sticks by his guns, even when his ideas are unpopular.
In late 1994, for instance, when he was still contemplating a race for the Presidency, Mr. Kemp gave a speech in California denouncing this state's Proposition 187, which denies schooling and other Government benefits to illegal immigrants. The proposition had just been approved by a 5-to-3 ratio, and surveys of voters showed that 80 percent of those who identified themselves as Republicans or conservatives voted for it. No matter to Mr. Kemp.
"In my view," he said in Yorba Linda that day, "that is not what America is all about. Don't ask me to defend something that is fundamentally flawed. I'm speaking from the heart, not politically."
This preference for ideas over politics, for principle over popularity, as much as it sets him apart from most other politicians, is one reason some of the people who know him best were surprised that Mr. Kemp was chosen by Bob Dole to be his running mate. Representative Christopher Shays, Republican of Connecticut, said he was thrilled by the choice, but added: "I didn't expect that he would pick Jack Kemp because Jack can be a pretty independent guy. He is going to be his own person."
John Mueller, who was the economic counselor in Mr. Kemp's Congressional office, put it this way: "Precisely because he's always been so identified with policies and ideas, I don't know how well he could fit in with the traditional Vice-Presidential role of taking marching orders and carrying them out to the letter."
The most important idea Mr. Kemp brought to the political arena was supply-side economics -- the theory that deep cuts in taxes would lead to such an economic boom that much if not all of the revenue lost from lower taxes would be offset by the additional tax receipts that resulted from greater earnings by individuals and larger business profits.
Mr. Kemp's long record as a champion of low taxes is doubtless a main reason by Mr. Dole tapped him to run for Vice President.
The story, often told over the years, is that one morning in 1976, Jude Wanniski, then an editorial writer for The Wall Street Journal and a devoted supply-sider, dropped by Mr. Kemp's Congressional office for an interview. Mr. Kemp was so impressed by Mr. Wanniski's economic views that the conversation lasted all day and ended at Mr. Kemp's home in Bethesda, Md., at midnight, by which time Mr. Kemp had been completely converted.
He began preaching the supply-side gospel far and wide, and in 1978, along with Senator William V. Roth Jr., Republican of Delaware, Mr. Kemp introduced legislation to cut income taxes by about one-third. The measure became the basis of many Republicans' Congressional campaigns that year, and two years later, Ronald Reagan made it a centerpiece of his Presidential campaign.
In 1981, the first year of the Reagan Presidency, the essence of the Kemp-Roth bill became law: a 25 percent tax cut over three years. For Mr. Kemp, it was an extraordinary accomplishment. Congressional scholars had trouble recalling another instance when a lawmaker without a seat on the committee with jurisdiction had so much influence over such important legislation.
Although few economists today embrace the supply-side theory without reservations, Mr. Kemp has never lost his fervor.
Early this year, as chairman of a private commission on tax reform created by Republican leaders in Congress, Mr. Kemp issued a report that recommended that the wages and salaries of all Americans, from corporate magnates to manual laborers, be taxed at a single, low rate. Such a step, Mr. Kemp said, would double the rate of economic growth in the country.
Mr. Kemp has never thought a balanced budget was very important. Mr. Dole, while still advocating a balanced budget, embraced the idea of lower taxes for all in the economic plan he announced this week. Republican officials have made clear that this plan will be the foundation for the speeches at the Republican National Convention, which opens here on Monday.
For Jack French Kemp, the trip to California to accept the Vice-Presidential nomination will basically be a homecoming. he was born on July 13, 1935, in Los Angeles and first became known nationally when he was a quarterback for the San Diego Chargers professional football team in the early 1960's.
He was one of four sons of a solidly middle-class couple, Paul and Frances Kemp. His father owned a small trucking business. His mother was a social worker. They lived in a heavily Jewish section of West Los Angeles. His parents were both Christian Scientists, and he was raised in that faith.
As a teen-ager, Jack Kemp's life revolved around football. Too small at 6 feet and less than 200 pounds to be recruited by the major football schools, he was determined nonetheless to become a professional quarterback. He accepted a football scholarship at Occidental College, a small liberal arts school in Los Angeles, in part because its team used professional formations and plays.
At Occidental, where he was a physical education major, he met Joanne Main, who was a year behind him in school, and they were married after she graduated in 1958. Jack and Joanne have four children, now grown: Jeffrey, Jennifer, Judith and James.
After his marriage, Mr. Kemp became a Presbyterian. He does not like to talk about his religion, although he says he has become a born-again Christian. He is a staunch opponent of legal abortions. But as a politician, he has always been more interested in economic issues than in the social issues like abortion that dominate the political thinking of organizations on the Christian right.
Mr. Kemp was drafted by the Detroit Lions after his college football career but did not make the team. He bounced around from one professional team to another, took a year off to serve as a private in the Army Reserves, tried his luck briefly in the Canadian Football League and finally landed in 1960 with the Los Angeles Chargers in the newly formed American Football League. The next year the team moved to San Diego, and by that time Mr. Kemp, if not a superstar, was solidly entrenched as a starting quarterback.
After the 1962 season, he was traded to the Buffalo Bills, and he led that team to league championships in 1964 and 1965. It was about this time that Mr. Kemp became involved in politics. Just as Ronald Reagan's first foray into politics was as president of the Screen Actors Guild, Mr. Kemp's was as a co-founder and the president of the A.F.L. Players Association, a position he held from 1965 to 1970.
He was a volunteer in Barry Goldwater's Presidential campaign in 1964 and Mr. Reagan's successful campaign for Governor of California in 1966. In the off-season in 1967, Mr. Kemp worked on Governor Reagan's staff in Sacramento.
By 1970, Mr. Kemp's football injuries, including several concussions, had taken their toll. Erie County Republicans drafted him to run for a Congressional seat in the Buffalo suburbs that had been held for six years by a Democrat who was running for the Senate. Mr. Kemp won his first election narrowly, but he won eight more terms in Congress by vote margins that never fell below 70 percent.
In his years in Congress he became an increasingly polished orator, his passion over issues overcoming a high, raspy voice. In addition to taxes, he was a fierce advocate of free trade, a staunch defender of anti-Communist forces in Central America, an important spokesman for civil rights legislation and the first lawmaker to popularize the notion of enterprise zones, which are poor neighborhoods where taxes are lowered or eliminated in order to attract business.
He called himself a "bleeding-heart conservative."
Among his closest allies in Congress were Newt Gingrich of Georgia, now Speaker of the House, and Trent Lott of Mississippi, then a Representative but now majority leader of the Senate.
Despite his preference for ideas over partisan politics, Mr. Kemp never made a secret of his political ambition.
He considered running for the Senate in 1980 but backed down rather than run against Senator Jacob K. Javits in the Republican primary. He was mentioned as a potential running mate for Mr. Reagan that year.
In 1988, Mr. Kemp announced he would not run for re-election to Congress and made a serious effort to win the Republican Presidential nomination. But his candidacy never took hold. He ended up winning only 39 delegates -- swamped not just by George Bush but by Mr. Dole and Pat Robertson as well.
Mr. Kemp had hopes of being the Vice-Presidential nominee that year. Mr. Bush picked Dan Quayle instead and made Mr. Kemp the Housing Secretary.
By almost any measure, Mr. Kemp was not successful as a Housing Secretary. He was never close to the inner circle of the Bush Administration. He battled constantly and fruitlessly for his ideas: enterprise zones, selling public housing to the poor, making welfare payments more generous. He often threatened to resign.
Moreover, he was so determined to avoid the scandals that characterized his department in the Reagan years that the housing bureaucracy became paralyzed. Local officials, developers and lenders complained regularly that plans to build or rehabilitate low-income housing were subject to long delays as the department debated its policies for awarding money.
Mr. Kemp also irritated many of his colleagues in the Cabinet with his personal manner, a problem he has faced often in public life. He was too impatient to sit quietly through Cabinet meetings, and he was always squirming, rolling his eyes and burying his head in his hands.
Asked about this after he had left the Government, Mr. Kemp told a reporter: "I mean, my body language is worse than anybody else's, you know. I can't hide my feelings."
But he has never relinquished his ideas, even when they have been mocked by others. Since he left the Government, he has spent most of his time writing and speaking and spreading the gospel about low taxes and much more.
To this day, he argues that the dollar should once again be based on the value of gold.
Until he left the Bush Administration, he held that welfare recipients should be allowed to keep 85 cents of every new dollar they earned without having their benefits reduced. And he did not relent even after Richard G. Darman, the budget director in those years, calculated that such a policy would mean that some people making $60,000 a year or more would still be collecting welfare.
He stood by his idea of selling public housing units to the tenants even when estimates of renovation and finance costs were reaching $100,000 a unit. Mr. Darman argued derisively that it would be cheaper to buy poor people new condominiums.
Mr. Kemp's main value to the Bush Administration was as a bridge to blacks. After the riots in Los Angeles in 1992, Mr. Kemp was probably the only senior official in the Administration who could move comfortably through black neighborhoods there and elsewhere and work well with black mayors.
Mr. Kemp often attributes his ability to work with blacks and his strong views on racial equality to the years he spent playing football with black teammates.
"This is my way of redeeming my existence on earth," he told a reporter a few years ago when asked where his passions about race relations and poverty came from. "I wasn't there with Rosa Parks or Dr. King or John Lewis. But I am here now, and I am going to yell from the rooftops about what we need to do."
Of course, it is one thing to shout out your opinions when you are your own man. It is another when you are running for Vice President.
Ed Rollins, a political consultant who worked for Mr. Kemp in his 1988 campaign for the Republican Presidential nomination, recalled in his new book, "Bare Knuckles and Back Rooms," (Broadway Books) that Mr. Kemp "was impossible to discipline and simply wouldn't listen."
"I call it the quarterback mentality," Mr. Rollins wrote. "Quarterbacks think they can always make the big play and resent being controlled by anyone."
 
PROFILE: Jack French Kemp
 
CURRENT JOB: Co-director of Empower America, a Washington-based conservative policy group.
BORN: Born July 13, 1935, in Los Angeles.
EDUCATION: Fairfax High School, Los Angeles. Bachelor's degree, Occidental College, 1957. Post-graduate work, Long Beach State University, California Western University.
RELIGION: Presbyterian.
MILITARY SERVICE: Army Reserves, 1958-62.
MARRIED: Married Joanne Main in 1958.
CHILDREN: Jeffrey, Jennifer, Judith and James; seven grandchildren.
GOVERNMENT POSITIONS: Special assistant to California Governor, 1967; special assistant to the Republican National Committee chairman, 1969; House of Representatives, representing the 31st Congressional District, in upstate New York, 1971-1989; Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, 1989-1992.
OTHER MAJOR POSITIONS: Thirteen years as a professional quarterback, first with the Chargers in Los Angeles and San Diego, and then with the Buffalo Bills, ending in 1969.

SECTION: Section 1; Page 26; Column 3; National Desk

HEADLINE: POLITICS;
IN HIS OWN WORDS: Jack Kemp and the Issues

 BODY:

On Abortion
In a December 1987 television interview when Mr. Kemp was seeking the Republican Presidential nomination, he was asked about what impact his wife's miscarriage had on his views:
 
"It's not something that I prefer to talk about; I don't think it's a part of the Presidential campaign. My wife had a miscarriage. We have rarely talked about it. It did make me more aware of the sanctity of human life, how precious every child is. . . . I believe, as Jefferson believed, that the whole American idea is predicated upon the idea that our rights come to use from our Creator -- not from Washington, D.C. . . .
My premise is that both the mother -- the woman -- and the child -- the unborn -- should have constitutional protections for life and freedom.
 
On Affirmative Action
From a position paper for Empower America, a public policy and advocacy organization that he co-founded in 1993:
"Affirmative action based on quotas is wrong -- wrong because it is antithetical to the genius of the American idea: individual liberty. Counting by race in order to remedy past wrongs or rewarding special groups by taking from others perpetuates and even deepens the divisions between us, but race-based politics is even more wrong and must be repudiated by men and women of civility and compassion."
 
On Race and Civil Rights
In a 1989 television interview while Secretary of Housing and Urban Development:
"I would like to make my mark as a Republican closer to the Lincoln tradition of the party as opposed to what I'd call the Hoover -- that's really unfair to Mr. Hoover. He wasn't a racist, but he made some clear mistakes in the late 1920's and 30's. But I want to be known as a civil rights Republican; somebody who is promoting what President Bush calls "an equal opportunity society."
 
On the Budget Deficit
In a policy paper for Empower America:
"The real malady is the anemic rate of growth in the economy and a political system that has lost the ability to set national priorities. It is not enough just to say that government is too big and that it overspends. The problem is that the economy isn't growing fast enough to accommodate the level of spending produced through the democratic process."
 
On the Minimum Wage
From his 1979 book, "An American Renaissance. A strategy for the 1980's." (Harper & Row):
"Of all the barriers to opportunity imposed by government, I can think of few more onerous than the minimum wage law, for it arrests the natural development of young people at a crucial stage."
 
On Trade and NAFTA
In a speech to an economic conference in Switzerland in 1995:
"It is time to establish a trans-Atlantic and trans-Pacific free trade agreement that would unite the European common market with a North American and Pacific common market. We must then invite third-world and developing nations of both Asia, Africa and Eastern Europe to participate in a global free trade initiative to offset the growing protectionism of both the political right and the political left."
 
On Gay Teachers
In newspaper and television interviews in 1987:
"I believe in civil liberties for homosexuals. I guess I'd have to say I'd draw the line at letting them teach in the schools."
"I think a school board should have the right to choose what type of example we have for our children in public schools."
On Capital Gains
In a New York Times Op-Ed article in February 1996:
"Cutting and indexing capital gains tax rates would help low-income and high-risk entrepreneurial ventures get investors, fostering a more vibrant national economy and thereby expanding the tax base. The capital gains tax is less of a tax on the rich than it is a barrier to the success of lower-income people willing to take a risk."
 
On the Gold Standard
From a position paper for Empower America:
"The new President should instruct the Treasury secretary to stabilize the dollar value of the nation's gold reserves, say within a $30 band, as a critical first step toward restoring sound money to America. This action would reinstate the dollar/gold link that was broken in 1971, which led to the most severe run of inflation in our nation's history. . . . It has long been my belief that it will never be possible to balance the Federal budget without some kind of dollar/gold link.

HEADLINE: CITY LIFE;
Brighten a Wall? How About a Whole Block?

BYLINE: By DAVID W. CHEN 

DATELINE: JERSEY CITY

 BODY:
The strip of Christopher Columbus Drive half a mile from the waterfront is easy to ignore. On either side are windows shuttered with rusted sheet metal, and desolate walls covered with grime and graffiti.
But come back in a year, and a full block of the blight should be covered with a montage of local and regional icons -- the Statue of Liberty, Ellis Island, Pulaski Skyway, the Colgate clock -- in bright acrylic paint. 
 On Wednesday, state officials approved financing for an ambitious mural covering 10 buildings between Barrow and Grove Streets, stretching 350 feet long and reaching as high as 60 feet. Work on the 15,000-square-foot mural, to be painted by local artists and student interns, is to begin in September and be done by spring.
The mural, as yet untitled, would be one of the nation's largest, and the first of several planned around the city to eliminate eyesores and beautify neighborhoods. They could also be a form of low-cost municipal therapy, a psychological boost that city officials say could turn into an economic one.
"Would you go to a store by a wall that is all graffiti and uncared for, or will you stop by a store by a beautiful wall?" asked Tsipi Ben-Haim, executive director of City Arts Inc., a nonprofit organization in Manhattan that sponsors public art. "Murals have been proven to be educational, a crime stopper, pride builder, economic development builder. There's a sense of ownership, and pride that the community gets after being involved in the creative process."
The use of murals as a rallying point for civic pride and renewal goes back at least to the New Deal, when the Federal Works Progress Administration commissioned more than 2,500 murals, most notably those by the great Mexican artist Diego Rivera, to depict images of human triumph and industry. In New York, the 1975 mural depicting the Brooklyn Bridge is a centerpiece of the revivified South Street Seaport.
But the Jersey City mural will challenge some of those better-known ones, at least in terms of size. It will not be the nation's largest -- that distinction belongs to the 128,000-square-foot "Planet Ocean" in Long Beach, Calif. -- but it will be one of the largest on the East Coast, dwarfing the famous 9,000-square-foot abstract mural on the defunct Alexander's store in Paramus.
The mural will be painted on the backs of 10 buildings whose storefronts are on Newark Avenue, stores that include a Woolworth's, a pharmacy and a pizza parlor. All have worked with a group of local artists for the last year and a half to plan the mural.
The final design is based on proposals submitted by five local artists, along with suggestions from the public. It was assembled by Rupert Ravens, a 41-year-old Jersey City painter who regularly works on a large scale. The finished mural, to be painted by nine artists and nine interns, will cover the buildings' back walls, peaking in the center with a triumphant Pulaski Skyway. Other images include a pastiche of Jersey City emblems, including the Barrow Mansion, a local landmark; a pencil, representing the Dixon Mills pencil factory, a Jersey City institution until it moved to Delaware) and the violet, New Jersey's state flower.
"It hopefully gives the city a landmark, and more identity," said Franc Palaia, another painter, noting that city officials say 18,000 cars pass through Christopher Columbus Drive daily.
The project is to cost $227,000, mostly to cover labor, starting with two months of intense chemical cleaning. About $182,000 will come from the state's Urban Enterprise Zone Authority, which allocates money collected from a special lowered sales tax meant to attract shoppers to designated urban areas. About $17,000 will come from the Jersey City Economic Development Corporation, and the rest from donations raised by Pro Arts, an organization of professional visual artists in Jersey City.
When the work starts, Pro Arts will train a camera on it and transmit the images to its site on the Internet (http://members. aol.com/proarts111) so computer users can follow its progress.
Artists want to paint their next mural on an empty storage tank at Liberty State Park. In all, the city hopes to paint murals in each of its seven wards, said Gene Nelson, director of the Jersey City Urban Enterprise Zone program. No designs have yet been made for those murals, only suggestions that each mural capture the flavor of its neighborhood.
Some artists are uneasy about being involved in projects with such a strong focus on economic development. "The important thing is to get it done and that it should be a good piece," said Richard Haas, the New York artist who painted the South Street Seaport mural. "Then, maybe it takes on a life of its own which neither I nor you can predict."
But artists say the murals can at least inspire people to keep their neighborhoods cleaner. In Philadelphia, where public art flourished in the 1980's, less than 1 percent of the murals have been vandalized.
"We don't have illusions that one mural will transform this city," said Leon Yost, a Jersey City photographer who has been the project's coordinator. "But we hope that each piece forms part of the package that makes the place better."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Five of the artists working on the 350-foot-long Jersey City mural stood in front of the block on Christopher Columbus Drive where it will be painted. From left, Franc Palaia, Rupert Ravens, Caroline Burton, Greg Bamgart and Leon Yost. (Norman Y. Lono for The New York Times)
 
Map of Jersey City, New Jersey showing area of the mural.

SECTION: Section 13NJ; Page 4; Column 1; New Jersey Weekly Desk
