HEADLINE: Battle Lines in a War on Noise Lie Just Beyond the Runway;
Nearby Queens Residents Unite to Take On Airports

BYLINE: By NORIMITSU ONISHI 

 BODY:
Bill Mulcahy, a retired city firefighter, was enjoying the warmth of a recent sunny morning in his backyard in Queens. His father-in-law sat at a table under an umbrella and his niece lazily dangled her toes in a shallow, plastic pool. This, Mr. Mulcahy said, is the good life.
Then a jet suddenly appeared in the sky, shattering Mr. Mulcahy's quiet retirement. The plane passed over Jamaica Bay and soared above the Mulcahys' two-story house in Rockaway Beach, the roar of its engines smothering conversation. 
 "That was from Runway 31-L," Mr. Mulcahy yelled, his arms akimbo, his eyes resentful and glued to the plane as it flew toward the Atlantic Ocean. "It had to make almost a 180-degree turn over Jamaica Bay to go over us."
Most people living near Kennedy and La Guardia Airports might shrug off the din after a while. But in a city filled with neighborhood agitators and block revolutionaries, Mr. Mulcahy, 51, belongs to a particular Queens subculture: those who hate the airports but refuse to move. They memorize the designation of each runway and publish newsletters against the airports, with a feistiness that puts them on a first-name basis in Borough Hall, at the Federal Aviation Administration offices in Washington and the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey atop the World Trade Center.
Three years ago, Mr. Mulcahy co-founded Sane Aviation For Everyone. Flanked by a former Roman Catholic priest from Rego Park and a septuagenarian podiatrist from Howard Beach, he has waged a relentless, sometimes colorful, campaign against airplane noise in news releases and marches, on public access television and the Internet.
The group is part of an increasingly sophisticated network of noise protesters who fax and E-mail one another studies and bills relating to their cause. From Queens to Seattle to Sydney, Australia, they share strategies on how to lobby politicians and battle their common enemies -- airports, airlines and government aviation officials.
"You become so involved because every rock you turn over, you find something nastier," said Jack Saporito, the director of the Alliance of Residents Concerning O'Hare International Airport in Chicago. "This has become a full-time job. I used to have a small marketing company, and it's gone straight to pot." And so Mr. Saporito, 49, now works four hours a night as a janitor to "keep himself above water."
He and the others view themselves as crusaders against a neglected form of pollution: noise. They say they fight on behalf of apathetic neighbors. They want fewer nighttime landings and takeoffs or higher-altitude routes over their roofs or different paths altogether. Their critics see them, at best, as gadflies and, at worst, as conspiracy-mongers whose identities are dependent on the airports they hate.
Noise protesters are rallying these days against Seattle-Tacoma International Airport, which plans to add a third runway, and the new Denver International Airport, which opened last year. But the New York area, where a third of the airplane-noise-affected people in the nation live, seems the epicenter of the debate.
Relief comes for only a few and then for only two weeks near the end of the summer, when the United States Open prompts the routing of flights around the National Tennis Center in Flushing Meadows. But moving flight patterns out of one neighborhood only puts them in another.
The Port Authority estimated in 1994 that 211,000 people, or more than 10 percent of Queens residents, were "noise impacted," living close enough to the borough's two major airports that the average ground noise level from planes was above 65 decibels.
A jet taking off usually registers more than 100 decibels, using the standard measurement for the relative loudness of a sound. Some residents live so near to La Guardia that the average ground noise level around their homes (between 30 and 40 decibels during quiet moments) reaches more than 75 decibels, the equivalent of a car alarm. But the majority of those affected by jet noise at the two New York airports endure between 65 and 70 decibels -- enough for many schools to have qualified for funds to soundproof their walls and windows.
Houses near the airports stand a stone's throw from runways. Jets land and take off, as if a few feet above rooftops, rattling walls and windows, temporarily blotting out the sun, stopping people in mid- . . . . La Guardia disturbs more people, but the summer raises the noise to its peak at Kennedy. International travel increases. Jets need more power when the weather is hot. Residents' windows are open.
The situation begs the question: why do these people stay?
Why should they move, asks Allan Greene, the podiatrist who helped start the Sane Aviation group and has lived in a two-story house in Howard Beach since 1964. "There are old houses here built before the airport was ever here."
Mr. Greene, who dedicates three hours a day to airplane noise, said he suddenly became deaf in his left ear in 1989. "The doctors claimed it was viral," he said. "They don't know. I tried to get them to say it was aircraft noise, but they wouldn't commit themselves."
If Mr. Greene describes himself as Sane Aviation for Everyone's whip, Frans C. Verhagen is its spiritual leader. After serving as a missionary priest in Ghana, the Dutch-born Mr. Verhagen became interested in ecology at Columbia University in the 1970's. He said he eventually "evolved out" of the priesthood, then married and taught environmentalism at the New York Institute of Technology and junior high schools.
Unlike the others, Mr. Verhagen, 60, lives in Rego Park, midway between the two airports. "Our organization is about far more than working toward noise mitigation," he said. "Noise policies represent only the tip of the ecological iceberg of neglect by the industrial technological paradigm of a mechanistic world view."
The group had trouble focusing early on. When four of its members met with Representative Nita M. Lowey a year ago, she listened to them for 15 minutes. Then, she asked what they wanted her to do.
"We didn't have an answer," Mr. Greene recalled. "It took us by surprise. We thought she would come up with an answer."
Since then, the group has retained Patrick Russell, a lawyer representing several antinoise groups on the East Coast and in Denver. One, a coalition of 208 communities in northern New Jersey, has waged one of the longest and fiercest campaigns since routes out of Newark International Airport were changed in 1987 and sent planes over virgin territory.
"Focus on noise!" Mr. Russell exhorted the Queens group during a recent meeting when someone had suggested tackling air pollution. Mr. Russell urged them to get a list of registered voters near the airports. Contact civic leaders. Create a new group, New York Citizens for Environmental Research, to unite members from Brooklyn, Long Island and Westchester County.
Antinoise forces organized in the last decade after the deregulation of the airline industry in 1978 led to a boom in flights. Built in the propeller age, airports were overwhelmed. Only one, Denver, has opened since 1974.
For Mr. Saporito, it all began in 1986. He moved away from an apartment half a mile from O'Hare to the suburb of Arlington Heights, 12 miles away, seeking quiet. But a runway extension a few years later sent planes his way, he said, and two years ago, he started his protest group with only 26 members. Today, the mailing list totals 1,200, he said, with each household paying $10.
Last month, Mr. Saporito, a Vietnam War veteran, reckoned he made 800 telephone calls, working up to 80-hour weeks. So complete is his devotion that he used to talk to his daughter on the phone twice a day but has not heard her voice in two weeks. Worse yet, his noise-protest efforts stopped him from spending as much time as he wanted last year with his dying mother.
People also began to regard noise as a form of pollution that might reduce the value of their homes and harm their health. Arline L. Bronzaft, a former professor of psychology with the City University of New York who has studied the effects of noise on learning and has worked with the Queens antinoise group, said no one has been willing to finance a comprehensive study of airport noise.
"The attitude toward the impact of airport noise now is comparable to the attitude toward cigarette smoking 30 years ago," she said.
The paradox for airport officials is the number of noise-affected people has dropped in recent years, they say. Quieter planes and new flight patterns have reduced the residents affected by the Port Authority's three major airports from 2 million two decades ago to 250,000 two years ago. By the year 2000, when airlines are required to convert their entire fleets to a new generation of jets, the number should go down again.
But no one expects the issue to disappear, especially in New York, the world's most congested airspace.
As David Plavin, president of the Airports Council International, a trade group for airports and a former head of airports for the Port Authority, put it: "It's a class issue. It's a political issue. It's a racial issue. It's an economic issue."
Mr. Mulcahy, surrounded by stacks of documents on Kennedy Airport in his bedroom, shook his finger at a map of the Rockaways. Although the aviation authorities are supposed to fan the routes over the peninsula, the planes avoid the wealthier, white communities west and east of his neighborhood, he said.
Even with fanning, which started in 1995, the Port Authority said Mr. Mulcahy's area, a straight shot from one of the runways, will inevitably draw more of the flights.
Mr. Mulcahy moved to this outpost of the New York empire after working for several years at a fire station nearby. He has no plans to move.
His wife wants him to make money from the thousands of dollars he has spent on computer equipment. But for him, the message of airport noise is more important. To spread it beyond New York, he created a Web page (http://pages.prodigy.com/ NY/rockaway/safe.html) and bombarded several Internet news groups with his views.
Many attacked him, some with surprising venom. Someone even created a news group (alt.aviation. bill-mulcahy.screech.babble.drool) just to ridicule his views on aviation. Mr. Mulcahy regarded all that as part of the Internet's Wild West culture.
But he was disappointed that the news group had recently become a no man's land to which the only visitors were pornography peddlers. He couldn't interest any of them in airplane noise.

HEADLINE: The Pitfalls in Home-Care Policies

BYLINE: By ANDREE BROOKS 

 BODY:
IT sounds indispensable: long-term care insurance that covers domestic help and personal-care services so that frail elderly people can remain in their own homes.
Advertisements for such policies, like the one in the August issue of Money magazine, promise "a surprisingly affordable way to guarantee yourself access to higher-quality home care without having to rely on your life savings." 
 Consumers, frightened by the prospect of entering a nursing home, bought 4.8 million long-term care policies that included in-home services in 1995, up from 1.9 million in 1990, according to the Health Insurance Association of America, a trade group. A typical policy for a healthy 65-year-old cost about $3,000 a year.
But there may be a sizable gap between what consumers think they bought and the help they will actually receive when they need it. And truly comprehensive coverage often exceeds a family's ability to pay.
Most policies will not provide immediate at-home help after a broken hip because so-called homemaker benefits do not go into effect until 60 to 100 days after a hospital stay. Most policies would not help someone who had simply lost the ability to get in and out of the bath; strict criteria must be met before such help is provided.
In-home benefits are "the most misunderstood element of today's long-term care policies," said Gail Holubinka, director of the New York State Partnership for Long-Term Care, a public-private program that works to bring down insurance costs. "They may be of less use than you expect, unless you have some family backup, too."
Long-term insurance used to cover only nursing-home care or in-home care after discharge from a nursing home. But critics noted that what most older people in declining health really needed was help with domestic chores and with dressing and bathing. Why require hospitalization before benefits kick in? they asked; the onset of physical or mental decline rarely happens that way.
So, insurers began offering policies with two parts. The first part offered in-home care benefits that usually pay $100 a day for help with personal and domestic chores. Most policies require that the helper be hired through a licensed home-health agency, costing $15 to $25 an hour.
The second part of a policy is the nursing-home benefit, usually $200 a day. (Nursing homes in the New York area cost about $250 a day, according to the Partnership for Long-Term Care.)
But are a few hours of help a day truly what an elderly person needs to keep functioning? Dr. Leslie Libow, chief of medical services at the Jewish Home and Hospital for the Aged in New York, described the needs of two recent patients.
The first was an 86-year-old widow living alone in a Manhattan apartment. She had lost most of her vision and was unsteady on her feet. By having a helper come in each day for three hours to wash and dress her, make some food and take her on brief walks, the woman was able to stay in her home for about three years longer than had been expected.
The typical policy would have been sufficient for this woman, but, Dr. Libow added, the woman could get by on so little help because her daughter lived nearby and visited each day.
A second case involved an obese woman of 78 who had severe neurological problems that left her so short of breath she had trouble getting out of bed and feeding herself. Her arms and legs were weak. But she wanted to stay at home with her husband, who was also quite frail. Home help was needed for at least eight hours each day.
In this sort of case, the average benefit would have fallen short. Hiring a helper for eight hours would cost $120 to $200 a day at agency rates.
In spite of such drawbacks, Dr. Libow said he found the advances in in-home coverage "impressive." Though he acknowledged that there are obstacles to widespread use, he said he believed that "as families become more facile at putting these policies into action, the better it will be."
To activate a policy, policyholders must get confirmation from a doctor that they have lost the ability to perform two or more of the following by themselves: eating, bathing, dressing, moving without falling, moving from a bed to a chair and getting to the toilet. Many insurance companies send their own representative to confirm the diagnosis.
"It has to be far more serious than people expect," Ms. Holubinka said. "It not just a matter of not being able to button your sweater."
A live-in companion may be of the most use to the elderly in the early stages of decline, said Cathy Cress, president of Cress Care Management for Elders of Monterey, Calif. Yet, a companion, costing $150 a day, rarely qualifies for reimbursement.
How, then, to make an informed decision? A good source for counseling is the National Association of Professional Geriatric Care Managers in Tucson, Ariz.; (520) 881-8008.
To reduce premiums, experts say, long-term care policies should be bought before age 60. Consider examples offered by Gerie Charnow of Huntington, L.I., a geriatric-care manager, who also sells long-term care insurance.
A 55-year-old New York woman in good health would pay around $1,880 a year for a policy from John Hancock that provided $200 a day for nursing-home care and $100 a day for homemaker services, either of which could last six years. A comparable policy from the Travelers Insurance Company would cost $1,470. If the same woman bought the policy at age 65, she would pay $3,500 from Hancock and $2,700 from Travelers.
At 55, it is also relatively inexpensive to reduce the waiting period for home-care benefits to go into effect, which could make a big difference. For instance, if the 55-year-old woman were to drop from a 60-day to a 20-day waiting period, her annual premiums would rise only $90 at Travelers, $218 at Hancock. To do that at 65 is much more expensive.
Some of the best deals in policies are offered in states that have public-private collaborations like the New York State Partnership for Long-Term Care (888 697-7582). The 65-year-old woman could get a Hancock policy through the Partnership for $2,500 a year, about 30 percent less.
Consider, too, companies that offer direct cash benefits for home care instead of reimbursement. First Unum Life Insurance Company of Portland, Ore., is one. Although premiums are higher -- the same 65-year-old New York woman would pay $3,600 for her Unum policy -- the net cost could be lower because the woman could hire helpers without going through an agency.
"You could even use the money to pay a daughter or son to care for you," said Tracy Sherman, a Unum spokeswoman.
A policy should have an inflation rider of at least 5 percent a year, experts say, and benefits should last at least three years. And it should cover respite care (to allow a family member a break) and adult day care, should outside services become more practical.
If the cost does not put you in the poor house, it could be a good idea to bring the daily benefits for home-based care up to the level of nursing-home care. Most policies incorporate only half the amount. Another way to maximize benefits is with policies that allow "pooling." If home help is needed only five days a week, the weekly sum of $700 is divided over five days.
Finally, "never be persuaded to buy more than you can comfortably afford," said Bonnie Burns, a consumer consultant in Santa Cruz, Calif. You could be paying for services you might never use.

HEADLINE: The New Car Market's Lost Generation;
Auto Industry Struggles to Satisfy the Tastes of First-Time Buyers on a Budget

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: MONROE, Mich.

 BODY:
Kristin M. Anson, a 31-year-old radiology technician, and her husband, Bill, a 35-year-old truck driver, really want to buy a new full-size, option-laden Dodge pickup for upward of $25,000. But after carefully reviewing their pinched budget, they have decided instead to keep the 1989 Mercury Cougar they bought in 1992 for $9,900.
What irks them is that Mrs. Anson's older brother, who is a 45-year-old power plant foreman, has been able to afford a succession of new cars and trucks. "It's aggravating that I work just as hard, if not harder, but the rewards do not come as easily as they do for people born 10 years earlier," Mrs. Anson said, balancing her 19-month-old daughter, Samantha, on her right hip at the county fair in this blue-collar town, some 40 miles south of Detroit. 
 Mrs. Anson is not the only one annoyed by the harsher financial realities faced by the 35-and-under generation. Increasingly, domestic and foreign auto makers worry that Americans born in the 1960's and early 1970's are proving a much less prosperous market than the graying baby boomers of the 1950's.
In response, the car companies are rethinking vehicle design and marketing strategies, aiming to match less expensive cars and small trucks with buyers who cannot keep up financially with their older brothers and sisters.
As Honda Motor tries to hold prices level for redesigned vehicles like the Civic coupe, it has hired authors of books about young people's finances to help it decide what features to omit. Ford Motor actually lowered prices on some versions of its Escort when it restyled the small car this spring. And General Motors and Ford both plan to go after the youth market by designing compact sport utility vehicles that could sell for under $15,000 with off-the-shelf engineering.
Indeed, the need to hold down costs for younger buyers -- who now account for a bit more than a quarter of new-car sales, a slowly eroding share -- is one reason that Detroit's Big Three are reluctant to grant significant pay and benefit increases in talks with the United Automobile Workers this fall.
Advertising campaigns are also being tweaked. After concluding that more and more buyers of Jeep Wranglers were turning to parents and grandparents for the money, Chrysler softened its rough-and-tumble cowboy theme this spring, said Thomas R. Krehbiel, a managing partner at Chrysler's advertising firm, Bozell Worldwide, a unit of Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon & Eckhardt Inc.
Now, Chrysler's television commercials show 20-year-olds sitting around campfires in serene wilderness, with Wranglers parked nearby. A new radio spot features a young woman driving a Wrangler with a dozing mother-in-law in the back. Wrangler prices start at $13,995, making it one of the few vehicles cheap enough to sell extremely well to young buyers.
At such prices, though, the vehicles being marketed to younger drivers cost far more than the classic first cars of the past. In 1951, for example, a Volkswagen Beetle listed for $1,280 -- or $7,626 in today's dollars.
"The whole industry, domestic and nondomestic, shares a concern with respect to affordability," said Harry J. Pearce, G.M.'s vice chairman. "You can't allow the pricing of our products to move beyond the market."
Car makers are far from alone in trying to cope with the profound economic changes set in motion by the aging of the baby-boom generation. That group's huge numbers left a dearth of well-paying jobs for those who followed, including the last of the boomers, who were born in the early 1960's. The impact is being felt from the fashion business to the home-building industry.
And the concerns may only grow as the younger generation grows older. When baby boomers begin retiring over the next couple of decades, experts predict that the next generation will be unable to fill the boomers' shoes. For car makers, that would mean fewer sales of the more expensive -- and profitable -- vehicles that mark middle age.
Demographics can cut both ways, of course. Some economists have found evidence that the youngest Americans now entering the work force -- those born when the birth rate bottomed out in the mid-1970's -- may be doing better financially because they are in relatively short supply. Detroit's marketers are already studying the buying preferences of this group -- for instance, interviewing students on spring break in Daytona Beach, Fla.
For now, though, the car makers have their hands full trying to satisfy those born in the 60's and early 70's, a demanding constituency that may have little to spend but does not want anything that looks cheap or cuts corners on reliability and safety.
So far, Detroit's record has been spotty, with high fixed costs for engineering and factory work making it hard to offer cars under $10,000 and sport utility vehicles under $15,000. Starting prices on Dodge and Plymouth Neons, which are marketed as first new cars, are jumping $500, to $10,895, for the coming model year. And some of the least expensive cars, like Ford's diminutive three-door Aspire, which sells for $9,530, are having trouble attracting buyers, who are put off by the lack of space and style, among other things.
Because of the dollar's long slide, foreign car makers, too, have had a hard time producing inexpensive vehicles that meet the quality demands of young buyers. For example, Toyota Motor has just introduced a compact sport vehicle, the RAV4, which is aimed at young buyers but sells for $15,368 to $18,518 before options.
The hand-wringing over affordability and young buyers represents a sharp U-turn for car makers after years of catering to people born in the 1950's, the nation's largest generation and one of the most prosperous. It was this group that fueled the market for small pickup trucks in the early 80's and then, as it began producing its own mini-boom of babies, created the mini-van market almost overnight. Now, these drivers are buying extraordinary numbers of large sport utility vehicles like the Jeep Grand Cherokee and the GMC Suburban. More than half of all industry profits come from mini-vans and sport utility vehicles.
But ask auto executives about the generation born in the 1960's and they grow grim.
A few statistics from Census Bureau data and other sources demonstrate the scale of the problem. When the children of the 1940's were aged 25 to 34 in 1974, they needed to work an average of only 21.7 weeks to afford a typical car -- just a week longer than the average then for Americans of all ages. When the children of the 50's were the same ages in 1984, they needed to work 31.9 weeks, or three weeks longer than the national average.
But when the children of the 60's were the same ages in 1994, they needed 36.2 weeks, or nearly five weeks longer than the average.
General Motors has been tracking this sort of data for years, keeping it in mind while designing fairly affordable cars like the Chevrolet Cavalier.
G.M. also takes elaborate steps to measure the popularity of certain options against the cost of making them standard. The analyses have persuaded the company to make antilock brakes optional on a growing number of low-priced models, like the Geo Metro, said Robert L. Bierley, G.M.'s director of truck planning. At the same time, G.M. is scrambling to install passenger-side air bags on all its cars and light trucks because the demand by young people for second air bags is strong relative to the cost.
In re-engineering vehicles to keep costs down, the biggest changes involve making novel use of existing parts, like putting suspension systems from today's cars on future sport utility vehicles. Auto makers are also trying to cut costs in smaller ways -- not painting fuel tanks, for instance, and choosing less expensive fabrics for seats and carpets.
Meanwhile, the financing arms of the auto companies are trying to address the affordability issue with long-term leases and stretched-out loans that reduce monthly payments. The big auto makers also have discount programs for recent college graduates.
One of the biggest questions confronting product planners is whether to stick with their current efforts to design more affordable sport utility vehicles, like the small Wrangler. The alternative is to switch to making even lower-priced cars, which can be cheaper than almost any sport vehicle.
Market surveys show that the younger the buyers, the more they want sport utility vehicles, said James N. Hall, a consultant at Auto Pacific Group, a marketing firm in Santa Ana, Calif. But not all cheap sport vehicles sell well; dealers have large inventories of unsold Geo Trackers.
The latest convert to generational analysis is Ford, which ran into trouble selling its redesigned and more expensive Taurus sedan last autumn. "We're really taking all of this data into our new products," said George E. Manning, Ford's strategy manager for corporate design.
What Ford and others are finding is that the younger buyers are not all the same. While the Mazda Miata is popular among the children of the 1960's, more practical vehicles like Saturns have been hits among the children of the early 70's, a period sometimes known as the Baby Bust because of its sharp decline in births. "The trailing-edge baby boomers would be more likely to trade off something practical for something cuter, while a baby buster would have nothing to do with that," Mr. Manning said.
Some industry executives profess not to be very concerned about affordability. John R. Watts, Honda's assistant manager of product planning, noted the rising number of young Americans living with their parents long after college and contended that these men and women might spend more money on cars and trucks, rather than less.
Other executives point out that the rise in income inequality in the United States, which has been particularly pronounced among young people, will allow them to at least sell large, high-profit sport utility vehicles to the most affluent younger buyers.
Peter Cansler, a 28-year-old data processing director in Milwaukie, Ore., just bought his first new vehicle, a 1996 GMC Sierra pickup. He reasoned that the $25,000 vehicle would hold most of its resale value because late-model pickups are in short supply. "I figure I can drive it for a year and only lose $1,000," he said.
More typical, though, are people like Neil and Kathryn Kramer, both born in 1969, who went looking for a car in late July. He earns $30,000 a year as a dispatcher for the sheriff's office here in Monroe, a job he found four years ago after six months of unemployment. She earns $18,000 from a clerical job at the county courthouse. They have a 6-year-old son, Nicholas, and recently bought an $85,000 house. So the prospect of spending close to $20,000 for a midsize sedan appalled them.
Instead, they paid $10,900 for a 1995 Oldsmobile Achieva.
"I can't afford a new one right now," Mr. Kramer said. "I can get a better deal on a used one that's a year or two old."

HEADLINE: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;
A Land of Civilities, Achievements and 'Chumley'

BYLINE: By MICHIKO KAKUTANI 

 BODY:

NOTES FROM A SMALL ISLAND
An Affectionate Portrait of Britain
By Bill Bryson
324 pages. William Morrow & Company. $25.
 As the title of this book suggests, the American writer Bill Bryson has not written your usual sort of travelogue. He has not tried to give us a dispassionate assessment of contemporary Britain or a reportorial tour of its cities and provinces. What he has written instead is an unabashed love letter, an affectionate inventory of the virtues of his adopted homeland.
 Having lived in Britain for nearly two decades, Mr. Bryson decided last year to make a sort of farewell tour of the island, before returning home to the United States with his wife and children. He would spend several weeks traveling about the country, from London down to the south coast and north through Manchester and Liverpool to Scotland; along the way, he would make some casual notes and try to dissect his abiding love for the country. The resulting book is an engaging, if somewhat self-indulgent, antidote to Paul Theroux's dyspeptic 1983 volume, "The Kingdom by the Sea." 
 Whereas Mr. Theroux saw poverty, unemployment, violence and dullwittedness, Mr. Bryson sees optimism, humor and achievement. He loves the country's curious pronunciation of words (Cholmondeley as "Chumley," Belvoir as "Beaver"). He loves its genius for names (prisons named Wormwood Scrubs and Strangeways; villages named White rashes, Mockbeggar and Blubberhouses).
Perhaps most of all, he loves its "incidental civilities": "cheery red mailboxes, drivers who actually stop for you at pedestrian crossings, lovely forgotten churches with wonderful names like St. Andrew by the Wardrobe and St. Giles Cripplegate, sudden pockets of quiet like Lincoln's Inn and Red Lion Square, interesting statues of obscure Victorians in togas, pubs, black cabs, double-decker buses, helpful policemen, polite notices, people who will stop to help you when you fall down or drop your shopping, benches everywhere."
Although Mr. Bryson glosses over many of Britain's problems, he is not a complete Pollyanna. In the course of his travels, he notes that northern Britain lost more than a million jobs during the early 1980's and that scores of factories have closed. Anonymous concrete and glass edifices have sprung up around the country, he says, and many small English towns have become indistinguishable from one another: "They all have a Boots the Chemist and W. H. Smith bookshop and Marks & Spencer department store."
Oxford, especially, has earned his displeasure for its careless treatment of the past, its disfigurement of the landscape with such architectural atrocities as "the horrible, low-ceilinged, ill-lit drabness" of the Clarendon Shopping Center, the "equally unadorable" Westgate Shopping Center and the "brutalist compound of the magistrates' courts."
Still, Mr. Bryson's disdain for Oxford cannot suppress his delight in its history and achievement. He marvels that he can walk through its streets and in the space of a few hundred yards pass "the home of Christopher Wren, the buildings where Halley found his comet and Boyle his first law, the track where Roger Bannister ran the first sub-four-minute mile, the meadow where Lewis Carroll strolled." Where else but in Britain, he asks, can one find "a landscape more packed with centuries of busy, productive attainment?"
The author of several books on language ("Made in America," "The Mother Tongue"), Mr. Bryson writes in snappy, novelistic prose that's seasoned with little-old-lady Britishisms. "Goodness me!" he exclaims when he catches himself railing against Oxford's modern architecture. Elsewhere, while trying to recover from a hangover, he laments that all he wanted was "a bit of a sit-down."
"Notes From a Small Island" has its longueurs -- too many descriptions of the author's drinking, too many asides about the weather -- but Mr. Bryson enlivens his account with amusing descriptions of places and people. He notes that the new houses surrounding the sanitarium in Virginia Park echo the mother building's Victorian details. "The result was that they looked as if they had somehow been pupped by the sanitarium," he writes. "You could almost imagine them, given sufficient time, growing into sanitariums themselves."
In addition, Mr. Bryson introduces us to a wide assortment of oddballs encountered in both his travels and his readings: a puffin aficionado, who's devastated when the author inadvertently causes him to miss "World of Birds" by switching channels on a rooming house television; the fifth Duke of Portland (1800-1879), who spent most of his time in a small corner of his mansion, in a room stacked to the ceiling with boxes of wigs, and a fellow railroad passenger who has devoted himself to traveling the rail lines of Britain, counting rivets and engine numbers.
There's a tendency on Mr. Bryson's part -- shared by many travel writers -- to focus on the eccentric, the bizarre and the anomalous, and also to make overly broad generalizations about his subject. For the most part, however, he is an entertaining travel companion, curious, whimsical and observant. With this volume, he has succeeded in sending his beloved Britain a charming, if sometimes facile, valentine.

HEADLINE: Economic Growth Shows Signs of Slowing

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 15

 BODY:
Strong production by auto makers gave national industrial output a small nudge upward in July, the Federal Reserve said today, as the economy showed signs of gradually slowing its pace of expansion.
Total output rose one-tenth of 1 percent in July -- its smallest monthly increase in four months -- following a revised jump of six-tenths of 1 percent for June. Businesses operated at 83.2 percent of their capacity last month, down slightly from a revised 83.4 percent for June. 
 Analysts said it showed the economy was still expanding at the start of the second half, but much less vigorously than during the spring and at a rate that should hold off interest-rate increases by Fed policy makers next week.
"It's all consistent with other data that suggest the economy in the second half is demonstrating a pace of growth that is on the subdued side," said Robert Dederick, economic consultant to Northern Trust Company in Chicago.
Another report, by the Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia, gave a clearer indication of a slowdown in manufacturing. The Philadelphia Fed's index of manufacturing activity fell sharply in August and its monthly survey pointed to weaker activity in the second half of 1996.
The Philadelphia Fed said its measure of manufacturing fell to 21.5 in August from 38.6 in July. The index is the percentage of respondents indicating an increase in activity minus the percentage noting a decrease.
All the increase in national industrial production during July came from a surge in output by auto plants. Auto makers depleted their inventories in the second quarter and may be building them up in advance of labor negotiations with the United Automobile Workers union this fall.
Manufacturing output over all registered a three-tenths of 1 percent increase in July after a stronger seven-tenths of 1 percent gain in June.
Output at utilities plunged 1.8 percent following a 1.5 percent drop in June, while production by mining companies was down three-tenths of 1 percent in July after a 1.7 percent rise in June.
Industrial production, after falling five-tenths of 1 percent in March, has risen for four straight months but at a diminishing rate. Output was up eight-tenths of 1 percent in April, five-tenths of 1 percent in May and six-tenths of 1 percent in June before last month's slim gain.
Excluding motor vehicles and parts in July, industrial production fell one-tenth of 1 percent after an increase of five-tenths of 1 percent in June.
Gross domestic product, or G.D.P., which is the broadest measure of total output of goods and services, expanded in the second quarter at a 4.2 percent rate, the strongest growth in two years.
Most analysts expect growth to slow to around 2.5 percent in the second half, more in line with a 2 percent to 2.25 percent rate that the Fed sees as safe long-term growth that will not fuel sharp wage and price rises.
A third report from the Labor Department, showing that weekly jobless claims edged up last week by 5,000, to 321,000, contained more ambiguous information about the economy's potential for generating inflation pressures.
While the weekly figure rose, the closely watched four-week moving average of claims fell to a seven-year low of 313,000, from 324,500 in the preceding week.
"The labor market is still quite strong," said Cynthia Latta, an economist with DRI/McGraw Hill Inc. in Lexington, Mass. "There's certainly no worry of any downturn there."
Nonetheless, Ms. Latta said she did not expect the Fed's policy-making Federal Open Market Committee to raise interest rates at Tuesday's meeting because of other signs that the rate of economic growth is beginning to lose a step.
Mr. Dederick of Northern Trust noted that the jobless claims figures, which are more current than the data used to measure industrial output, implied the possibility that wage pressures continued to bubble below the economy's surface.
"But it's not enough to be consistent with the idea that the Fed has reached the point where it has to rein the economy in" by raising rates, Mr. Dederick said. "Perhaps it should do so, but the evidence isn't there for it yet."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
New Hint of German Rate Cut Leaves Dollar Largely Steady

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The dollar was steady against most leading currencies yesterday, as comments from German central bank officials reinforced perceptions that the bank might soon lower interest rates.
The latest remarks came from Edgar Meister, a member of the Bundesbank's policy council. In a television interview, he said that another small rate cut could help Germany's sluggish economy. 
 The dollar had surged against the mark on Wednesday after Otmar Issing, the Bundesbank's chief economist, also hinted that a rate cut might be in the offing. And the bank's rate-setting council returns from its four-week summer break next Thursday.
"After the Issing and Meister comments, it is certainly starting to look like the Bundesbank might cut rates again," said Stephen Flanagan, currency trader at Credit Agricole in New York, adding that the possibility of lower German rates was supporting the dollar.
In late trading in New York yesterday, the dollar slipped to 1.4854 marks, from 1.4895 marks on Wednesday. The dollar was unchanged at 108.10 Japanese yen. The British pound edged up to $1.5510 from $1.5490.
But trading volume was light because of the Assumption Day holiday, which closed markets in France, Italy and elsewhere in Europe.
A reduction in short-term interest rates in Germany would make bank deposits in dollars more attractive.
"The dollar is looking strong again, and that's one reason why," said Richard Vullo, manager of currency sales at Bayerische Hypotheken-und Wechsel-Bank.
The Bundesbank's rate-cut deliberations may turn on whether the growth of Germany's M-3 money supply slows. The central bank watches the money supply figure -- a measure of cash, short-term time deposits, and most savings deposits -- as a gauge of future inflation. So far this year, it has overshot the bank's 4 to 7 percent target, growing in June at an annual rate of 9.6 percent.
If the Bundesbank decides not to lower rates, "you could see the same thing as last time: another period of mark strength," said Steve Barrow, an economist at Chase Investment Bank in London.

LENGTH: 688 words

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Securities Sag in Price

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities sagged under a combination of manufacturing and labor data yesterday. While there was strength in the numbers, the reports did not indicate that the manufacturing sector was about to race ahead in the third quarter, as some investors fear.
Nevertheless, the bond market gave this batch of mixed data a cold reception. The 30-year bond fell 8/32 , to a price of 9911/32 , pushing its yield up to 6.80 percent, from 6.78 percent on Wednesday. 
 The market managed to cut into some of its early losses after the Philadelphia Federal Reserve released the results of its August business survey, which saw the general business activity index drop to 21.5, compared with 38.6 in July, offsetting the industrial production statistics. The index had been expected to drop to 26.9. The significance of the report is that it is the first reading on the manufacting sector for August.
Industrial production in July rose one-tenth of 1 percent in contrast to an expected decline of one-tenths of 1 percent, while the weekly jobless claims showed a gain of 5,000, to 321,000, for the week ended last Saturday, in line with expectations. But it was the drop in the four-week moving average that drew a negtive reaction from market participants.
Supply has also been a factor weighing on prices, with a $19.25 billion Treasury auction of a new one-year bill today amid heavy issuance of corporate debt competing for investor dollars.
Donald Fine, chief market analyst at Chase Asset Management, said: "The recent slide in the market is primarily the result of an economy that does not appear to be slowing nearly as much as had been hoped. But economic growth, in fact, is moderating, although the extent of that moderation is still unknown.
"Thus, while a Fed tightening seems to be a long way off, the market is still allowing for a less accommodative policy stance before the year is out."
Mr. Fine observed that industrial production during July was not as soft as expected, but, he added, a gain of only one-tenth of 1 percent is not exactly an indication of strength. Further, he said, while the decline in capacity utilization was less than expectations, "at 83.2 percent, capacity utilization is hardly suggestive of any imminent breakout of inflation in the industrial sector."
Of the Philadelphia Fed survey, he noted that general business conditions in that Fed district were still healthy, although activity was off from July. "Of more concern," Mr. Fine said, "perhaps, was the outlook six months forward, which dropped noticeably from the prior month and may be an early sign of a worsening business psychology."
Analysts note that technical factors, or the use of price movements as indictors of future price patterns, have played a key role in Treasury trading over the last few days, and participants have waited for further signs of economic weakness. Traders believe that for the market to move higher and for the yield on the long bond to make a move toward 6.50 percent, economic data of pronounced weakness and duration will be required.
Yesterday's one-year bill auction had little market impact, traders said, since the size of the issue has not changed for the last four auctions and little of it is new cash.
The average rate at the auction was 5.36 percent, about as expected, down from 5.49 percent last month. The bid-to-cover ratio -- the total amount bid against the size of the auction -- was at 2.52 to 1, and noncompetitive bids somewhat below average at $902 million.

HEADLINE: Steven D. Gold Is Dead at 52; Expert on Government Financing

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
Steven D. Gold, an authority on state and local government financing, died on Wednesday night at George Washington University Hospital Center in Washington. He was 52 and lived in Chevy Chase, Md.
The cause was cancer, his family said. 
 Mr. Gold, an economist, joined the Urban Institute in Washington eight months ago as co-director of a multimillion dollar project dealing with changes in health services and social programs as the Federal Government shifts responsibility for these programs increasingly to the states.
Before going to the institute as a senior fellow, Mr. Gold served for six years as director of the Center for the Study of the States at the State University of New York in Albany, where he was also a professor of public administration and policy.
As director of the center, he earned a reputation for expertise on state and local taxes, budget deficits and financing. He advocated against balancing the Federal budget at the expense of programs important to the states.
In this vein, he had criticized the balanced-budget amendment that Congress considered last year.
"Republicans are right that giving states more flexibility can reduce some costs," Mr. Gold wrote, "but exaggerate when they say states could save enough to absorb all the Federal cuts without slashing services."
Mr. Gold was born in 1944 in Philadelphia, and received a bachelor's degree from Bucknell University in 1966, and a master's degree and doctorate in economics from the University of Michigan, the latter in 1972. He had taught at Grinnell College and Drake University, and in 1981 became a senior fellow of the National Conference of State Legislatures. From 1985 to 1990, he was director of the conference's fiscal studies.
Mr. Gold wrote or edited 17 books on state and local finances, the last being "The Fiscal Crisis of the States"(Georgetown University Press), published last year. He wrote dozens of articles on his specialty.
Mr. Gold is survived by his wife of 28 years, the former JoAnn Levine, a sister, Linda Gold of Seattle, and a brother, Richard, of Seattle.

HEADLINE: Stocks Mixed in a Quiet Day, With the Dow Down by 1.10

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
Stocks ended mixed in one of the quietest sessions of the year yesterday, enlivened only by a small, late rush of buying ahead of today's "double witching" expiration of stock options and index options.
"It's one of those hurry up and wait days," said Michael Metz, Oppenheimer & Company's chief investment strategist."There's no incentive to get aggressive in either direction." 
 The Dow Jones industrial average fell 1.10 points, to 5,665.78. But broader market gauges rose, and advancing issues led decliners, 1,293 to 1,048, on light volume of 325.2 million shares on the New York Stock Exchange. It was the seventh-slowest full session so far this year, the exchange said.
The Nasdaq composite index added 1.18 points, to 1,134.69.
Blue-chip issues were lower much of the session but blipped upward on late buying tied to today's expiration of options.
Stocks were hampered by weakness in bonds, where long-term rates rose to 6.80 percent, from 6.78 percent on Wednesday, after a mixed bag of economic reports. Industrial production rose one-tenth of 1 percent in July, the Federal Reserve reported, in contrast to the one-tenth of 1 percent decline that had been expected on Wall Street.
A separate report from the Labor Department showed that while jobless claims rose 5,000, to 321,000 last week, the closely watched four-week moving average of claims fell to a seven-year low, pointing to strength in the labor market that could put upward pressure on wages.
Analysts said the reports should help convince Fed policy makers not to raise interest rates at their meeting on Tuesday.
"The data were sufficiently mixed," Mr. Metz said. "They didn't disturb the mind-set that there was some moderation of economic expansion."
Drug stocks rose despite the weakness in other blue chips.
Merck rose 3/4, to 69 1/8; Eli Lilly edged up 3/8, to 58 1/2, and American Home Products added 3/8, to 58. Officials at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, the National Foundation for Infectious Diseases and other health groups said Merck's chicken pox vaccine should be given to all adolescents not yet exposed.
Among individual issues, Orchard Supply Hardware Stores surged 5, to 34 3/4, after it agreed to be acquired by Sears, Roebuck for $35 a share, or $415 million. Sears fell 1/4, to 44 5/8.
Hewlett-Packard slipped 1/8, to 43 3/8, but fell 3 1/2 in after-hours trading after reporting a 26 percent drop in third-quarter earnings, reflecting a slowdown in new orders and a charge to exit the disk drive manufacturing business.
The company said it earned $425 million, or 40 cents a share -- below analysts' estimates of 48 cents a share. Hewlett, whose warnings about earnings had been a key factor in the market's July tailspin, also said its near-term outlook was uncertain, particularly overseas.
But Bill Meehan, a Prudential Securities market analyst, did not see Hewlett's news sparking a broad tech selloff today. "I don't see a spillover tomorrow or a rampage to the downside," he said.
Protein Design stumbled 33 percent, or 7 5/8 points, to 15 1/2, after news that trials of its Protovir antibody for treating inflammation of the retina in AIDS patients was halted due to lack of effectiveness.
The Big Board composite index of all listed common stocks rose 0.58 points, to 354.22. The average price per share added 6 cents.
The American Stock Exchange index gained 2.19 points, to 552.53.
The Wilshire Associates Equity Index -- the market value of Big Board, American and Nasdaq issues -- was 6,482.397, up 12.470 points, or 0.19 percent.

HEADLINE: Reporter's Notebook;
So Beautiful, So Relaxing, So Far From San Diego

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM 

DATELINE: JACKSON, Wyo., Aug. 15

 BODY:
Here in the crystalline splendors of the Tetons, President Clinton has played many roles on his vacation this week: golfer, hiker, horseback rider, armchair astronomer. But none has he played with more apparent relish or conviction than that of studied ignorer of the Republican National Convention.
The President's aides insist that, to their knowledge, he has watched not so much as a minute of the televised proceedings from San Diego (though they have, of course). And whenever Mr. Clinton is asked about it in public, he responds with a nonchalance bordering on narcolepsy. 
 "I'm going to leave them alone and let them have their convention," he told reporters on Wednesday, as he and his daughter, Chelsea, rode horses at the 800-acre ranch where they are staying. Asked his reaction to Bob Dole's choice of Jack Kemp, he allowed: "I like Al Gore."
To be sure, the President has had plenty of diversions. On Monday, he did not get home until nearly 10 P.M. after a long day and an 8 1/2-mile hike in Yellowstone National Park, and simply "soaked my weary bones." On Tuesday, he played golf until dusk and watched a movie. Tonight, he is to attend a party for local glitterati like the actor Harrison Ford at the home of James D. Wolfensohn, president of the World Bank.
But surely Mr. Clinton, a self-confessed channel surfer, has sneaked just an itsy-bitsy, teensy-weensy peek at the Republicans from time to time.
"He has not watched any of the convention," said the traveling White House spokeswoman, Mary Ellen Glynn. "I can't tell you whether he's caught some of the news clips or not. He may have."
Then again, Mr. Clinton may not have to watch the convention, because Douglas Sosnik, the White House political director, is here to watch it for him, in a dumpy downtown motel. Mr. Sosnik gives his boss morning-after briefings.
"Every time I see him, I ask him, because I know the press is going to ask," Mr. Sosnik said. "And he says, 'Gimme a break! I'm not going to watch that.' "

In the Rough, on the Greens
If Mr. Clinton has been close-mouthed about the Republicans this week, he has been chatty enough about nearly everything else, from his weight (15 to 20 pounds less than a year or so ago, he says) to his fitness (he admitted to "a little heavy breathing" during his hike with his wife, Hillary Rodham Clinton, 2,220 feet down Mt. Washburn in Yellowstone).
In Yellowstone, the President marveled at the wonders of nature ("You can feel the heat coming up!" he said of a hot spring) and the leavings of nature ("We saw some bear scat.") He gave tips on hiking at altitude, warning reporters to take it easy at first, but adding: "You could stay here a week or 10 days, and you wouldn't even feel it."
In fact, Mr. Clinton told reporters on Wednesday, he might have pushed himself a bit too hard on Monday in his ramble through the land of grizzlies, pine and cow parsnips in Yellowstone.
"When I took you off on that wild goose chase, I didn't know how demanding it was," said Mr. Clinton, who chose the 8 1/2-mile hike over an easier, three-mile alternative down a road, offered by the Park Service. "I was very sore yesterday, I was very sore. I found out my rhythm wasn't quite there on the golf course. Oooooh, that was bad."

Everything He Needs
 In all, Mr. Clinton has kept a much slower pace, and much lower public profile, in his eight-day visit than he did in his 17-day sojourn here last summer. He himself said that on Wednesday, he was "sort of a derelict -- I thought I would sleep in and kind of laze around."
Part of the reason for the President's low profile is that he need not ever leave the 4,000-square-foot log home where he is staying as the guest of Max Chapman Jr., the former head of the American branch of Nomura Securities, the Japanese investment giant. Mr. Chapman's spread, along the Snake River north of town, has almost every conceivable amenity.
There are horses and trails, fishing in the river, a squash court, a gym and a private observatory. Mr. Clinton and Chelsea wanted to stay up to watch a midnight meteor shower on Monday, but the President pooped out too early, aides said.
Mr. Chapman's spread, the Bar B Bar Ranch, is apparently impressive even by the standards of Jackson, where log mansions have popped up like mushrooms in recent years, and where some of America's oldest and richest families have vacationed for generations. "Have you seen the house?" Senator John D. Rockefeller 4th, Democrat of West Virginia, who lent his own impressive home adjoining the Jackson Hole Golf and Tennis Club to the President last summer, asked reporters the other day. When the reporters told him they had not, the Senator's face lit up: "Neither have I," he said, "but I hear it's spectacular."

HEADLINE: Tourist-Hungry Hartford Revives Spirit of Twain;
Banking on the Appeal of an Adopted Son

BYLINE: By JONATHAN RABINOVITZ 

DATELINE: HARTFORD, Aug. 15

 BODY:
Mark Twain was born in the small, backwater town of Florida, Mo., grew up in nearby Hannibal, and achieved fame writing about life on the Mississippi River. A world traveler, lecturing from London to Sydney, he insisted that he be buried in Elmira, N.Y., where he and his wife, Olivia, spent many summers.
Yet, the way people here tell it, Hartford is the place he really called home. 
 "He left Hannibal as soon as he could get out of there," said Wilson Faude, a former curator of the Mark Twain House, the 19-room Victorian mansion where Samuel L. Clemens, better known as Mark Twain, lived for 17 of his 74 years.
"The Mississippi is a brown, mosquito-ridden river," Mr. Faude said. "Hartford is the green end of the road for him. I don't care what he did everywhere else. I know that under the shelter of these trees, American literature was transformed."
It was during that period, from 1874 to 1891, that Twain wrote "The Adventures of Tom Sawyer," "The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn" and "A Connecticut Yankee in King Arthur's Court."
Although some might quarrel with Hartford's claim to Twain's affections, the issue is not just a matter of academic debate or civic pride. What is at stake here is money. Over the last few years, this city has hit hard times, and Mark Twain has emerged as a ticket to revival.
This weekend, the city will be host to Mark Twain Days, a three-day hoopla organized by the Mark Twain House, with free performances by Arlo Guthrie, Richie Havens and the Smothers Brothers; a raft race down the Connecticut River; a Tom Sawyer and Becky Thatcher look-alike contest, and a jousting tournament, among other activities. The hope is that thousands of suburbanites who have steered clear of Hartford will be drawn into the city.
It comes as civic leaders have done their best to promote a Twain frenzy. Banners bearing the writer's mustachioed face adorn the streets. A local brew pub has a new offering, Samuel Clemens Extra Pale Ale. And the city and state have imported a play about the author's life, "Mark Twain: The Musical" from Elmira, converting the state armory into an air-conditioned 1,300-seat theater. The play will run through August.
Indeed, Twain seems to be popping up all over town. Last month, the State Bond Commission approved $1.5 million to build a visitors' center and make repairs at the author's mansion here. At that meeting, a Twain impersonator interrupted Gov. John G. Rowland's speech on the importance of tourism and called for the vote. "Isn't it about time for the ayes?" the actor, Ken Richters, drawled, explaining that he needed the money to fix up his house.
Hartford is certainly not the first to try to cash in on the writer. His books have been translated into 72 languages and have inspired more than 100 movies, not to mention a Tom Sawyer television series, Mark Twain riverboat rides at Disney theme parks and a Mark Twain guest character on "Star Trek: The Next Generation." Ernest Hemingway described "The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn" as the origin of "all modern American literature."
In Japan, there are Tom Sawyer clubs and Tom Sawyer camps where children are sent for rustic outings. For 68 years, Angels Camp, Calif., has held its Calaveras County Fair and Jumping Frog Jubilee, inspired by Twain's short story "The Celebrated Jumping Frog of Calaveras County," with this May's event drawing 37,000 people.
In Elmira, where visitors can see Twain's grave and the study from the summer home where he wrote, receptionists at the Chamber of Commerce answer the (800) MARK TWAIN telephone line with the greeting, "Hello, Mark Twain country."
But they are a little prickly when Twain's ties to Elmira are challenged. "The largest portions of his books were written here," insisted Nancy Keefer, executive vice president of the Chemung County Chamber of Commerce, noting that Twain's six-week summer vacations provided relief from the business stress and social obligations of Hartford.
The loss of the Twain musical has hurt tourism in Elmira, but Ms. Keefer said the town's position in Twain lore was secure -- he is buried there. "Everyone can claim him, but we still have him," she said.
And Hannibal, undoubtedly the champion of Mark Twain kitsch, is clearly not concerned about Hartford.
Tourism is estimated to bring 400,000 people to Hannibal each year, and with a Twain museum and some historic sites, there is the Tom 'n Huck Motel, the Becky Thatcher Book and Gift Shop, the Mark Twain Dinette and a car dealership, Mark Twain Jeep Eagle. Visitors can buy Mark Twain mugs, Mark Twain shot glasses, Huckleberry Finn straw hats and pens with figurines of Tom and Becky floating inside.
The high point of the year in Hannibal is National Tom Sawyer Days, the week of July 4, complete with a Tom and Becky look-alike contest, mud volleyball, a watermelon-seed-spitting contest and a fence-painting competition.
Told of Hartford's event, Mayor Richard B. Schwartz of Hannibal expressed disappointment that Hannibal's latest reigning Tom and Becky were not invited to offer their official imprimatur. But he wished Hartford well.
Whatever Hartford's ambitions, it will take work to get people to think of the city as a Twain landmark.
A survey of a dozen patrons at the New York Public Library found that five thought Twain lived in New York City when "Huckleberry Finn" and "Tom Sawyer" were published, two said Missouri, two said the South, one said "Philly" and one answered simply "not in Brooklyn." Only a librarian knew it was Hartford.
Long known as the insurance city, Hartford, with its Puritan roots, might seem an unlikely place for Twain to have called home. The often profane author, who practically chain-smoked cigars and enjoyed his Scotch whisky, was not always patient with his fellow citizens, referring to the church he attended, which drew many insurance executives, as "The Church of the Holy Speculators."
But Twain, whose publisher was here, clearly fell in love with the place. Flush with insurance money and a center of manufacturing and the subscription book industry, Hartford was said to be the nation's wealthiest city, and it had its own genteel literary and artistic circle. Twain's next-door neighbor was Harriet Beecher Stowe, the author of "Uncle Tom's Cabin."
Although Twain gushed about other places -- he called the Chemung Valley, where Elmira sits, a "foretaste of heaven" and described San Francisco as "the friendliest land and the livest, heartiest community on our continent" -- he saved his most purple prose for Hartford.
"Of all the beautiful towns it has been my fortune to see, this is the chief," Twain wrote upon his first visit in 1868. "Everywhere the eye turns it is blessed with visions of refreshing green. You do not know what beauty is if you have not been here."
It was here that Twain raised his three daughters before leaving the city in 1891 because of financial troubles.
"Hartford was really home after he left Hannibal," said Justin Kaplan, who wrote the Pulitzer Prize-winning "Mr. Clemens and Mark Twain: A Biography" (Touchstone: 1966). "When he moved to Hartford he did not want to be known as the cigar-smoking, poker-playing Mark Twain. He wanted to become part of a genteel literary and social circle. He became determined to be a respectable family man."
Asked whether Twain succeeded, Mr. Kaplan said, "No, but he gave it a good try."
Despite this history, city leaders had ignored Twain's potential as a lure for tourists. The idea of exploiting Twain's links to Hartford came largely from Lary Bloom, the editor of The Hartford Courant's Sunday magazine.
Aware of Hartford's troubled economy, Mr. Bloom made it his mission to educate his readers about Hartford's past, and touted "cultural heritage tourism," a growing segment of the tourism industry, as the road to revitalization. During the last two years, he published a series, Twain's World, highlighting historical landmarks, and he was part of the initial discussions behind Mark Twain Days.
In the May 7, 1995, introduction to the series, Mr. Bloom wrote about Hartford as "the most underappreciated city in America," dubbing it "the passthrough city in the passthrough state."
Mr. Bloom said he had recently visited Prince Edward Island, Canada, where thousands go to visit the birthplace of Anne Shirley, the heroine of "Anne of Green Gables," the novel by Lucy Maude Montgomery.
"Is there a hook for Hartford that would also serve as a hook for Connecticut?" he said. "Surely there is -- a face even more famous, if less adorable than Anne's, with a cigar dangling from its mouth."
The linchpin of this dream was the Farmington Avenue house, which was used for coal storage in the 1920's and converted to apartments and a public library before it was restored to its original form and reopened as a museum in 1974. Last year, it attracted about 50,000 people.
The home is a striking dark brick mix of Gothic and gingerbread, with three turrets, five balconies, an elaborate veranda and porte-cochere. Mr. Kaplan described it as "part steamboat, part medieval stronghold and part cuckoo clock."
The interior is even more elaborate -- hand-stenciled walls and wall papers by Louis Comfort Tiffany and other designers. From the entrance hall to the third-floor billiard room, it is a fabulous display of the decorative arts -- carved wood panels from India, elegant brass and cloisonne enamel lighting fixtures and other period furnishing.
"This house captures all of Twain's exuberance, his taste for the world and his passion for things modern," said John Boyer, the house's executive director. "This town now realizes what it's got. People have found religion."
And the boosterism has taken in some grand claims.
Mr. Faude, the former curator, contended that Twain came up with the name Huckleberry when staring out the window of his Hartford home and seeing the bushes. And he even maintains that the writer's descriptions of the Mississippi River were inspired by the "glittering, gleaming" water of the Connecticut River.
Some writers might take offense at such hype, but Twain likely would not have.
A frustrated businessman who was always in search of ways to make millions, Twain sold his likeness and pen name for use on cigar boxes, whisky labels, insurance promotions and his own line of scrapbooks and vest straps.
"He would love this," Mr. Boyer said. "He was the arch-propagandist who made up his name and created this persona. The only thing that troubles me are the words I hear him whispering late at night: 'Where's my cut?' "

HEADLINE: Burundi's Leader Plans to Rule at Least 3 Years

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: BUJUMBURA, Burundi, Aug. 15

 BODY:
Defying international pressure for a return to civilian rule, Burundi's new military leader says the Government plans to remain in power for three years.
"We think a period of three years will be enough to achieve the program we have set ourselves," the leader, Pierre Buyoya, a retired major who took power in a coup on July 25, said in a broadcast on Wednesday night. 
 In his address, Mr. Buyoya urged Burundians to support his plans for a three-year transitional government "at this serious point in our history."
He said he planned to include legislators from the previous National Assembly in a proposed parliament. But he gave no further details. He has previously said that a transitional parliament "would include representatives from all walks of society."
Besides the powers held by the previous assembly, the new parliament "will also play a determining role in the national debate and the attempts at national reconciliation," he added, without elaborating.
He also repeated his earlier pledge to rein in the military, saying, "We are to reinforce discipline, strictness and professional ethics among all the forces charged with maintaining law and order."
The Tutsi-dominated military has been accused of killing Hutu civilians in retaliation for attacks by Hutu rebels. The Hutu guerrillas have also been blamed for killing Tutsi civilians, especially those living in camps after the fighting drove them from their homes.
Eighty-four percent of Burundi's people are Hutu, 14 percent are Tutsi and the rest are Twa. But the Tutsi have traditionally controlled the military and much of the economy.
Mr. Buyoya has defended seizing power, saying he can stop the violence that has killed more than 500,000 people since the 1993 assassination of the country's first Hutu leader, Melchior Ndadaye, in a failed military coup. President Sylvestre Ntibantungaya, the Hutu leader ousted in last month's coup, remains at the residence of the United States Ambassador, Morris Hughes.
Mr. Buyoya spoke only hours after the state radio reported food prices and transport fares were rising because of economic sanctions imposed by Burundi's neighbors.
Borders with Zaire, Rwanda and Tanzania have been closed. Zambia has said it will be vigilant in enforcing the sanctions and has barred Burundi from using its ports on Lake Tanganyika.

HEADLINE: A Last Blast Of the Whistle Coming Soon

BYLINE: By DIRK JOHNSON 

DATELINE: BOISE, Idaho Aug. 14

 BODY:
This city was so charmed by its old train depot, and so enchanted by the mystique of locomotive travel, that it mounted a $1.5 million campaign to buy the station.
The donations poured in, with corporate bigwigs and working-class Joes and Janes helping the city buy the depot from a private company last month. 
 As it turns out, people here would do anything at all for the train, except ride it.
With ridership declining, Amtrak has announced it is cutting train travel to Boise, one of 42 cities that will lose service, including Dallas, Las Vegas and Little Rock.
"I'm sorry to see it go," said Dan Neighbor, 45, who had donated $150 for the depot purchase, but said, "I've got to admit, I never rode it."
Amtrak is restoring the Broadway Limited, between New York and Chicago, and adding a third daily train between New York and Miami. But the train travel in the West is being cut sharply, with more than 3,000 passenger miles being discontinued.
The latest cuts were deemed necessary after Congress earmarked $200 million for Amtrak, some $50 million less than it had requested.
Many of the cuts, which take effect Nov. 10, will be on routes where service had been scaled back a year ago. The Pioneer, for example, which stops in Boise on its runs between Seattle and Denver, and then on to Chicago, had gone from daily service in each direction, to just three days a week. Amtrak had hoped, vainly it turns out, that reducing the frequency of train runs could improve efficiency and save some endangered routes.
"It worked for a while," said Marc Magliari, a spokesman for Amtrak. "But ultimately, people are not willing to shift their demand to your supply. If you don't do it daily, you might as well just not do it at all."
He noted that some cities on struggling routes, like Boise, had made "Herculean efforts" to save train service, "which made these unfortunate choices all the more difficult."
Three of the lines to be discontinued -- Los Angeles to Salt Lake City; St. Louis to San Antonio; Denver to Seattle -- were losing a total of about $60 million, Mr. Magliari said.
In Boise, where the Union Pacific began rail service in 1887, ridership lately had dropped sharply in the last 12 months, to 4,666, from 6,258.
Some people here blamed Amtrak's problems in Boise, in part, on odd service hours. The train to Seattle leaves here at 4:24 A.M.; the train to Denver leaves at 11:26 P.M.
"Those hours were simply unmarketable," said Suzanne Burton, a spokeswoman for the city.
More than anything else, the lower ridership is a matter of competition: trains are slower than airplanes, and generally just as expensive.
"If you're in a hurry, the train is just not an option," said Mr. Neighbor, a carpentry contractor. "And in this society, we're pretty much always in a hurry."
For Boise, the Amtrak announcement was certainly no reflection on the city's fortunes, or its future. From its perch in the foothills of the Sawtooth Mountains, this city, the capital of Idaho, has been one of the hot spots of the American West for several years, a place for high technology, and fly-fishing.
"We haven't done any marketing for the past four years," Shirl Boyce, the manager of the Boise Area Ecomomic Development Council. "We've had so much coming in, we haven't been able to handle it."
The population of the Boise area has grown to about 365,000, from about 275,000 a decade ago. It has been an astonishing turnabout from the 1980's, bleak times here for an economy then dominated by agriculture, mining and timber.
"You could have shot a howitzer through a street downtown and not hit anything," Mr. Boyce said. "We were doing each other's laundry."
Today, the economy has greatly diversified, particular with growth in the computer field. Micron Technology, for example, employs about 10,000 workers in the Boise area.
Boise already has plenty of uses for the old railroad depot, which has arched windows, a soaring belltower and a great hall with high ceilings and painted beams. A real estate developer is leasing much of the depot for office space. The hall will be rented out for private affairs, like wedding receptions, said Ms. Burton, the city spokeswoman.
By and large, people took the news of the train's demise as a foregone conclusion. "All of us drive around in our cars, and then we say we ought to keep the trains," said Roy Ellsworth, a 64-year-old physician, as he sat inside his four-wheel-drive vehicle. "We're hypocrites."
For all the complaints about subsidies for trains, he added, few talk about subsidies for automobiles.
"What, for example, is the highway patrol, if not a huge subsidy to the highway system?" he asked.
His wife, Frances Ellsworth, 47, said she was not surprised that the train's days were numbered, but added, "I'm sure going to miss the sound of the whistle."
There was a touch of melancholy in the voices of some, who recalled the station for its joyful homecomings and tearful farewells, the place where families waved to scared young troops going off to war.
Pablo Pacania, a 90-year-old retired Air Force veteran, recalled riding the train from California to Boise in 1951. "I remember waking up and looking out the window," he said, "and seeing my wife, the first thing I saw, my wife."
Mr. Pacania lives in a modest house next to the station. "People always ask me, 'What about the noise? What about the noise?' " he said. "And I tell them, 'It does not bother me. I like the train.' "
Then he took off the broad cowboy hat and waved it, wistfully.
"I will miss the train, yes," he said. "People were always standing there, waving. So many families, waiting, waiting. Now -- all gone. I will miss the train."

HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS;
Hewlett Stock Tumbles as Earnings Fall Despite Alert

BYLINE: By JOHN MARKOFF 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 15

 BODY:
The Hewlett-Packard Company, confirming an earlier warning of bad financial news, reported a 26 percent decline in its fiscal third-quarter earnings today.
The company, whose warning of a growth slowdown early last month had helped send technology stocks plummeting, reported profits of 40 cents a share -- well below the 49 cents a share that had been predicted in the latest survey of analysts by Zacks Investment Research. 
 Shares of the company's stock plunged $3.50, to $40, today. But analysts were unwilling to predict whether the selloff would affect other technology stocks on Friday, in part because another computer company, Cisco Systems Inc., reported better-than-expected profits today after the stock market closed.
As Hewlett-Packard had warned last month, its earnings were reduced by a pre-tax charge of $135 million, or about 13 cents a share, to cover the company's withdrawal from the computer disk-drive manufacturing business and to account for losses in that business.
Without that charge the company would have met Wall Street's earnings estimate, Hewlett-Packard's chief financial officer, Robert Wayman, said.
But David Wu, an analyst at the Chicago Corporation, said, "It really didn't matter whether they met expectations. This wasn't a good quarter for H.-P."
The earnings for the quarter totaled $425 million, compared with $576 million, or 55 cents a share, in the comparable quarter a year earlier. Revenue rose 17.7 percent, to $9.11 billion from $7.74 billion.
The most recent quarter, which ended on July 31, put an abrupt end to the rocketing earnings growth that the electronics manufacturer, which is based in Palo Alto, Calif., had enjoyed in recent years; earnings increases of 20 percent were not uncommon. But now the company's executives are expressing concern about the uncertain business climate Hewlett-Packard is facing in diverse markets including personal computers, work stations, peripherals, test equipment and components.
For the quarter, Hewlett-Packard said orders were up 8 percent, well below the 24 percent rise reported in the second quarter of this year and the 34 percent gain in the third quarter of the 1995 fiscal year.
In the third quarter, orders in the United States grew 4 percent, to $3.9 billion, while orders from outside the United States increased 11 percent, to $4.8 billion.
Company officials cited transitions to new products and a general economic slowdown in major markets for some of the slowdown. They also said that the company's fiscal third quarter had traditionally been slow and that last year's period had been unusually strong for the company.
"Our PC growth continues at or above the industry growth rate," Mr. Wayman said. "But it is slower than when we were rapidly gaining market share."
Mr. Wu, the analyst, said he was concerned that the company's growth appeared to be weak in both the United States and Asia. "And when the computer business goes to single-digit growth, that's ominous," he said.
Cisco Systems, the leader in equipment and software used for controlling the flow of information in corporate computer networks, said that its fiscal fourth-quarter earnings rose 85.7 percent, to $266.8 million, or 45 cents a share. Analysts surveyed by Zacks had been expecting earnings of 40 cents a share.
Revenue in the quarter, which ended on July 28, soared 176.3 percent, to $1.72 billion, from $621.2 million a year earlier.
The results do not include earnings and revenue from the Stratacom Corporation, a networking vendor that Cisco bought last month, and $15.5 million in pretax expenses for the acquisition. With those results, Cisco had earnings of $276.6 million, or 41 cents a share.
Cisco reported its earnings after the Nasdaq market closed; its shares had ended the day's regular trading session up $1.125 at $57.75, in anticipation of good news. Trading in the stock, at volume of 9.9 million shares, was the third most active in United States markets. Cisco shares rose 37.5 cents, to $58.125, in after-hours trading.
