HEADLINE: Streetscapes/Hayden Planetarium;
A Remnant of the 1930's, and Its Sky, Will Fall

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER GRAY 

 BODY:
THE Landmarks Preservation Commission has twice designated as a landmark the 1935 Hayden Planetarium on West 81st Street. But the American Museum of Natural History is moving ahead with plans to demolish its mild, moderne structure -- with the landmarks commission's blessing, but amid dismay and suspicion by some preservation groups.
The American Museum of Natural History opened its first building in 1877, one unit in what was planned as a giant, gridded complex of 12 buildings enclosing four courtyards running from 77th to 81st Streets, between Central Park West and Columbus Avenue. Although the style changed, the museum announced at least three more times -- the 1890's, the 1920's and the 1970's -- that it would complete the original plan. 
 But by 1934 the scale of the undertaking and the Depression left the museum not even half complete. The Hayden Planetarium is the only structure built since that time.
In the 1920's the museum planned a five-story astronomical hall at the exact center of the projected complex. Its crowning ornament was to be a planetarium, a domed auditorium where special projectors could display the night skies. But the project stalled, in part because of money.
The modern projection planetarium was developed after World War I by Walter Bauersfeld, an engineer for the Carl Zeiss Optical Works. A craze for planetariums followed, and the first Zeiss-type planetarium in America was the dramatic Adler in Chicago, built in 1930.
In 1933 the American Museum of Natural History established the Planetarium Authority; its state charter allowed it to receive $650,000 in Federal funds from the Reconstruction Finance Authority. Charles Hayden, described by Time magazine as a "dapper bachelor banker," gave $150,000 for the optics.
The revived planetarium project was shifted to one of the four projected courtyards of the complex. The architects Trowbridge & Livingston designed a severe brick rectangle with Art Moderne grillwork and doors, accented by floodlighting.
Even for the 1930's and even for a completely new building type, the Hayden is a puzzling structure, strangely disconnected from the rest of the museum and not much to look at.
Research by Higgins & Quasebarth, a preservation firm and consultant to the museum, indicates that the planetarium was expressly designed to be enveloped by the future museum complex and was thus, nominally, a temporary design.
BUT it was good enough to fool the writers of the 1939 "W.P.A. Guide to New York City," who described it as "among the most interesting examples of modern functional architecture."
There was no other architectural criticism of the Hayden Planetarium, but its show of 9,000 stars of the Northern and Southern Hemispheres drew rave reviews and millions of visitors, as did its first-floor orrery, with moving models of the planets out to the orbit of Saturn.
Now the American Museum of Natural History believes that the Hayden Planetarium is out of date and wants to replace it by the year 2000.
Dr. Neil Tyson, the director, says that since 1935, the field of astronomy has profoundly changed. For instance, constellations were once a major part of astronomy texts but are now barely noticed.
Dr. Tyson foresees a sophisticated center where a computerized projector can display not just the stars as seen from the Earth, but black holes and other phenomena. The architects Polshek and Partners and the exhibit designer Ralph Appelbaum Associates have developed futuristic plans for a huge transparent cube containing a spherical planetarium inside and planetary models suspended in midair.
Another aspect of the design is a three-level parking garage next door -- lines of cars often back up into 81st Street waiting for spaces to open up in the museum's lot.
In 1967 the Landmarks Preservation Commission designated the museum complex -- including the Hayden Planetarium -- as a landmark, and it was also included in the 1990 Central Park West Historic District. But last fall the commission reported favorably on the proposed demolition of the Hayden Planetarium, noting that the 1935 structure had received short shrift in previous designation reports. The Municipal Art Society and the New York Landmarks Conservancy also supported the demolition.
But other groups continue to oppose the destruction of the Planetarium and believe the museum has received a kind of preferential treatment for which private owners would not even hope.
The Historic Districts Council pointed out that the commission specifically protected the Hayden Planetarium in its earlier actions, even though it did exclude other museum structures. The council has suggested building the new planetarium on the open parking lot next door, reusing the Hayden and encouraging the use of mass transit.
Both groups, along with local preservationists like Samuel Leff, who lives on West 79th Street, suspect that the American Museum of Natural History is getting the same treatment the Metropolitan Museum of Art received 25 years ago, when its massive building campaign severely altered several landmark facades.
But although other permits are pending, most dissenters think the landmarks commission was the biggest hurdle. John Krawchuk, a spokesman for Landmark West!, a local preservation group, said that the Polshek plan is "a good, solid design" but that the adaptive reuse of the Hayden Planetarium is now a lost opportunity.
"Because of its humility, it bespeaks of an era of economy, and our landmarks need to tell the whole story of New York City," he said. "We feel it is a dangerous precedent."
However, Deborah Sack, a spokeswoman for the landmarks commission, said the commission found that the Hayden "is not a distinguished example of planetarium architecture." She said the commission had allowed the demolition of other individual structures within landmark complexes, like the Central Park Zoo.

GRAPHIC: Photos: The Hayden Planetarium (under construction in 1934 at left) is to be demolished with the approval of the landmarks commission. (Frances Roberts for The New York Times) (American Museum of Natural History)

SECTION: Section 9; Page 9; Column 1; Real Estate Desk

HEADLINE: Commercial Property/Physicians' Offices;
For Doctors, Togetherness Is the New Way of Life

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA 

 BODY:
DR. MICHAEL KRAMER is an internist and cardiologist who practices on the Upper East Side on Manhattan. But lately he has been spending as much time managing his Manhattan Primary Care medical group and physicians' network as he does with patients.
In the managed-care environment of the 1990's, solo practices are rapidly diminishing. Doctors who have treasured their ground-floor offices on Park and Fifth Avenues are moving out and joining with others in larger spaces to reduce their overhead. 
 "Group practices and networks will be the dominant form within three years," Dr. Kramer said. "Doctors' profit margins are shrinking, and the managed-care systems are using incentives to group people together. The other problem is that there are far too many doctors in this town."
He said there are eight doctors employed by the medical group, which has offices at 90th Street and Madison Avenue and at Central Part West and 83d Street. The network has 120 doctors in a loose alliance that allows them to practice under their own name and does not guarantee them a level of income.
Many who have been watching the changes in the medical business and its real estate consequences say they were overdue. "Doctor and the medical community are now experiencing what corporate America has already gone through," said Josh N. Kuriloff, a senior director of Cushman & Wakefield. "They are downsizing and re-engineering their practices to lower their overhead."
"New York is 10 to 15 years behind what happened on the West Coast," said Debra C. Weissman, a practice management consultant based in White Plains. The reason, she said, is that New Yorkers had a greater choice of doctors and hospitals and strongly preferred staying with their favorites until cost pressures became intolerable for employers. "The doctors here looked up one day and all of a sudden they were inundated by managed care," Ms. Weissman said.
With managed care, people covered by corporate health insurance plans are directed to doctors who have agreed to a fee schedule that is less than many had been charging. This put many doctors, particularly those involved in primary care, in a squeeze. Lower fees meant less income for the same amount of work, but those who tried to stay independent risked facing empty waiting rooms.
"Patients were loyal to their doctors, but the companies they worked for joined plans that limited choice," said Paul Wexler, a broker with Douglas Elliman's professional leasing and sales operation. "If the doctors don't join they are not going to have enough business, and if they waited too long they might have trouble getting aboard."
"One of the ways doctors are adapting," said Michael Dubin of Brown Harris Stevens, "is using real estate to achieve economies of scale. If five doctors get together, obviously you do not need five waiting rooms, five receptionists or five X-ray machines. All an individual doctor needs is a consulting room and two examining rooms."
Some established physicians tried to hang on to their prestigious addresses in the face of falling incomes and rising rents by doubling or tripling up. "Just a few years ago it was one doctor to one office," Mr. Wexler said. "Now you have two and three people in the same office."
One doctor giving up his Park Avenue office is Michael C. Bruno, who is also chairman of the department of medicine at Lenox Hill Hospital. "My old office is beautiful and I love it, but it is going to be sold," Dr. Bruno said. The three-doctor office is at 535 Park Avenue.
Instead, he will move in with 37 other physicians as managing director of the Madison Medical Group. The group is leasing 60,000 square feet on three floors at 110 East 59th Street, between Park and Lexington Avenues. The new facility will be equipped with X-ray and other diagnostic facilities and a testing laboratory.
He said he feels fortunate to have found the space. "Not a lot of real estate operators want a lot of doctors in their buildings," he said.
DOCTORS' offices need a lot more plumbing and generate more garbage than a standard business office, which makes them costly to equip and operate, and they tend to be open at nonstandard hours, like evenings and weekends. There is also the fact that they bring sick people into a building.
"You can build out beautiful space in an office building for $30 to $40 a square foot," said Mr. Dubin, who specializes in medical space. "A medical office will cost from $75 to $125 a square foot, so owners are going to want a long-term commitment."
One of the ironies of the current situation, real estate executives say, is that many of the offices being given up by primary-care doctors are being leased and purchased by plastic surgeons. "It makes sense, because they are not being paid by insurance companies," said Dr. Harry W. Kent, who stopped practicing as a dentist 20 years ago to run the Professional Enterprises Organization in Queens. "People who want to be beautiful are willing to pay the price themselves."
His business, he said, takes advantage of the fact that most doctors are not trained, or inclined, to be businessmen. "We buy buildings, rehabilitate them and equip them for medical uses," he said. "In today's environment, the most successful doctors are the ones who have a businessman to negotiate contracts, buy equipment and so forth."
Another businessman who manages doctors is Philip Villacci, the chief executive of Mid-Manhattan Medical Associates. The group has 25 doctors scattered over 17 locations between 59th and 90th Streets on the East and West Sides of Manhattan.
The group has leased two floors at 654 Madison Avenue, at the northeast corner of 60th Street, and Mr. Villacci said the plan is to consolidate many of the practices at that location as individual leases expire.
He said the financial squeeze of managed care has curbed the once-fierce independence some doctors were known for. "Economics has overcome ego," he said. "Now it is like managing the Yankees. Everybody is a star, but occasionally someone will have to bunt."
The same cost pressures that are pushing doctors into groups are squeezing hospitals as well, touching off a wave of mergers. A survey conducted by the accounting firm Price Waterhouse indicated that as many as 2,000 of the nation's 6,000 tertiary-care hospitals may close by 2000, throwing some pricey real estate on the market.
"It used to be that health care drove real estate, but now it is real estate that is driving health care," said Deborah Kops, a corporate real estate consultant at Price Waterhouse. "The average health care facility has 50 percent of its assets tied up in real estate, so they are simply going to have to manage more aggressively."
Hospitals are expensive because, like medical offices, they need lots of plumbing to deliver water and medical gases and carry away waste water. They also need extensive wiring to serve diagnostic machinery and other equipment.
They must also have advanced air-handling equipment to prevent diseases from being spread, and the ability to quickly isolate an area if fire breaks out. Unlike an office building, where people can be expected to leave under their own power in an emergency, patients in hospitals are essentially immobile.
AS a rule of thumb, hospitals cost twice as much to build per square foot as office buildings, said Charles G. Siconolfi, a health-care specialist with the architectural firm Hellmuth Obata Kassabaum.
It is not clear what will happen to those empty hospitals, experts say. In some cases a sale will involve rewriting history. "A lot of health-care facilities were financed on a tax-exempt basis, so there are a lot of covenants and restrictions which will be hard to disgorge," said Ms. Kops. "It will be difficult to deliver a piece of real estate that looks like a shopping center."
There have been suggestions that as the number of acute-care, or hospital, beds shrinks, the buildings themselves can be converted to non-acute, or nursing, care. But the inherently high cost of operating hospital building, particularly in urban locations, may make nursing-home application impractical, unless there is some kind of subsidy.
"The only people who can operate sub-acute operations economically are the chains," Mr. Siconolfi said, "and they seem to have a formula that involves building on an open site, so they probably would not be interested in taking over an existing building."
